quote: But whenever I say that I will do this or that, it looks very different when the time comes.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But whenever I say that I will do this or that, it looks very different when the time comes.
summary: This quote means that when the speaker makes plans or says they will do something, the actual situation often turns out to be very different from what they expected when it's time to do it. It highlights how intentions and spoken commitments can frequently differ from the practical outcome when the moment for action truly arrives.

quote: Actually I am a Christian, and indeed a Roman Catholic, so that I do not expect 'history' to be anything but a 'long defeat' - though it contains (and in a legend may contain more clearly and movingly) some samples or glimpses of final victory. (Letter #195)
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Actually I am a Christian, and indeed a Roman Catholic, so that I do not expect 'history' to be anything but a 'long defeat' - though it contains (and in a legend may contain more clearly and movingly) some samples or glimpses of final victory. (Letter #195)
summary: As a devout Roman Catholic, the author believes that human history is essentially a continuous struggle or "long defeat." This perspective stems from his faith, which teaches that while humanity strives, true and complete victory—spiritual salvation and the ultimate triumph of good—is not fully achieved in this earthly realm. However, he also recognizes that within this ongoing struggle, there are moments, or even stories and legends, that offer glimpses and promises of an ultimate, final triumph, hinting at a divine purpose that will eventually prevail.

quote: Justice is not Healing. Healing cometh only by suffering and patience, and maketh no demand, not even for Justice. Justice worketh only within the bonds of things as they are... and therefore though Justice is itself good and desireth no further evil, it can but perpetuate the evil that was, and doth not prevent it from the bearing of fruit in sorrow.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Justice is not Healing. Healing cometh only by suffering and patience, and maketh no demand, not even for Justice. Justice worketh only within the bonds of things as they are... and therefore though Justice is itself good and desireth no further evil, it can but perpetuate the evil that was, and doth not prevent it from the bearing of fruit in sorrow.
summary: This quote suggests that justice and healing are two very different things. True healing, it argues, comes only through enduring suffering and patience, and notably, it doesn't demand justice as a prerequisite. Justice, on the other hand, operates within the existing rules and realities of the world. Therefore, while justice is inherently good and doesn't wish for more harm, it can only address past wrongs within its established framework. This means it might inadvertently perpetuate the lingering effects of past evils, rather than preventing them from causing continued sorrow.

quote:
The consolation of fairy-stories, the joy of the happy ending: or more correctly of the good catastrophe, the sudden joyous turn (for there is no true end to any fairy-tale): this joy, which is one of the things which fairy-stories can produce supremely well, is not essentially escapist, nor fugitive. In its fairy-tale--or otherworld--setting, it is a sudden and miraculous grace: never to be counted on to recur. It does not deny the existence of dyscatastrophe, of sorrow and failure: the possibility of these is necessary to the joy of deliverance; it denies (in the face of much evidence, if you will) universal final defeat and in so far is evangelium, giving a fleeting glimpse of Joy, Joy beyond the walls of the world, poignant as grief.

It is the mark of a good fairy-story, of the higher or more complete kind, that however wild its events, however fantastic or terrible the adventures, it can give to child or man that hears it, when the turn comes, a catch of the breath, a beat and lifting of the heart, near to (or indeed accompanied by) tears, as keen as that given by any form of literary art, and having a peculiar quality ... In such stories when the sudden turn comes we get a piercing glimpse of joy, and heart's desire, that for a moment passes outside the frame, rends indeed the very web of story, and lets a gleam come through.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The consolation of fairy-stories, the joy of the happy ending: or more correctly of the good catastrophe, the sudden joyous turn (for there is no true end to any fairy-tale): this joy, which is one of the things which fairy-stories can produce supremely well, is not essentially escapist, nor fugitive. In its fairy-tale--or otherworld--setting, it is a sudden and miraculous grace: never to be counted on to recur. It does not deny the existence of dyscatastrophe, of sorrow and failure: the possibility of these is necessary to the joy of deliverance; it denies (in the face of much evidence, if you will) universal final defeat and in so far is evangelium, giving a fleeting glimpse of Joy, Joy beyond the walls of the world, poignant as grief.

It is the mark of a good fairy-story, of the higher or more complete kind, that however wild its events, however fantastic or terrible the adventures, it can give to child or man that hears it, when the turn comes, a catch of the breath, a beat and lifting of the heart, near to (or indeed accompanied by) tears, as keen as that given by any form of literary art, and having a peculiar quality ... In such stories when the sudden turn comes we get a piercing glimpse of joy, and heart's desire, that for a moment passes outside the frame, rends indeed the very web of story, and lets a gleam come through.
summary: The author explains that the joy found in fairy tales, especially the "happy ending" or "good catastrophe" (a sudden, joyous turn of events), is not just a way to escape reality. Instead, this joy is a rare and miraculous gift that doesn't deny the existence of sorrow or failure. However, it *does* deny the idea of universal, final defeat, offering a brief glimpse of profound, almost spiritual joy that exists beyond our everyday world. A good fairy tale, no matter how wild or scary its events, can make the listener gasp, feel their heart lift, and even shed tears when this happy turn comes, providing a piercing and unique sense of joy that feels so real it momentarily transcends the story itself.

quote: It needs but one foe to breed a war, not two, Master Warden,' answered Éowyn. 'And those who have not swords can still die upon them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It needs but one foe to breed a war, not two, Master Warden,' answered Éowyn. 'And those who have not swords can still die upon them.
summary: Éowyn explains that it only takes one enemy to start a war, not two willing parties. She means that a conflict can be initiated by a single aggressor, regardless of whether the other side wants to fight. Furthermore, she emphasizes that even those who are unarmed or defenseless can still be killed by the violence of war.

quote: It is best to love first what you are fitted to love, I suppose: you must start somewhere and have some roots, and the soil of the Shire is deep. Still there are things deeper and higher; and not a gaffer could tend his garden in what he calls peace but for them, whether he knows about them or not. I am glad that I know about them, a little.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is best to love first what you are fitted to love, I suppose: you must start somewhere and have some roots, and the soil of the Shire is deep. Still there are things deeper and higher; and not a gaffer could tend his garden in what he calls peace but for them, whether he knows about them or not. I am glad that I know about them, a little.
summary: The speaker believes it's natural and necessary to first love what is familiar and close to home, like the deep-rooted traditions and comforting environment of the Shire. This provides a vital starting point and a sense of belonging. However, they emphasize that there are even more profound and fundamental forces at play in the world. These deeper truths are essential for maintaining peace and well-being, even for everyday life, whether people are aware of them or not. The speaker expresses a quiet satisfaction in having at least a small understanding of these greater underlying principles.

quote:
The eyes were hollow and the carven head was broken, but about the high, stern forehead there was a coronal of silver and gold. A trailing plant with flowers like white stars had bound itself across the brows as if in reverence for the fallen king, and in the crevices of his stony hair yellow stonecrop gleamed.

"They cannot conquer for ever!" said Frodo.

quote: Is everything sad going to come untrue?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Is everything sad going to come untrue?
summary: The quote, "Is everything sad going to come untrue?" is a deeply hopeful and poignant question. It expresses a profound longing for a future where all the pain, sorrow, and difficult experiences of life are not just forgotten, but somehow undone, reversed, or redeemed. Essentially, it asks if there will be a time when the weight of all past sadness is lifted, its effects are nullified, and joy ultimately prevails.

quote: Elves and Dragons! I says to him. Cabbages and potatoes are better for me and you.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Elves and Dragons! I says to him. Cabbages and potatoes are better for me and you.

They are suggesting that focusing on tangible, humble things that truly sustain you is far more beneficial and sensible than chasing elaborate dreams or getting lost in fantasy.

quote: Elen síla lúmenn' omentielvo
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Elen síla lúmenn' omentielvo

It's a beautiful and hopeful greeting, suggesting that the encounter between two people is a fortunate, blessed, and perhaps even destined event. The star symbolizes good fortune, light, and a sense of auspiciousness surrounding their connection.

quote: It is plain that we were meant to go together.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is plain that we were meant to go together.
summary: This quote means it's incredibly clear and obvious that two people, ideas, or things are perfectly suited for each other. It suggests a strong sense of destiny or a natural, undeniable connection, as if they were always meant to be together. There's no doubt; their partnership or shared path feels entirely right and preordained.

quote: I will not give you counsel, saying do this, or do that. For not in doing or contriving, nor in choosing between this course and another, can I avail; but only in knowing what was and is, and in part also what shall be.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I will not give you counsel, saying do this, or do that. For not in doing or contriving, nor in choosing between this course and another, can I avail; but only in knowing what was and is, and in part also what shall be.
summary: The speaker explains they won't give direct advice on specific actions, telling someone "do this" or "do that." They believe their usefulness doesn't come from dictating what to do, how to plan, or which choices to make. Instead, their strength lies solely in understanding the fundamental nature of things – what has happened, what is currently happening, and what is likely to occur in the future. Their value is in their knowledge of reality, not in telling others how to act within it.

quote: Without the high and noble the simple and vulgar is utterly mean; and without the simple and ordinary the noble and heroic is meaningless
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Without the high and noble the simple and vulgar is utterly mean; and without the simple and ordinary the noble and heroic is meaningless
summary: This quote suggests that grand ideals and heroic acts are essential for giving meaning and dignity to our ordinary lives, preventing them from feeling trivial or base. However, it also emphasizes that without the everyday reality and common experiences, those noble and heroic deeds would lack a foundation or purpose, becoming meaningless themselves. Essentially, the extraordinary and the ordinary are deeply intertwined and depend on each other to have true significance.

quote: I am going with him, if he climbs to the Moon.

quote: His head was swimming, and he was far from certain even of the direction they had been going in when he had his fall. It was a turning point in his career, but he did not know it. He put the ring in his pocket almost without thinking; certainly it did not seem of any particular use at the moment.

quote:

quote: The Recovered Thing is not quite the same as the Thing-never-lost. It is often more precious. As Grace, recovered by repentance, is not the same as primitive Innocence, but is not necessarily a poorer or worse state.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Recovered Thing is not quite the same as the Thing-never-lost. It is often more precious. As Grace, recovered by repentance, is not the same as primitive Innocence, but is not necessarily a poorer or worse state.
summary: This quote suggests that something we regain after it's been lost is not identical to something we've always possessed. However, this recovered state or item often holds greater value. It illustrates this by comparing spiritual "Grace" (a state of goodness) that is restored through repentance (admitting and atoning for wrongs) to "primitive Innocence" (a state of never having sinned). While different, the quote emphasizes that this recovered Grace is not necessarily inferior; in fact, it can be just as good, or even more precious, than the original, untainted state.

quote: The Light failed; but the Darkness that followed was more than loss of light.

Instead, it's a much worse and more impactful situation. It suggests that the resulting period is actively negative, bringing problems, despair, or even destruction, rather than just an empty space where good once was.

quote: I wish it need not have happened in my time,’ said Frodo. ‘So do I,’ said Gandalf, ‘and so do all who live to see such times. But that is not for them to decide. All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.

summary: Frodo expresses a common wish that the difficult times he's living through weren't happening during his life. Gandalf agrees that everyone facing such challenges feels the same way. The message is to focus on action and responsibility within the present moment, rather than lamenting uncontrollable events.

quote: We may stand, if only on one leg, or at least be left still upon our knees.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We may stand, if only on one leg, or at least be left still upon our knees.
summary: This quote suggests that even when facing extreme difficulty, we should try to maintain some form of resilience or dignity. It means that while we might only be able to stand precariously, like on one leg, that's still better than completely falling. And if standing isn't possible, the next best thing is to remain in a stable, though humbled, position on our knees, rather than being utterly defeated or broken down. It's about finding a way to endure and hold on, even in the weakest state.

quote: What did I tell you, Mr. Pippin?' said Sam, sheathing his sword. 'Wolves won't get him. That was an eye-opener, and no mistake! Nearly singed the hair off my head!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: What did I tell you, Mr. Pippin?' said Sam, sheathing his sword. 'Wolves won't get him. That was an eye-opener, and no mistake! Nearly singed the hair off my head!
summary: Sam, putting away his sword, confidently told Mr. Pippin that his earlier prediction was correct: the wolves would not harm the person they were protecting. He then expressed how intense and surprising the experience had been, describing it as a truly shocking moment that was so close to being disastrous it felt like it almost burned the hair off his head.

quote: I perceived or thought of the Light of God and in it suspended one small mote (or millions of motes to only one of which was my small mind directed), glittering white because of the individual ray from the Light which both held and lit it...And the ray was the Guardian Angel of the mote: not a thing interposed between God and the creature, but God's very attention itself, personalized...This is a finite parallel to the Infinite. As the love of the Father and Son (who are infinite and equal) is a Person, so the love and attention of the Light to the Mote is a person (that is both with us and in Heaven): finite but divine, i.e. angelic.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I perceived or thought of the Light of God and in it suspended one small mote (or millions of motes to only one of which was my small mind directed), glittering white because of the individual ray from the Light which both held and lit it...And the ray was the Guardian Angel of the mote: not a thing interposed between God and the creature, but God's very attention itself, personalized...This is a finite parallel to the Infinite. As the love of the Father and Son (who are infinite and equal) is a Person, so the love and attention of the Light to the Mote is a person (that is both with us and in Heaven): finite but divine, i.e. angelic.
summary: The author imagines God as a vast, brilliant light, from which individual rays extend to each person, seen as a tiny "mote." This personal ray not only holds and lights the mote but is also understood as the person's Guardian Angel. Crucially, this angel is not a separate being, but rather God's own direct, personalized attention and love focused on that individual. Drawing a parallel to the Christian concept of the Trinity where the love between God the Father and Son is a "Person," the author suggests that God's specific, loving attention to each person is also a "person"—an angelic, divine presence that is both with us and in heaven, embodying God's personal care.

quote:
All now took leave of the Lord of the City and went to rest while they still could. Outside there was a starless blackness as Gandalf, with Pippin beside him bearing a small torch, made his way to their lodging. They did not speak until they were behind closed doors. Then at last Pippin took Gandalf's hand.

'Tell me,' he said, 'is there any hope? For Frodo, I mean; or at least mostly for Frodo.'

Gandalf put his hand on Pippin's head. 'There never was much hope,' he answered. 'Just a fool's hope, as I have been told. And when I heard of Cirith Ungol--' He broke off and strode to the window, as if his eyes could pierce the night in the East. 'Cirith Ungol!' he muttered. 'Why that way, I wonder?' He turned. 'Just now, Pippin, my heart almost failed me, hearing that name. And yet in truth I believe that the news that Faramir brings has some hope in it. For it seems clear that the Enemy has opened his war at last and made the first move when Frodo was still free. So now for many days he will have his eye turned this way and that, away from his own land. And yet, Pippin, I feel from afar his haste and fear. He has begun sooner than he would. Something has happened to stir him.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All now took leave of the Lord of the City and went to rest while they still could. Outside there was a starless blackness as Gandalf, with Pippin beside him bearing a small torch, made his way to their lodging. They did not speak until they were behind closed doors. Then at last Pippin took Gandalf's hand.

'Tell me,' he said, 'is there any hope? For Frodo, I mean; or at least mostly for Frodo.'

Gandalf put his hand on Pippin's head. 'There never was much hope,' he answered. 'Just a fool's hope, as I have been told. And when I heard of Cirith Ungol--' He broke off and strode to the window, as if his eyes could pierce the night in the East. 'Cirith Ungol!' he muttered. 'Why that way, I wonder?' He turned. 'Just now, Pippin, my heart almost failed me, hearing that name. And yet in truth I believe that the news that Faramir brings has some hope in it. For it seems clear that the Enemy has opened his war at last and made the first move when Frodo was still free. So now for many days he will have his eye turned this way and that, away from his own land. And yet, Pippin, I feel from afar his haste and fear. He has begun sooner than he would. Something has happened to stir him.
summary: After a long day, Pippin, feeling despair, asks Gandalf if there is any hope left, especially for Frodo. Gandalf initially admits there was never much hope, calling it a "fool's hope," and is deeply troubled by the mention of Cirith Ungol, a dangerous path Frodo might have taken. However, he then finds a cautious glimmer of hope in the news brought by Faramir. Gandalf reasons that because the Enemy has launched his war sooner than expected, while Frodo was still free, his attention will now be divided and focused on the ongoing conflict rather than solely on finding Frodo. This premature attack, Gandalf believes, suggests the Enemy is reacting to something, feeling a sense of haste and fear, which might unexpectedly work in Frodo's favor.

quote: Here ends the SILMARILLION. If it has passed from the high and the beautiful to darkness and ruin, that was of old the fate of Arda Marred; and if any change shall come and the Marring be amended, Manwë and Varda may know; but they have not revealed it, and it is not declared in the dooms of Mandos.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Here ends the SILMARILLION. If it has passed from the high and the beautiful to darkness and ruin, that was of old the fate of Arda Marred; and if any change shall come and the Marring be amended, Manwë and Varda may know; but they have not revealed it, and it is not declared in the dooms of Mandos.
summary: This passage marks the end of "The Silmarillion." It suggests that if the story's events moved from a state of beauty and goodness to one of darkness and ruin, it's because the world itself, Arda, was already damaged or "marred" a long time ago. The author implies that if this damage is ever to be fixed, only powerful beings like Manwë and Varda would know, but they haven't revealed it, and it's not foretold in any known prophecies or destinies.

quote:
And so Gollum found them hours later, when he returned, crawling and creeping down the path out of the gloom ahead. Sam sat propped against the stone, his head dropping sideways and his breathing heavy. In his lap lay Frodo's head, drowned in sleep; upon his white forehead lay one of Sam's brown hands, and the other lay softly upon his master's breast. Peace was in both their faces.
Gollum looked at them. A strange expression passed over his lean hungry face. The gleam faded from his eyes, and they went dim and grey, old and tired. A spasm of pain seemed to twist him, and he turned away, peering back up towards the pass, shaking his head, as if engaged in some interior debate. Then he came back, and slowly putting out a trembling hand, very cautiously he touched Frodo's knee--but almost the touch was a caress. For a fleeting moment, could one of the sleepers have seen him, they would have thought that they beheld an old weary hobbit, shrunken by the years that had carried him far beyond his time, beyond friends and kin, and the fields and streams of youth, an old starved pitiable thing.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: And so Gollum found them hours later, when he returned, crawling and creeping down the path out of the gloom ahead. Sam sat propped against the stone, his head dropping sideways and his breathing heavy. In his lap lay Frodo's head, drowned in sleep; upon his white forehead lay one of Sam's brown hands, and the other lay softly upon his master's breast. Peace was in both their faces.
Gollum looked at them. A strange expression passed over his lean hungry face. The gleam faded from his eyes, and they went dim and grey, old and tired. A spasm of pain seemed to twist him, and he turned away, peering back up towards the pass, shaking his head, as if engaged in some interior debate. Then he came back, and slowly putting out a trembling hand, very cautiously he touched Frodo's knee--but almost the touch was a caress. For a fleeting moment, could one of the sleepers have seen him, they would have thought that they beheld an old weary hobbit, shrunken by the years that had carried him far beyond his time, beyond friends and kin, and the fields and streams of youth, an old starved pitiable thing.
summary: When Gollum returned, he found Sam and Frodo asleep, peacefully resting with Frodo's head in Sam's lap. As Gollum watched them, a strange change came over him; his usual hungry look faded, and his eyes grew dim and tired, as if he felt a pang of pain and was struggling with an inner conflict. He then cautiously reached out a trembling hand and gently touched Frodo's knee, almost like a caress. For a brief moment, he didn't seem like the monstrous Gollum, but rather a weary, old, and pitiful hobbit, shrunken by time and hardship.

quote: Life is rather above the measure of us all (save for a very few perhaps). We all need literature that is above our measure--though we may not have sufficient energy for it all the time.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Life is rather above the measure of us all (save for a very few perhaps). We all need literature that is above our measure--though we may not have sufficient energy for it all the time.
summary: This quote suggests that life is generally too vast and complex for most people to fully grasp or master. Because life presents such a challenge, we need to engage with literature that also stretches our minds and makes us think deeply, pushing us beyond our current understanding. Even though reading such demanding material requires significant effort and we may not always feel up to it, it is crucial for our intellectual and personal growth.

quote: On two chairs beneath the bole of the tree and canopied by a living bough there sat, side by side, Celeborn and Galadriel. Very tall they were, and the Lady no less tall than the Lord; and they were grave and beautiful. They were clad wholly in white; and the hair of the Lady was of deep gold, and the hair of the Lord Celeborn was of silver long and bright; but no sign of age was upon them, unless it were in the depths of their eyes; for these were keen as lances in the starlight, and yet profound, the wells of deep memory.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: On two chairs beneath the bole of the tree and canopied by a living bough there sat, side by side, Celeborn and Galadriel. They were clad wholly in white; and the hair of the Lady was of deep gold, and the hair of the Lord Celeborn was of silver long and bright; but no sign of age was upon them, unless it were in the depths of their eyes; for these were keen as lances in the starlight, and yet profound, the wells of deep memory.
summary: Celeborn and Galadriel were seated together under a large tree. They were both exceptionally tall, equally so, and possessed a serious yet beautiful appearance. They wore all white, and Galadriel had deep gold hair, while Celeborn's hair was long, bright silver. Despite their ancient wisdom, they showed no outward signs of age, except perhaps in their eyes, which were both incredibly sharp and held a profound depth, hinting at vast memories.

quote: There is no real going back. Though I may come to the Shire, it will not seem the same; for I shall not be the same. I am wounded with knife, sting, and tooth, and a long burden. Where shall I find rest?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is no real going back. Though I may come to the Shire, it will not seem the same; for I shall not be the same. I am wounded with knife, sting, and tooth, and a long burden. Where shall I find rest?
summary: The speaker feels that they can never truly go back to how things were before. Even if they return to their familiar home, it won't feel the same because they themselves have been profoundly changed by their experiences. They explain that they are deeply wounded by various painful events and have carried a heavy burden for a long time. Because of all this, they are exhausted and desperately wonder where they might ever find peace or rest.

quote: I would have followed you. My brother. My captain. My king.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I would have followed you. My brother. My captain. My king.
summary: This quote expresses a profound sense of loyalty, admiration, and regret. The speaker held the person they are addressing in the highest regard, seeing them not just as a beloved family member ('My brother'), but also as a trusted leader ('My captain') and an ultimate authority figure worthy of complete devotion ('My king'). The phrase "I would have followed you" conveys that despite this deep respect and desire to follow, circumstances prevented them from doing so, suggesting a missed opportunity or a final parting.

quote: No onslaught more fierce was ever seen in the savage world of beasts, where some desperate small creature armed with little teeth, alone, will spring upon a tower of horn and hide that stands above its fallen mate.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: No onslaught more fierce was ever seen in the savage world of beasts, where some desperate small creature armed with little teeth, alone, will spring upon a tower of horn and hide that stands above its fallen mate.
summary: This quote describes the most incredibly fierce and desperate kind of fight, likening it to the brutal world of animals. It paints a picture of a small, weak creature, armed only with tiny teeth, launching a solo, suicidal attack against a massive, powerful beast. This desperate act is driven by the fact that the larger enemy is standing victorious over the small creature's fallen or defeated mate.

quote: the association of children and fairy-stories is an accident of our domestic history. Fairy-stories have in the modern lettered world been relegated to the nursery, as shabby or old-fashioned furniture is relegated to the play-room, primarily because the adults do not want it, and do not mind if it is misused.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: the association of children and fairy-stories is an accident of our domestic history. Fairy-stories have in the modern lettered world been relegated to the nursery, as shabby or old-fashioned furniture is relegated to the play-room, primarily because the adults do not want it, and do not mind if it is misused.
summary: This quote suggests that fairy tales are associated with children not because they are inherently meant for kids, but due to a historical quirk in our homes. In modern, educated society, adults have relegated fairy tales to the nursery, treating them much like old or out-of-style furniture moved to a playroom. This is primarily because adults themselves no longer value these stories and therefore don't care if children don't fully understand or even "misuse" them.

quote: Follow what may, great deeds are not lessened in worth.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Follow what may, great deeds are not lessened in worth.
summary: This quote means that the true value of a good or important action is not affected by future events or consequences. No matter what challenges or difficulties arise later, the worth and significance of a great deed remain strong and undiminished. It emphasizes that noble actions hold their value intrinsically, regardless of external outcomes.

quote: Arrow! Black arrow! I have saved you to the last. You have never failed me and I have always recovered you. I had you from my father and he from of old. If ever you came from the forges of the true king under the Mountain, go now and speed well!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Arrow! Black arrow! I have saved you to the last. You have never failed me and I have always recovered you. I had you from my father and he from of old. If ever you came from the forges of the true king under the Mountain, go now and speed well!
summary: The speaker addresses a very special black arrow, which is their last and most trusted weapon. They express deep faith in it, saying it has never failed them and they've always managed to get it back. The arrow is an old family heirloom, passed down through generations. In a final plea, the speaker hopes that the arrow's legendary power, possibly from the forges of an ancient king, will ensure its success in this critical moment.

quote: But the only measure that he knows is desire desire for power and so he judges all hearts. Into his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it that having the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this we shall put him out of reckoning.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But the only measure that he knows is desire desire for power and so he judges all hearts. Into his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it that having the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this we shall put him out of reckoning.
summary: This quote explains that a powerful character (implied to be an antagonist like Sauron) only understands the desire for power and assumes everyone else is motivated by the same ambition. He cannot even imagine that someone who possesses his powerful Ring would choose to destroy it rather than use it. His inability to comprehend such an act of selflessness or rejection of power is his greatest weakness, and if his opponents actually try to destroy the Ring, it will be his undoing.

quote: Don't be a fool Mr. Baggins if you can help it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Don't be a fool Mr. Baggins if you can help it.
summary: This quote is a direct piece of advice telling Mr. Baggins to avoid acting foolishly or making unwise decisions whenever he has the power to do so. It's a warning to think carefully and choose wisely, rather than being impulsive or reckless. The phrase "if you can help it" is key; it implies that while there might be situations where foolishness seems unavoidable, he should always strive to be sensible and intelligent in his actions, making a conscious effort to avoid poor choices.

quote: Yet dawn is ever the hope of men.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Yet dawn is ever the hope of men.
summary: This quote means that no matter how dark or difficult a situation may be, people always find a constant source of hope in the idea of a new beginning. Just as the dawn breaks through the night, symbolizing an end to darkness and a fresh start, humanity consistently looks forward to a better future. It suggests that even after the toughest times, the promise of a new day – a chance to start over or for things to improve – remains a fundamental and enduring source of optimism for everyone.

quote: Some of my kin look just like trees now, and need something great to rouse them; and they speak only in whispers. But some of my trees are limb-lithe, and many can talk to me.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Some of my kin look just like trees now, and need something great to rouse them; and they speak only in whispers. But some of my trees are limb-lithe, and many can talk to me.

However, the speaker also notes that other trees, or perhaps a different group of their kind, are agile and lively, and many of them are capable of open communication.

Essentially, fairies often hide their true nature behind an alluring facade that we wish we could possess.

quote:
Now when Túrin learnt from Finduilas of what had passed, he was wrathful, and he said to Gwindor: 'In love I hold you for your rescue and sake-keeping. But now you have done ill to me, friend, to betray my right name, and call my doom upon me, from which I would lie hid.'
But Gwindor answered: 'The doom lies in yourself, not in your name.

quote: Saruman," I said, standing away from him, "only one hand at a time can wield the One, and you know that well, so do not trouble to say we!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Saruman," I said, standing away from him, "only one hand at a time can wield the One, and you know that well, so do not trouble to say we!
summary: The speaker is firmly telling Saruman not to use the word "we" when discussing their plans, especially regarding something as immensely powerful as "the One" (referring to the One Ring). They remind Saruman that such ultimate power can only ever be controlled by one person at a time, never by a partnership or group. The speaker emphasizes that Saruman knows this truth very well, essentially calling him out for pretending there could be a shared alliance or control when, in reality, it's always about singular dominion.

quote: Perhaps it is better not to tell what you wish. if you cannot have it.

quote:
With a suddenness that startled them all the wizard sprang to his feet. He was laughing! "I have it!" he cried. "Of course, of course! Absurdly simple, like most riddles when you see the answer."

Picking up his staff he stood before the rock and said in a clear voice: Mellon!

The star shone out briefly and faded again. Then silently a great doorway was outlined, though not a crack or joint had been visible before. Slowly it divided in the middle and swung outwards inch by inch, until both doors lay back against the wall.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: With a suddenness that startled them all the wizard sprang to his feet. He was laughing! "I have it!" he cried. "Of course, of course! Absurdly simple, like most riddles when you see the answer."

Picking up his staff he stood before the rock and said in a clear voice: Mellon!

The star shone out briefly and faded again. Then silently a great doorway was outlined, though not a crack or joint had been visible before. Slowly it divided in the middle and swung outwards inch by inch, until both doors lay back against the wall.
summary: The wizard suddenly had a breakthrough, realizing the surprisingly simple answer to a riddle and laughing with delight. He then approached a large rock and, speaking the word "Mellon!" aloud, caused a star to briefly appear. Immediately afterward, a hidden doorway silently materialized where no crack had been visible before, slowly dividing and swinging open to reveal a passage.

quote: But do not despise the lore that has come down from distant years; for oft it may chance that old wives keep in memory word of things that once were needful for the wise to know.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But do not despise the lore that has come down from distant years; for oft it may chance that old wives keep in memory word of things that once were needful for the wise to know.
summary: This quote advises us not to dismiss old knowledge or traditions simply because they are ancient. It suggests that often, seemingly simple or common folk, like "old wives," preserve valuable insights and practical wisdom that was once considered essential even for the most intelligent people. Therefore, we shouldn't undervalue these traditional sources, as they may still contain important lessons relevant today.

quote: Master Meriadoc,’ said Aragorn, ‘if you think that I have passed through the mountains and the realm of Gondor with fire and sword to bring herbs to a careless soldier who throws away his gear, you are mistaken, If your pack has not been found, then you must send for the herb-master of this House, And he will tell you that he did not know the herb you desire had any virtues, but that it is called westmansweed by the vulgar, and galenas by the noble, and other names in other tongues more learned, and after adding a few half-forgotten rhymes that he does not understand, he will regretfully inform you that there is none in the House, and he will leave you to reflect on the history of tongues.

quote: But there, my friends, songs like trees bear fruit only in their own time and their own way: and sometimes they are withered untimely.

quote: So most men teach, and few men learn.

In essence, there's a lot of talking and telling, but not much genuine listening or personal growth happening.

quote: There are many things in the deep waters; and seas and lands may change. And it is not our part here to take thought only for a season, or for a few lives of Men, or for a passing age of the world. We should seek a final end of this menace, even if we do not hope to make one.

quote:
The king was silent. "Ents!" he said at length. "Out of the shadows of legend I begin a little to understand the marvel of the trees, I think. I have lived to see strange days. Long we have tended our beasts and our fields, built our houses, wrought our tools, or ridden away to help in the wars of Minas Tirith. And that we called the life of Men, the way of the world.
We cared little for what lay beyond the borders of our land. Songs we have that tell of these things, but we are forgetting them, teaching them only to children, as a careless custom. And now the songs have come down among us out of the strange places, and walk visible under the Sun."
"You should be glad," Théoden King," said Gandalf. "For not only the little life of Men is now endangered, but the life also of those thing which you have deemed the matter of legend. You are not without allies, even if you know them not."
"Yet also I should be sad," said Théoden. "For however the fortune of war shall go, may it not so end that much that was fair and wonderful shall pass for ever out of Middle-earth?
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The king was silent. "Ents!" he said at length. Long we have tended our beasts and our fields, built our houses, wrought our tools, or ridden away to help in the wars of Minas Tirith. And that we called the life of Men, the way of the world.
We cared little for what lay beyond the borders of our land. Songs we have that tell of these things, but we are forgetting them, teaching them only to children, as a careless custom. And now the songs have come down among us out of the strange places, and walk visible under the Sun."
"You should be glad," Théoden King," said Gandalf. "For not only the little life of Men is now endangered, but the life also of those thing which you have deemed the matter of legend. You are not without allies, even if you know them not."
"Yet also I should be sad," said Théoden. "For however the fortune of war shall go, may it not so end that much that was fair and wonderful shall pass for ever out of Middle-earth?
summary: King Théoden is astonished by the sight of the legendary Ents, realizing that creatures previously thought to be mere myths are real. He reflects on how his people have always focused on their practical, everyday human lives—tending fields, building homes, and fighting wars—and have largely forgotten or dismissed the ancient, wondrous tales beyond their borders as just children's stories. Now, these very legends have come to life and are walking among them. Gandalf points out that this is actually a good thing, as these legendary beings are also endangered and can be unexpected allies. However, Théoden expresses a deeper sadness, fearing that no matter the outcome of the war, much of what is fair and wonderful, including these newly revealed wonders, might disappear from Middle-earth forever.

quote: The romantic chivalric tradition takes, or at any rate has in the past taken, the young man's eye off women as they are, as companions in shipwreck not guiding stars.

quote:
Are we riding far tonight, Gandalf? asked Merry after a while. I don’t know how you feel with small rag-tag dangling behind you; but the rag-tag is tired and will be glad to stop dangling and lie down.
So you heard that? said Gandalf. Don’t let it rankle! Be thankful no longer words were aimed at you. He had his eyes on you. If it is any comfort to your pride, I should say that, at the moment, you and Pippin are more in his thoughts than the rest of us. Who you are; how you came here, and why; what you know; whether you were captured, and if so, how you escaped when all the orcs perished—it is with those little riddles that the great mind of Saruman is troubled. A sneer from him, Meriadoc, is a compliment, if you feel honoured by his concern.
Thank you! said Merry. But it is a greater honour to dangle at your tail, Gandalf. For one thing, in that position one has a chance of putting a question a second time. Are we riding far tonight?
Gandalf laughed. A most unquenchable hobbit! All wizards should have a hobbit or two in their care—to teach them the meaning of the world, and to correct them.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Are we riding far tonight, Gandalf? asked Merry after a while. I don’t know how you feel with small rag-tag dangling behind you; but the rag-tag is tired and will be glad to stop dangling and lie down.
So you heard that? said Gandalf. Don’t let it rankle! Be thankful no longer words were aimed at you. He had his eyes on you. If it is any comfort to your pride, I should say that, at the moment, you and Pippin are more in his thoughts than the rest of us. Who you are; how you came here, and why; what you know; whether you were captured, and if so, how you escaped when all the orcs perished—it is with those little riddles that the great mind of Saruman is troubled. A sneer from him, Meriadoc, is a compliment, if you feel honoured by his concern.
Thank you! said Merry. But it is a greater honour to dangle at your tail, Gandalf. For one thing, in that position one has a chance of putting a question a second time. Are we riding far tonight?
Gandalf laughed. A most unquenchable hobbit! All wizards should have a hobbit or two in their care—to teach them the meaning of the world, and to correct them.
summary: Merry, tired from a long journey, asks Gandalf when they will finally stop for the night, feeling like an unimportant burden. Gandalf explains that Saruman, who just sneered at them, is actually deeply troubled and curious about Merry and Pippin. Saruman is trying to understand who they are, how they got there, what they know, and how they managed to escape. Gandalf reassures Merry that Saruman's dismissive attitude is actually a sign of how much the powerful wizard is preoccupied with them. Unfazed, Merry cleverly repeats his original question about stopping. Gandalf, amused by Merry's persistent and practical nature, praises hobbits for their ability to challenge and teach even the wisest wizards.

quote: Faithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens,’ said Gimli. ‘Maybe,’ said Elrond, ‘but let him not vow to walk in the dark, who has not seen the nightfall.’ ‘Yet sworn word may strengthen quaking heart,’ said Gimli. ‘Or break it,’ said Elrond.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Faithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens,’ said Gimli. ‘Maybe,’ said Elrond, ‘but let him not vow to walk in the dark, who has not seen the nightfall.’ ‘Yet sworn word may strengthen quaking heart,’ said Gimli. ‘Or break it,’ said Elrond.
summary: This dialogue explores the nature of commitment and promises. Gimli believes it's disloyal to abandon a commitment when difficulties arise. Elrond agrees it might be, but warns against making solemn vows without truly understanding the full extent of the challenges ahead. Gimli counters that a sworn promise can give a person courage and resolve when they are afraid. However, Elrond wisely points out that such a promise, if made without foresight, can just as easily overwhelm and break a person.

quote:
All that the unsuspecting Bilbo saw that morning was an old man with a staff. He had a tall pointed blue hat, a long grey cloak, a silver scarf over which his long white beard hung down below his waist, and immense black boots.

"Good morning!" said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.

"What do you mean?" he said. "Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I wish it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?"

"All of them at once," said Bilbo. "And a very fine morning for a pipe of tobacco out of doors, into the bargain." Then Bilbo sat down on a seat by his door, crossed his legs, and blew out a beautiful grey ring of smoke that sailed up into the air without breaking and floated away over The Hill.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All that the unsuspecting Bilbo saw that morning was an old man with a staff. He had a tall pointed blue hat, a long grey cloak, a silver scarf over which his long white beard hung down below his waist, and immense black boots.

"Good morning!" said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.

"What do you mean?" he said. "Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I wish it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?"

"All of them at once," said Bilbo. "And a very fine morning for a pipe of tobacco out of doors, into the bargain." Then Bilbo sat down on a seat by his door, crossed his legs, and blew out a beautiful grey ring of smoke that sailed up into the air without breaking and floated away over The Hill.
summary: One sunny morning, Bilbo Baggins met a peculiar old man with a tall blue hat, a long grey cloak, and a very long white beard. Bilbo offered a simple, cheerful "Good morning," but the old man, who was Gandalf, surprisingly questioned the exact meaning of his greeting, asking if it was a wish, a statement about the day, or how Bilbo felt. Unfazed, Bilbo calmly explained it meant all of those things. He then comfortably settled down by his door to enjoy a pipe, blowing a perfect, floating smoke ring.

quote: I can put it no plainer than by saying that Bilbo was meant to find the Ring, and not by its maker. In which case you also were meant to have it. And that may be an encouraging thought.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I can put it no plainer than by saying that Bilbo was meant to find the Ring, and not by its maker. In which case you also were meant to have it. And that may be an encouraging thought.
summary: This quote suggests that Bilbo finding the One Ring was not a random accident, but part of a larger, benevolent plan, despite the evil intentions of the Ring's creator. Similarly, the speaker implies that the person they are addressing (Frodo, in the original context) was also destined to receive it. The message is that challenging circumstances or burdens aren't always accidental; they can be part of a greater purpose or design, which can be a source of comfort and encouragement.

quote: To him that is pitiless the deeds of pity are ever strange and beyond reckoning.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: To him that is pitiless the deeds of pity are ever strange and beyond reckoning.

To them, such deeds seem utterly strange and illogical because they cannot fathom the motives behind showing compassion. Since they don't possess empathy themselves, the idea of selfless pity is completely baffling and unexplainable.

quote: Don't dip your beard in the foam, Father!" They cried to Thorin. "It is long enough without watering it!

quote: His thought turned to the Ring, but there was no comfort there, only dread and danger. No sooner had he come in sight of Mount Doom, burning far away, than he was aware of a change in his burden. As it drew near the great furnaces where, in the deeps of time, it had been shaped and forged, the Ring's power grew, and it became more fell, untameable except by some mighty will. As Sam stood there, even though the Ring was not on him but hanging by its chain about his neck, he felt himself enlarged, as if he were robed in a huge distorted shadow of himself, a vast and ominous threat halted upon the walls of Mordor. He felt that he had from now on only two choices: to forbear the Ring, though it would torment him; or to claim it, and challenge the Power that sat in its dark hold beyond the valley of shadows. Already the Ring tempted him, gnawing at his will and reason. Wild fantasies arose in his mind; and he saw Samwise the Strong, Hero of the Age, striding with a flaming sword across the darkened land, and armies flocking to his call as he marched to the overthrow of Barad-dur. And then all the clouds rolled away, and the white sun shone, and at his command the vale of Gorgoroth became a garden of flowers and trees and brought forth fruit. He had only to put on the Ring and claim it for his own, and all this could be. In that hour of trial it was his love of his master that helped most to hold him firm; but also deep down in him lived still unconquered his plain hobbit-sense: he knew in the core of his heart that he was not large enough to bear such a burden, even if such visions were not a mere cheat to betray him. The one small garden of a free gardener was all his need and due, not a garden swollen to a realm; his own hands to use, not the hands of others to command. 'And anyway all these notions are only a trick, he said to himself.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: His thought turned to the Ring, but there was no comfort there, only dread and danger. No sooner had he come in sight of Mount Doom, burning far away, than he was aware of a change in his burden. As it drew near the great furnaces where, in the deeps of time, it had been shaped and forged, the Ring's power grew, and it became more fell, untameable except by some mighty will. As Sam stood there, even though the Ring was not on him but hanging by its chain about his neck, he felt himself enlarged, as if he were robed in a huge distorted shadow of himself, a vast and ominous threat halted upon the walls of Mordor. He felt that he had from now on only two choices: to forbear the Ring, though it would torment him; or to claim it, and challenge the Power that sat in its dark hold beyond the valley of shadows. Already the Ring tempted him, gnawing at his will and reason. Wild fantasies arose in his mind; and he saw Samwise the Strong, Hero of the Age, striding with a flaming sword across the darkened land, and armies flocking to his call as he marched to the overthrow of Barad-dur. And then all the clouds rolled away, and the white sun shone, and at his command the vale of Gorgoroth became a garden of flowers and trees and brought forth fruit. He had only to put on the Ring and claim it for his own, and all this could be. In that hour of trial it was his love of his master that helped most to hold him firm; but also deep down in him lived still unconquered his plain hobbit-sense: he knew in the core of his heart that he was not large enough to bear such a burden, even if such visions were not a mere cheat to betray him. The one small garden of a free gardener was all his need and due, not a garden swollen to a realm; his own hands to use, not the hands of others to command. 'And anyway all these notions are only a trick, he said to himself.
summary: As Samwise Gamgee approached Mount Doom, the Ring's power grew incredibly strong, making him feel its dark influence intensely even though he wasn't wearing it. He felt himself transform into a huge, threatening shadow and was tempted by a grand vision: he could become a mighty hero, overthrow evil, and turn the desolate land into a beautiful garden by simply claiming the Ring. Despite this powerful temptation, Sam resisted. His deep love for his master, Frodo, helped him stay firm, and his practical hobbit-sense also told him that these visions were a trick. He knew he wasn't meant to wield such power, preferring his simple life as a gardener to ruling a vast empire.

quote: How do you pick up the threads of an old life? How do you go on, when in your heart, you begin to understand...there is no going back? There are some things that time cannot mend. Some hurts that go too deep, that have taken hold.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: How do you pick up the threads of an old life? How do you go on, when in your heart, you begin to understand...there is no going back? There are some things that time cannot mend. Some hurts that go too deep, that have taken hold.
summary: This quote expresses the profound difficulty of moving on after a life-altering experience, especially when one realizes that the past is irrevocably gone. It questions how a person can possibly rebuild or continue their life when they understand there's no returning to what was before. Ultimately, it conveys that some emotional wounds are so deep and ingrained that even the passage of time, which usually heals, cannot mend them, leaving lasting pain.

quote: evil labours with vast power and perpetual success - in vain: preparing always only the soil for unexpected good to sprout in.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: evil labours with vast power and perpetual success - in vain: preparing always only the soil for unexpected good to sprout in.
summary: Even though evil appears incredibly powerful and constantly achieves its goals, its successes are ultimately meaningless. This is because all of evil's actions, no matter how destructive or dominant they seem, unintentionally prepare the groundwork. They create the necessary conditions, like fertile soil, for unexpected good to eventually emerge and thrive, often in surprising ways. In essence, evil's destructive work ironically sets the stage for positive outcomes.

quote: At first the beauty of the melodies and of the interwoven words in elven-tongues, even though he understood them little, held him in a spell, as soon as as he began to attend to them. quote:
Then out of the blackness in his mind he thought that he heard Dernhelm speaking; yet now the voice seemed strange, recalling some other voice that he had known.

'Begone, foul dwimmerlaik, lord of carrion! Leave the dead in peace!'

A cold voice answered: 'Come not between the Nazgûl and his prey! Or he will slay thee in thy turn. He will bear thee away to the houses of lamentation, beyond all darkness, where thy flesh shall be devoured, and thy shrivelled mind be left naked to the Lidless Eye.'

A sword rang as it was drawn. 'Do what you will; but I will hinder it, if I may.'

'Hinder me? Thou fool. No living man may hinder me!'

Then Merry heard of all sounds in that hour the strangest. It seemed that Dernhelm laughed, and the clear voice was like the ring of steel. 'But no living man am I! You look upon a woman. Éowyn I am, Éomund's daughter. You stand between me and my lord and kin. Begone, if you be not deathless! For living or dark undead, I will smite you, if you touch him.

The Nazgûl threatens Dernhelm with death and torment for interfering. When Dernhelm draws a sword in defiance, the Nazgûl boasts that no living man can hinder it. However, Dernhelm then reveals a shocking truth: "But no living man am I! You look upon a woman. Éowyn I am." Éowyn declares her identity and her fierce determination to protect her lord and kin, vowing to fight the Nazgûl if it touches them, regardless of its power.

quote:
And Iluvatar spoke to Ulmo, and said: 'Seest thou not how here in this little realm in the Deeps of Time Melkor hath made war upon thy province? He hath bethought him of bitter cold immoderate, and yet hath not destroyed the beauty of thy fountains, nor of my clear pools. Behold the snow, and the cunning work of frost! Melkor hath devised heats and fire without restraint, and hath not dried up thy desire nor utterly quelled the music of the sea. Behold rather the height and glory of the clouds, and the ever changing mists; and listen to the fall of rain upon the Earth! And in these clouds thou art drawn nearer to Manwe, thy friend, whom thou lovest.'

Then Ulmo answered: 'Truly, Water is become now fairer than my heart imagined, neither had my secret thought conceived the snowflake, nor in all my music was contained the falling of the rain. I will seek Manwe, that he and I may make melodies for ever to my delight!' And Manwe and Ulmo have from the beginning been allied, and in all things have served most faithfully the purpose of Iluvatar.

Iluvatar points out how the cold led to the beauty of snow and frost, and the heat created glorious clouds, mist, and rain, which also bring Ulmo closer to his friend Manwe, the spirit of air. Ulmo agrees, realizing that water has become far more wonderful than he ever imagined, confessing he had never conceived of snowflakes or the music of falling rain. He then declares his desire to work with Manwe to create beautiful melodies forever, confirming their long-standing partnership in serving Iluvatar's purpose.

quote:
There was a deep silence, only scraped on its surfaces by the faint quiver of empty seed-plumes, and broken grass-blades trembling in small air-movements they could not feel.

'Not a bird!' said Sam mournfully.

'No, no birds,' said Gollum. 'Nice birds!' He licked his teeth. 'No birds here. There are snakeses, wormses, things in the pools. Lots of things, lots of nasty things. No birds,' he ended sadly.

Sam looked at him with distaste.

Sam notices the complete absence of birds and expresses his sadness about it. Gollum confirms there are no birds, hinting that he finds them "nice" to eat, and then lists the unpleasant creatures that *do* live there, like snakes and worms. Sam looks at Gollum with disgust, clearly disturbed by both the grim environment and Gollum's unsettling nature.

quote:
Good Morning! said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.
What do you mean? he said. Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Good Morning! said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.
What do you mean? he said. Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?
summary: This quote shows Bilbo genuinely wishing Gandalf a good morning, reflecting his own cheerful mood and the pleasant weather. However, Gandalf, ever the astute and skeptical observer, doesn't simply accept the greeting at face value. Instead, he challenges Bilbo to clarify his precise meaning, questioning whether it was a polite wish, a statement of fact about the day, an expression of Bilbo's own good mood, or even an instruction to behave well.

quote: For a while the hobbits continued to talk and think of the past journey and of the perils that lay ahead; but such was the virtue of the land of Rivendell that soon all fear and anxiety was lifted from their minds. The future, good or ill, was not forgotten, but ceased to have any power over the present. Health and hope grew strong in them, and they were content with each good day as it came, taking pleasure in every meal, and in every word and song.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For a while the hobbits continued to talk and think of the past journey and of the perils that lay ahead; but such was the virtue of the land of Rivendell that soon all fear and anxiety was lifted from their minds. The future, good or ill, was not forgotten, but ceased to have any power over the present. Health and hope grew strong in them, and they were content with each good day as it came, taking pleasure in every meal, and in every word and song.
summary: Initially, the hobbits were troubled by their past journey and worried about future dangers. However, the special quality of Rivendell soon lifted all their fear and worry. While they didn't forget about the future, its uncertainties no longer had power over their present. Instead, they grew healthier and more hopeful, becoming content with each day and finding joy in simple things like meals, conversations, and music.

quote: Faithful heart may have froward tongue.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Faithful heart may have froward tongue.
summary: This quote means that someone who is truly loyal, sincere, and good-hearted might sometimes speak in a way that seems rude, blunt, or difficult. Even if their words come across as harsh or impolite, their underlying intentions and character are still good and faithful. Their manner of speaking doesn't always reflect the genuine goodness of their heart.

quote:
At that sound the bent shape of the king sprang suddenly erect. Tall and proud he seemed again; and rising in his stirrups he cried in a loud voice, more clear than any there had ever heard a mortal man achieve before:

Arise, arise, Riders of Theoden!
Fell deeds awake: fire and slaughter!
spear shall be shaken, shield be splintered,
a sword-day, a red day, ere the sun rises!
Ride now, ride now! Ride to Gondor!

With that he seized a great horn from Guthlaf his banner-bearer, and he blew such a blast upon it that it burst asunder. And straightway all the horns in the host were lifted up in music, and the blowing of the horns of Rohan in that hour was like a storm upon the plain and a thunder in the mountains.

Ride now, ride now! Ride to Gondor!

Suddenly the king cried to Snowmane and the horse sprang away. Behind him his banner blew in the wind, white horse upon a field of green, but he outpaced it. After him thundered the knights of his house, but he was ever before them. Eomer rode there, the white horsetail on his helm floating in his speed, and the front of the first eored roared like a breaker foaming to the shore, but Theoden could not be overtaken. Fey he seemed, or the battle-fury of his fathers ran like new fire in his veins, and he was borne up on Snowmane like a god of old, even as Orome the Great in the battle of the Valar when the world was young. his golden shield was uncovered, and lo! it shone like an image of the Sun, and the grass flamed into green about the white feet of his steed. For morning came, morning and a wind from the sea; and darkness was removed, and the hosts of Mordor wailed, and terror took them, and they fled, and died, and the hoofs of wrath rode over them. And then all the host of Rohan burst into song, and they sang as they slew, for the joy of battle was on them, and the sound of their singing that was fair and terrible came even to the City.

With an incredibly clear and powerful voice, he rallied his Riders, urging them to ride to Gondor for a fierce battle. He then blew a mighty horn until it burst, and all the other horns of Rohan joined in, creating a storm of sound. Theoden immediately charged into battle on his horse, Snowmane, moving so fast that he outpaced everyone, appearing almost superhuman. As he charged, morning broke, dispelling the darkness. The enemy was struck with terror and fled, while the Riders of Rohan, filled with battle-joy, sang as they rode over them to victory.

quote: They sat beside the stone, and did not speak again; and when the sun went down Morwen sighed and clasped his hand, and was still; and Hurin knew that she died.He looked down at her in the twilight and it seemed to him that the lines of grief and cruel hardship were smoothed away.

summary: As the sun set, Morwen and Hurin sat together by a stone. Morwen quietly passed away, and Hurin knew she had died when she sighed, clasped his hand, and became still. Looking at her in the fading light, he saw that the signs of her grief and the hardships she had endured seemed to have vanished, leaving her face looking peaceful.

quote: İçinizden en az yarısını, arzuladığımın yarısı kadar bile tanımıyorum; ve yarınızdan azını hak ettiğinizin ancak yarısı kadar sevebiliyorum.

As a result of this lack of understanding, they find themselves only able to love less than half of these individuals, and even then, only half as much as those people genuinely deserve.

quote: Frodo heard a sweet singing running in his mind: a song that seemed to come like a pale light behind a grey rain-curtain, and growing stronger to turn the veil all to glass and silver, until at last it was rolled back, and a far green country opened before him under a swift sunrise.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Frodo heard a sweet singing running in his mind: a song that seemed to come like a pale light behind a grey rain-curtain, and growing stronger to turn the veil all to glass and silver, until at last it was rolled back, and a far green country opened before him under a swift sunrise.
summary: Frodo experienced a beautiful song in his mind that started faintly, like a weak light trying to break through a gloomy, obscuring veil. As the song grew stronger, it transformed this barrier into something clear and bright, until finally, the obstruction vanished completely. What was revealed was a vast, beautiful green land appearing suddenly under a bright, hopeful sunrise, symbolizing a moment of profound clarity, peace, and new beginnings.

quote: I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.’ ‘What do you fear, lady?’ he asked. ‘A cage,’ she said. ‘To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.’ ‘What do you fear, lady?’ he asked. ‘A cage,’ she said. ‘To stay behind bars, until use and old age accept them, and all chance of doing great deeds is gone beyond recall or desire.
summary: The lady states that she is strong and fearless, not afraid of physical challenges, pain, or even death. However, when asked, she reveals her true fear: a "cage." This isn't a literal prison, but the idea of being confined and losing her freedom, eventually becoming old and complacent. Her greatest dread is not being able to achieve great things in life and, even worse, losing the desire or ambition to pursue them as time passes.

quote: One dream is better than a thousand realities.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: One dream is better than a thousand realities.
summary: This quote suggests that having one powerful dream or aspiration for the future is more valuable and inspiring than all the things that are already real in your life. It means that the hope and potential of a single, cherished goal can outweigh the vastness of your current circumstances, no matter how many positive or negative experiences you've had. Ultimately, it highlights the immense power of a dream to motivate, provide direction, and offer a sense of purpose that can be superior to simply accepting the present.

quote: For Isildur would not surrender it to Elrond and Círdan who stood by. They counselled him to cast it into the fire of Orodruin night at hand... But Isildur refused this counsel, saying: 'This I will have as weregild for my father's death, and my brother's. Was it not I that dealt the Enemy his death-blow?' And the Ring that he held seemed to him exceedingly fair to look on; and he would not suffer it to be destroyed.

summary: After defeating Sauron, Elrond and Círdan urged Isildur to immediately destroy the One Ring by throwing it into the fires of Mount Doom. However, Isildur refused their counsel. He declared that he would keep the Ring as compensation for the deaths of his father and brother, believing it was his right since he was the one who had struck the decisive blow against the Enemy. Additionally, Isildur found the Ring exceedingly beautiful and could not bring himself to allow its destruction.

quote:
But Arwen went forth from the House, and the light of her eyes was quenched, and it seemed to her people that she had become cold and grey as nightfall in winter that comes without a star. Then she said farewell to Eldarion, and to her daughters, and to all whom she had loved; and she went out from the city of Minas Tirith and passed away to the land of Lórien, and dwelt there alone under the fading trees until winter came. Galadriel had passed away and Celeborn also was gone, and the land was silent.

'There at last when the mallorn-leaves were falling, but spring had not yet come, she laid herself to rest upon Cerin Amroth; and there is her green grave, until the world is changed, and all the days of her life are utterly forgotten by men that come after, and elanor and niphredil bloom no more east of the Sea.

summary: Arwen left her home, looking sorrowful and frail, and said her goodbyes to her son, daughters, and all she loved. She then departed Minas Tirith and went to the land of Lórien, where she lived alone, as Galadriel and Celeborn had already passed away, leaving the land silent. Finally, as winter was ending but spring had not yet come, Arwen lay down to rest on Cerin Amroth. Her green grave remains there, a lasting mark until the world changes and her memory fades completely from history.

quote: They hammered on the outer gate and called, but there was at first no answer; and then to their surprise someone blew a horn, and the lights in the windows went out. quote: Through darkness you have come to your hope, and have now all your desire. Use well the days.

Now that you have reached this fulfilling point, it's important to live each day fully and appreciate what you have.

quote:
I thought Fangorn was dangerous.

'Dangerous!' cried Gandalf. 'And so am I, very dangerous: more dangerous than anything you will ever meet, unless you are brought alive before the seat of the Dark Lord. And Aragorn is dangerous, and Legolas is dangerous. You are beset with dangers, Gimli son of Glóin; for you are dangerous yourself, in your own fashion. Certainly the forest of Fangorn is perilous — not least to those that are too ready with their axes; and Fangorn himself, he is perilous too; yet he is wise and kindly nonetheless.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I thought Fangorn was dangerous.

'Dangerous!' cried Gandalf. 'And so am I, very dangerous: more dangerous than anything you will ever meet, unless you are brought alive before the seat of the Dark Lord. And Aragorn is dangerous, and Legolas is dangerous. You are beset with dangers, Gimli son of Glóin; for you are dangerous yourself, in your own fashion. Certainly the forest of Fangorn is perilous — not least to those that are too ready with their axes; and Fangorn himself, he is perilous too; yet he is wise and kindly nonetheless.
summary: Gimli believed the Fangorn forest was dangerous, but Gandalf quickly corrected him, asserting that *he* himself was far more dangerous than Fangorn, surpassing almost anything Gimli would ever face, save for the Dark Lord himself. Gandalf added that Aragorn and Legolas were also dangerous, and even Gimli possessed his own form of peril. While confirming the forest's danger, especially to those quick with axes, and acknowledging Fangorn the Ent's own perilous nature, Gandalf also noted the Ent's wisdom and kindness. Essentially, Gandalf was highlighting that danger surrounded them from many different sources, not just the obvious ones.

quote: but I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend: the city of the Men of Númenor; and I would have her loved for her memory, her ancientry, her beauty, and her present wisdom. Not feared, save as men may fear the dignity of a man, old and wise.
