summary: The speaker clarifies that their affection isn't for the tools of war—neither the sharpness of a sword nor the swiftness of an arrow—nor for the glory of a warrior. Instead, their love is solely for what these things protect: the city of the Men of Númenor. They wish for this city to be cherished for its long memory, its ancient origins, its beauty, and its present wisdom, rather than being feared. The only "fear" it should inspire is the deep respect and dignity one would naturally feel towards a wise and venerable old person.

quote: Don't put a lump of rock under my elbow again!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Don't put a lump of rock under my elbow again!
summary: This quote is a frustrated request for someone to stop doing something that causes discomfort or makes a task difficult. The "lump of rock under the elbow" is a metaphor for an annoying or unhelpful obstacle that hinders comfort or progress. The word "again" highlights that this is a repeated issue, indicating the speaker has experienced this problem before and is now fed up and wants it to stop permanently.

quote: Speak, or I will put a dint in your hat that even a wizard will find hard to deal with!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Speak, or I will put a dint in your hat that even a wizard will find hard to deal with!
summary: This quote is a very forceful and impatient demand for someone to speak immediately. The speaker is threatening to cause serious, permanent damage to the listener's hat – symbolizing a personal injury or disgrace – if they don't comply. The phrase "that even a wizard will find hard to deal with" emphasizes that the threatened damage isn't minor; it's so severe and irreversible that even someone with extraordinary magical powers would struggle to fix it. Essentially, it's an intimidating warning: "Talk now, or face consequences that are practically impossible to undo."

quote: Very fair was her face, and her long hair was like a river of gold. Slender and tall she was in her white robe girt with silver; but strong she seemed and stern as steel, a daughter of kings. quote:
But the helm of her secrecy had fallen from her, and her bright hair, released from its bonds, gleamed with pale gold upon her shoulders. Her eyes grey as the sea were hard and fell, and yet tears were on her cheek. A sword was in her hand, and she raised her shield against the horror of her enemy's eyes.
[…]Still she did not blench: maiden of the Rohirrim, child of kings, slender but as a steel-blade, fair yet terrible. A swift stroke she dealt, skilled and deadly. The outstretched neck she clove asunder, and the hewn head fell like a stone. Backward she sprang as the huge shape crashed to ruin, vast wings outspread, crumpled on the earth; and with its fall the shadow passed away. A light fell about her, and her hair shone in the sunrise.

This brave maiden of the Rohirrim, a child of kings, was slender but strong as steel, fair yet formidable. Without hesitation, she delivered a swift and deadly strike, cleaving the neck of the huge, winged creature she faced. As the monstrous foe crashed to the ground, the oppressive shadow it brought vanished, and a light enveloped her as the sun rose.

quote: The great storm is coming, but the tide has turned.

It suggests that even though a "storm" is on the horizon, the underlying circumstances or the balance of power have changed, potentially making the future outcome different or more hopeful than it might otherwise seem.

quote:

quote: Children are meant to grow up, and not to become Peter Pans. Not to lose innocence and wonder, but to proceed on the appointed journey: that journey upon which it is certainly not better to travel hopefully than to arrive, though we must travel hopefully if we are to arrive.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Children are meant to grow up, and not to become Peter Pans. quote:

'The eagles are coming! The eagles are coming!'

And even as it winged away into forgetfulness it heard voices, and they seemed to be crying in some forgotten world far above:
'The eagles are coming! The eagles are coming!'
For one moment more Pippin's thought hovered. "Bilbo! But no! That came in his tale, long long ago. This is my tale, and it ended now. Good-bye!' And his thought fled far away and his eyes saw no more.
summary: Pippin's thoughts were coming to an end, just as he had anticipated. Surprisingly, his mind felt light and joyful, shedding all doubt, worry, and fear as it faded away. As his thoughts slipped into forgetfulness, he faintly heard distant voices crying, "The eagles are coming!" For a brief moment, he wondered if this was from Bilbo's old stories, but then he realized it was his own story reaching its conclusion. With a final farewell, his thoughts completely left him, and his eyes could no longer see.

quote:
The dragon is withered

His splendour is humbled!

And throne and crown perish
With strength that men trusted
And wealth that they cherish,
Here grass is still growing,
And leaves are yet swinging,
The white water flowing,
And elves are yet singing
Come! Tra-la-la-lally!
Come back to the Valley!

The stars are far brighter
Than gems without measure,
The moon is far whiter
Than silver in treasure:
The fire is more shining
On hearth in the gloaming
Than gold won by mining,
So why go a-roaming?
O! Tra-la-la-lally
Come back to the Valley!

O! Where are you going,
So late in returning?
The river is flowing,
The stars are all burning!
O! Wither so laden,
So sad and so dreary?
Here elf and elf-maiden
Now welcome the weary
With Tra-la-la-lally
Come back to the Valley,
Tra-la-la-lally
Fa-la-la-lally
Fa-la!

quote: For suddenly above him far and faint his song was taken up, and a voice answering called to him. Maedhros it was that sang amid his torment. quote: For the less even as for the greater there is some deed that he may accomplish but once only; and in that deed his heart shall rest.

When they complete this specific, one-time deed, they will find deep peace, fulfillment, and a sense of purpose.

quote: Darkness must pass; a new day will come, and when the sun shines, it will shine out the clearer.

quote:

quote: Of course, it is likely enough, my friends," he said slowly, "likely enough that we are going to our dooms: the last march of the Ents. But if we stayed at home and did nothing, doom would find us anyway, sooner or later.

quote: Frodo raised his head, and then stood up. Despair had not left him, but the weakness had passed. He even smiled grimly, feeling now as clearly as a moment before he had felt the opposite, that what he had to do, he had to do, if he could, and that whether Faramir or Aragorn or Elrond or Galadriel or Gandalf or anyone else knew about it was beside the purpose. He took his staff in one hand and the phial in his other. When he saw that the clear light was already welling through his fingers, he thrust it into his bosom and held it against his heart. quote: Touching your cap to the squire may be damn bad for the squire, but it's damn good for you.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Touching your cap to the squire may be damn bad for the squire, but it's damn good for you.

However, the quote argues that this seemingly submissive act is incredibly good for *you*, the person performing it. It implies that such an action, whether it's about humility, self-discipline, or wisely navigating a social situation, builds your own character and internal strength, regardless of how the other person is affected or whether they even deserve the respect.

quote:
Of the Three Rings that the Elves had preserved unsullied no open word was ever spoken among the Wise, and few even of the Eldar knew where they were bestowed. Yet after the fall of Sauron their power was ever at work, and where they abode there mirth also dwelt and all things were unstained by the griefs of time. Therefore ere the Third Age was ended the Elves perceived that the Ring of Sapphire was with Elrond, in the fair valley of Rivendell, upon whose house the stars of heaven most brightly shone; whereas the Ring of Adamant was in the Land of Lórien where dwelt the Lady Galadriel. A queen she was of the woodland Elves, the wife of Celeborn of Doriath, yet she herself was of the Noldor and remembered the Day before days in Valinor, and she was the mightiest and fairest of all the Elves that remained in Middle-earth. But the Red Ring remained hidden until the end, and none save Elrond and Galadriel and Cirdan knew to whom it had been committed.

Thus it was that in two domains the bliss and beauty of the Elves remained still undiminished while that Age endured: in Imladris; and in Lothlórien, the hidden land between Celebrant and Anduin, where the trees bore flowers of gold and no Orc or evil thing dared ever come. Yet many voices were heard among the Elves foreboding that, if Sauron should come again, then either he would find the Ruling Ring that was lost, or at the best his enemies would discover it and destroy it; but in either chance the powers of the Three must then fail and all things maintained by them must fade, and so the Elves should pass into the twilight and the Dominion of Men begin. And so indeed it has since befallen: the One and the Seven and the Nine are destroyed; and the Three have passed away, and with them the Third Age is ended, and the Tales of the Eldar in Middle-earth draw to then-close.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Of the Three Rings that the Elves had preserved unsullied no open word was ever spoken among the Wise, and few even of the Eldar knew where they were bestowed. Yet after the fall of Sauron their power was ever at work, and where they abode there mirth also dwelt and all things were unstained by the griefs of time. Therefore ere the Third Age was ended the Elves perceived that the Ring of Sapphire was with Elrond, in the fair valley of Rivendell, upon whose house the stars of heaven most brightly shone; whereas the Ring of Adamant was in the Land of Lórien where dwelt the Lady Galadriel. A queen she was of the woodland Elves, the wife of Celeborn of Doriath, yet she herself was of the Noldor and remembered the Day before days in Valinor, and she was the mightiest and fairest of all the Elves that remained in Middle-earth. But the Red Ring remained hidden until the end, and none save Elrond and Galadriel and Cirdan knew to whom it had been committed.

Thus it was that in two domains the bliss and beauty of the Elves remained still undiminished while that Age endured: in Imladris; and in Lothlórien, the hidden land between Celebrant and Anduin, where the trees bore flowers of gold and no Orc or evil thing dared ever come. Yet many voices were heard among the Elves foreboding that, if Sauron should come again, then either he would find the Ruling Ring that was lost, or at the best his enemies would discover it and destroy it; but in either chance the powers of the Three must then fail and all things maintained by them must fade, and so the Elves should pass into the twilight and the Dominion of Men begin. And so indeed it has since befallen: the One and the Seven and the Nine are destroyed; and the Three have passed away, and with them the Third Age is ended, and the Tales of the Eldar in Middle-earth draw to then-close.
summary: The Three Elven Rings were powerful, secretly guarded artifacts that preserved beauty, joy, and peace in Middle-earth, particularly in Elrond's Rivendell and Galadriel's Lothlórien. Elrond held the Ring of Sapphire, Galadriel the Ring of Adamant, while the Red Ring remained hidden. The Elves knew that if Sauron's One Ring was ever found or destroyed, the power of their own rings would fade, leading to their eventual departure from Middle-earth and the beginning of the Age of Men. This prophecy indeed came true: with the destruction of the One Ring, the power of the Three faded, marking the end of the Third Age and the Elves' long history in Middle-earth.

quote: Evil is not able to create anything new, it can only distort and destroy what has been invented or made by the forces of good.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Evil is not able to create anything new, it can only distort and destroy what has been invented or made by the forces of good.
summary: This quote means that evil is not capable of coming up with new ideas or making original things. Instead, its only power is to twist, corrupt, or destroy what has already been created or invented by positive forces or good intentions. Essentially, evil doesn't build; it only damages or dismantles what good has brought into existence.

quote: The Road goes ever on and on Down from the door where it began. Now far ahead the Road has gone, And I must follow, if I can, Pursuing it with eager feet, Until it joins some larger way Where many paths and errands meet. And whither then? I cannot say.

quote:
But I have so little of any of these things! You are wise and powerful. Will you not take the Ring?"

"No!" cried Gandalf, springing to his feet. "With that power I should have power too great and terrible. And over me the Ring would gain a power still greater and more deadly." His eyes flashed and his face was lit as by a fire within. "Do not tempt me! For I do not wish to become like the Dark Lord himself. Yet the way of the Ring to my heart is by pity, pity for weakness and the desire of strength to do good. Do not tempt me! I dare not take it, not even to keep it safe, unused. The wish to wield it would be too great for my strength. I shall have such need of it. Great perils lie before me.

Gandalf insists he cannot even keep the Ring safe and unused, as the temptation to wield it, especially in the face of coming dangers, would be overwhelming and ultimately lead to his downfall.

quote: If there are any to see I at least am revealed to them. I have written Gandalf is here in signs that all can read from Rivendell to the mouths of Anduin.

He emphasizes that he has clearly communicated his arrival or location through signs that anyone can understand, and these messages have spread across a vast area, from Rivendell all the way to the mouths of the Anduin River. Essentially, he wants everyone to know he is here.

quote: La Fantasía es una actividad connatural al hombre. Claro está que ni destruye ni ofende a la Razón. Y tampoco inhibe nuestra búsqueda ni empaña nuestra percepción de las verdades científicas. Al contrario. Cuanto más aguda y más clara sea la razón, más cerca se encontrará de la Fantasía. Si el hombre llegara a hallarse alguna vez en un estado tal que le impidiese o le privase de la voluntad de conocer o percibir la verdad (hechos o evidencias), la Fantasía languidecería hasta que la humanidad sanase.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: La Fantasía es una actividad connatural al hombre. Claro está que ni destruye ni ofende a la Razón. Y tampoco inhibe nuestra búsqueda ni empaña nuestra percepción de las verdades científicas. Al contrario. Cuanto más aguda y más clara sea la razón, más cerca se encontrará de la Fantasía. Si el hombre llegara a hallarse alguna vez en un estado tal que le impidiese o le privase de la voluntad de conocer o percibir la verdad (hechos o evidencias), la Fantasía languidecería hasta que la humanidad sanase.
summary: This quote argues that fantasy is a natural human activity that doesn't harm or contradict reason, nor does it hinder our search for scientific truths. In fact, it suggests the opposite: the clearer and sharper our reason is, the closer we are to fantasy. The text concludes by stating that if humanity ever lost its desire or ability to perceive truth—facts and evidence—fantasy would wither away until our collective will to know the truth was healed.

quote: In all the days of the Third Age, after the fall of Gil-galad, Master Elrond abode in Imladris, and he gathered there many Elves, and other folk of wisdom and power from among all the kindreds of Middle-earth, and he preserved through many lives of Men the memory of all that had been fair; and the house of Elrond was a refuge for the weary and the oppressed, and a treasury of good counsel and wise lore. In that house were harboured the Heirs of Isildur, in childhood and old age, because of the kinship of their blood with Elrond himself, and because he knew in his wisdom that one should come of their line to whom a great part was appointed in the last deeds of that Age. And until that time came the shards of Elendil's sword were given into the keeping of Elrond, when the days of the Dúnedain darkened and they became a wandering people.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In all the days of the Third Age, after the fall of Gil-galad, Master Elrond abode in Imladris, and he gathered there many Elves, and other folk of wisdom and power from among all the kindreds of Middle-earth, and he preserved through many lives of Men the memory of all that had been fair; and the house of Elrond was a refuge for the weary and the oppressed, and a treasury of good counsel and wise lore. In that house were harboured the Heirs of Isildur, in childhood and old age, because of the kinship of their blood with Elrond himself, and because he knew in his wisdom that one should come of their line to whom a great part was appointed in the last deeds of that Age. And until that time came the shards of Elendil's sword were given into the keeping of Elrond, when the days of the Dúnedain darkened and they became a wandering people.
summary: For a very long time after a major historical event, Master Elrond made his home in Imladris, also known as Rivendell. He gathered many wise Elves and other knowledgeable and powerful people there, making it a place where the memory of good things was preserved. His house served as a safe haven for those who were tired or struggling, and it was a trusted source of good advice and ancient wisdom. Elrond also secretly protected the descendants of Isildur (the royal line that would eventually include Aragorn) because they were related to him and he knew one of them was destined for a great role. Until that time came, he also kept the broken pieces of Elendil's sword (Narsil), entrusted to him when Isildur's people, the Dúnedain, lost their kingdom and became wanderers.

quote:
But this is terrible!’ cried Frodo. ‘Far worse than the worst that I imagined from your hints and warnings. O Gandalf, best of friends, what am I to do? For now I am really afraid. What am I to do? What a pity that Bilbo did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!’
‘Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his ownership of the Ring so. With Pity.’
‘I am sorry,’ said Frodo. ‘But I am frightened; and I do not feel any pity for Gollum.’
‘You have not seen him,’ Gandalf broke in.
‘No, and I don’t want to,’ said Frodo. I can’t understand you. Do you mean to say that you, and the Elves, have let him live on after all those horrible deeds? Now at any rate he is as bad as an Orc, and just an enemy. He deserves death.’
‘Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.

O Gandalf, best of friends, what am I to do? For now I am really afraid. What am I to do? What a pity that Bilbo did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!’
‘Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his ownership of the Ring so. With Pity.’
‘I am sorry,’ said Frodo. ‘But I am frightened; and I do not feel any pity for Gollum.’
‘You have not seen him,’ Gandalf broke in.
‘No, and I don’t want to,’ said Frodo. I can’t understand you. Do you mean to say that you, and the Elves, have let him live on after all those horrible deeds? Now at any rate he is as bad as an Orc, and just an enemy. He deserves death.’
‘Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
summary: Frodo is extremely frightened and upset, wishing Bilbo had killed Gollum instead of letting him live, as he believes Gollum is evil and deserves death. Gandalf explains that Bilbo showed "Pity" and "Mercy" by not killing Gollum when it wasn't necessary, and this act of compassion actually protected Bilbo from the Ring's corrupting influence. Frodo, still scared, admits he feels no pity for Gollum. Gandalf then delivers a crucial piece of wisdom, cautioning Frodo not to be too quick to judge who deserves to die, because even the wisest people cannot foresee all the future consequences of such decisions.

quote: I know I don't look old, but I'm beginning to feel it in my heart... I need a holiday. A very long holiday. And I don't expect I shall return.

quote:
What a pity Bilbo did not stab the vile creature, when he had a chance!

Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need.

I do not feel any pity for Gollum. He deserves death. Deserves death! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some die that deserve life. Can you give that to them? Then be not too eager to deal out death in the name of justice, fearing for your own safety. Even the wise cannot see all ends.

While the first speaker still insists Gollum deserves to die, a wiser perspective warns against being too eager to deal out death, even in the name of justice or self-preservation. This is because we cannot bring back those who die but deserved to live, nor can we fully understand the future consequences of our actions, as even the wisest cannot see all possible outcomes.

Though here at journey's end I lie
in darkness buried deep,
beyond all towers strong and high,
beyond all mountains steep,
above all shadows rides the Sun
and Stars for ever dwell:
I will not say the Day is done,
nor bid the Stars farewell.

quote: [T]here were two musics progressing at one time before the seat of Ilúvatar, and they were utterly at variance. The one was deep and wide and beautiful, but slow and blended with an immeasurable sorrow, from which its beauty chiefly came. The other had now achieved a unity of its own; but it was loud, and vain, and endlessly repeated; and it had little harmony, but rather a clamorous unison as of many trumpets braying upon a few notes. And it essayed to drown the other music by the violence of its voice, but it seemed that its most triumphant notes were taken by the other and woven into its own solemn pattern.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: [T]here were two musics progressing at one time before the seat of Ilúvatar, and they were utterly at variance. The one was deep and wide and beautiful, but slow and blended with an immeasurable sorrow, from which its beauty chiefly came. The other had now achieved a unity of its own; but it was loud, and vain, and endlessly repeated; and it had little harmony, but rather a clamorous unison as of many trumpets braying upon a few notes. And it essayed to drown the other music by the violence of its voice, but it seemed that its most triumphant notes were taken by the other and woven into its own solemn pattern.
summary: Before Ilúvatar, two very different kinds of music were playing simultaneously. One was deeply beautiful and expansive, though its beauty was intertwined with a profound sorrow. The other music was loud, boastful, and repetitive, lacking true harmony and sounding more like many trumpets blaring the same few notes. This second music tried to silence the first with its overwhelming volume. However, the more beautiful music absorbed even the loudest and most triumphant sounds of the noisy one, incorporating them into its own grand and solemn composition.

quote: What would you here, unhappy mortal, and for what cause have you left your own land to enter this, which is forbidden to such as you? Neither rock, nor steel, nor the fires of Morgoth, nor all the powers of the Elf-kingdoms, shall keep from me the treasure that I desire. For Luthien your daughter is the fairest of all the Children of the World." Then silence fell upon the hall...

quote:
Slowly the lights of the torches in front of Merry flicked and went out, and he was walking in a darkness; and he thought: ‘This is a tunnel leading to a tomb; there we shall stay forever.’ But suddenly into his dream there fell a living voice.
‘Well, Merry! Thank goodness I have found you!’
He looked up and the mist before his eyes cleared a little. There was Pippin! They were face to face in a narrow lane, but for themselves it was empty. He rubbed his eyes.
‘Where is the king?’ He said. ‘And Eowyn?’ Then he stumbled and sat down on a doorstep and began to weep again.
‘They must have gone up into the Citadel,’ said Pippin. ‘I think you must have fallen asleep on your feet and taken the wrong turning. When we found out you were not with them, Gandalf sent me to look for you. Poor old Merry! How glad I am to see you again! But you are worn out, and I won’t bother you with any talk. But tell me, are you hurt, or wounded?’
‘No,’ said Merry. ‘Well, no, I don’t think so. But I can’t use my right arm, Pippin, not since I stabbed him. And my sword burned away like a piece of wood.’
Pippin’s face was anxious. ‘Well, you had better come with me as quick as you can,’ he said. ‘I wish I could carry you. You aren’t fit to walk any further. They shouldn’t have let you walk at all; but you must forgive them. So many dreadful things have happened in the City, Merry, that one poor hobbit coming in from battle is easily overlooked.’
‘It’s not always a misfortune being overlooked,’ said Merry. ‘I was overlooked just now by—no, no, I can’t speak of it. Help me, Pippin! It’s all going dark again, and my arm is so cold.’
‘Lean on me, Merry lad! said Pippin. ‘Come now. Foot by foot. It’s not far.’
‘Are you going to bury me?’ said Merry.
‘No, indeed!’ said Pippin, trying to sound cheerful, though his heart was wrung with fear and pity. ‘No, we are going to the Houses of Healing.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Slowly the lights of the torches in front of Merry flicked and went out, and he was walking in a darkness; and he thought: ‘This is a tunnel leading to a tomb; there we shall stay forever.’ But suddenly into his dream there fell a living voice.
‘Well, Merry! Thank goodness I have found you!’
He looked up and the mist before his eyes cleared a little. There was Pippin! They were face to face in a narrow lane, but for themselves it was empty. He rubbed his eyes.
‘Where is the king?’ He said. ‘And Eowyn?’ Then he stumbled and sat down on a doorstep and began to weep again.
‘They must have gone up into the Citadel,’ said Pippin. ‘I think you must have fallen asleep on your feet and taken the wrong turning. When we found out you were not with them, Gandalf sent me to look for you. Poor old Merry! How glad I am to see you again! But you are worn out, and I won’t bother you with any talk. But tell me, are you hurt, or wounded?’
‘No,’ said Merry. ‘Well, no, I don’t think so. But I can’t use my right arm, Pippin, not since I stabbed him. And my sword burned away like a piece of wood.’
Pippin’s face was anxious. ‘Well, you had better come with me as quick as you can,’ he said. ‘I wish I could carry you. You aren’t fit to walk any further. They shouldn’t have let you walk at all; but you must forgive them. So many dreadful things have happened in the City, Merry, that one poor hobbit coming in from battle is easily overlooked.’
‘It’s not always a misfortune being overlooked,’ said Merry. ‘I was overlooked just now by—no, no, I can’t speak of it. Help me, Pippin! It’s all going dark again, and my arm is so cold.’
‘Lean on me, Merry lad! said Pippin. ‘Come now. Foot by foot. It’s not far.’
‘Are you going to bury me?’ said Merry.
‘No, indeed!’ said Pippin, trying to sound cheerful, though his heart was wrung with fear and pity. ‘No, we are going to the Houses of Healing.
summary: After a terrible battle, Merry was disoriented and felt like he was in a dark, tomb-like tunnel, believing he was about to die. Suddenly, his friend Pippin found him, having been sent by Gandalf to search for him. Merry was confused, asking about the King and Eowyn, and revealed that his right arm was useless after he had stabbed someone, and his sword had vanished. Pippin, seeing Merry's exhaustion and injury, reassured him that they weren't burying him but were taking him to the Houses of Healing for care, gently leading him away and explaining that Merry had simply been overlooked in the post-battle chaos.

quote: the fragrance that came to each was like a memory of dewy mornings of unshadowed sun in some land of which the fair world in Spring is itself but a fleeting memory.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: the fragrance that came to each was like a memory of dewy mornings of unshadowed sun in some land of which the fair world in Spring is itself but a fleeting memory.
summary: The fragrance reminded everyone of perfect, fresh mornings bathed in pure sunlight. This wasn't a memory from our current world, though; it was a fleeting glimpse of an ideal, pristine land so wonderfully beautiful that even the most glorious spring day we experience is merely a faint, temporary echo of its true splendor.

quote: Art is the human process that produces by the way (it is not its only or ultimate object) Secondary Belief.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Art is the human process that produces by the way (it is not its only or ultimate object) Secondary Belief.
summary: This quote suggests that art, as a human activity, has a unique effect: it creates "Secondary Beliefs." These aren't necessarily core truths, but rather new ways of understanding, feeling, or seeing things that emerge from engaging with the art. Crucially, the quote emphasizes that producing these beliefs isn't the primary or ultimate goal of art; instead, it's something that happens incidentally, as a kind of byproduct or side effect of the artistic process.

quote: some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
summary: This quote warns against being too quick to condemn someone to death. It suggests that some people who are sentenced to die might actually have deserved to live, and since you cannot bring them back once they are gone, any mistake in judgment is permanent and irreversible. Therefore, the quote advises extreme caution and humility when making such a serious decision, reminding us that even the wisest people cannot foresee all the future consequences or fully understand every aspect of a situation. Essentially, it urges us to be very hesitant to end a life through judgment because human understanding is limited and a wrongful death cannot be undone.

quote:
Fantasy can, of course, be carried to excess. It can be ill done. It can be put to evil uses. It may even delude the minds out of which it came. But of what human thing in this fallen world is that not true?

Men have conceived not only of elves, but they have imagined gods, and worshiped them, even worshiped those most deformed by their authors own evil. But they have made false gods out of other materials: their nations, their banners, their monies; even their sciences and their social and economic theories have demanded human sacrifice.

Fantasy remains a human right: we make in our measure and in our derivative mode, because we are made: and not only made, but made in the image and likeness of a Maker.

Men have conceived not only of elves, but they have imagined gods, and worshiped them, even worshiped those most deformed by their authors own evil. summary: The quote acknowledges that fantasy can sometimes be misused, poorly done, or even lead people astray. It emphasizes that people have created "false gods" not just from mythical beings, but also from things like nations, money, or even scientific theories, which have often demanded terrible sacrifices. Ultimately, the author argues that fantasy remains a fundamental human right, a natural act of creation that stems from being made in the image of a Creator.

quote: But if I had spoken sooner, it would not have lessened your desire, or made it easier to resist. On the contrary! No, the burned hand teaches best. After that advice about fire goes to the heart.

Instead, the most effective way for people to learn is through direct, often painful, experience. It's only after someone has gone through a difficult situation themselves, like burning their hand, that they truly understand and deeply internalize the advice they were given about it.

quote: A ruler who discerning justice refuseth to it the sanction of law, demanding abnegation of rights and self-sacrifice, will not drive his subjects to these virtues, virtuous only if free, but by unnaturally making justice unlawful, will drive them rather to rebellion against all law.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: A ruler who discerning justice refuseth to it the sanction of law, demanding abnegation of rights and self-sacrifice, will not drive his subjects to these virtues, virtuous only if free, but by unnaturally making justice unlawful, will drive them rather to rebellion against all law.
summary: This quote explains that a ruler who recognizes what is right and fair, but refuses to make it law and instead demands that people give up their rights and sacrifice themselves, will not make his subjects truly good or virtuous. True virtue, the quote argues, can only exist when people are free. By making what is inherently just unlawful, such a ruler will not inspire obedience, but will instead push his people to rebel against all laws and authority.

quote:
The morning came, pale and clammy. Frodo woke up first, and found that a tree-root had made a hole in his back, and that his neck was stiff. "Walking for pleasure! Why didn't I drive?" he thought, as he usually did at the beginning of an expedition. "And all my beautiful feather beds are sold to the Sackville-Bagginses! These tree-roots would do them good." He stretched. "Wake up, hobbits!" he cried. "It's a beautiful morning."

"What's beautiful about it?" said Pippin, peering over the edge of his blanket with one eye. "Sam! Get breakfast ready for half-past nine! Have you got the bath-water hot?"

Sam jumped up, looking rather bleary. "No, sir, I haven't, sir!" he said.

Frodo stripped the blankets from Pippin and rolled him over, and then walked off to the edge of the wood.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The morning came, pale and clammy. Frodo woke up first, and found that a tree-root had made a hole in his back, and that his neck was stiff. "Walking for pleasure! Why didn't I drive?" he thought, as he usually did at the beginning of an expedition. "And all my beautiful feather beds are sold to the Sackville-Bagginses! These tree-roots would do them good." He stretched. "Wake up, hobbits!" he cried. "It's a beautiful morning."

"What's beautiful about it?" said Pippin, peering over the edge of his blanket with one eye. "Sam! Get breakfast ready for half-past nine! Have you got the bath-water hot?"

Sam jumped up, looking rather bleary. "No, sir, I haven't, sir!" he said.

Frodo stripped the blankets from Pippin and rolled him over, and then walked off to the edge of the wood.
summary: The hobbits woke up to an uncomfortable, damp morning, with Frodo feeling particularly sore and regretting the journey, wishing he was back in his soft bed. Despite his discomfort, he ironically declared it a "beautiful morning" and urged the others to wake up. Pippin, still half-asleep and grumpy, immediately demanded breakfast and a hot bath. Sam, looking bleary, admitted he hadn't prepared anything yet, leading Frodo to pull Pippin out of bed before heading off himself.

quote: But Olwë answered: ‘We renounce no friendship. But it may be the part of a friend to rebuke a friend’s folly.

quote: One who cannot cast away a treasure at need is in fetters.

Instead, their attachment to that "treasure" acts like chains, restricting their ability to adapt, grow, or move forward. In essence, being unable to release what you hold dear, when necessary, means you are controlled by it rather than being in control of your own life.

summary: Gandalf observes that some deep wounds never fully heal. Frodo agrees, feeling this is true for him. quote:
But this is terrible!" cried Frodo. "Far worse than the worst that I imagined from your hints and warnings. O Gandalf, best of friends, what am I to do? For now I am really afraid. What am I to do? What a pity that Bilbo did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!"

"Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his ownership of the Ring so. With Pity."

"I am sorry," said Frodo. "But I am frightened; and I do not feel any pity for Gollum.

Gandalf believes Bilbo was rewarded for this compassion, allowing him to escape the Ring's evil relatively unharmed. However, Frodo, still consumed by his fear, admits he feels no pity for Gollum himself.

quote: The trees do not like strangers. They watch you. They are usually content merely to watch you, as long as daylight lasts, and don't do much. summary: This quote suggests that trees are like watchful, wary beings who don't welcome strangers. They constantly observe people, and during the day, they usually just watch without much action. However, some particularly unfriendly trees might occasionally try to bother someone by dropping a branch, extending a root, or grabbing with a vine. The speaker implies that the real danger and alarming behavior from the trees begin after dark, though this is based on what they've been told.

summary: This quote is the inscription found on the One Ring from J.R.R. Tolkien's *The Lord of the Rings*. It translates to: "One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them." In simple terms, it means the Ring's entire purpose is to gain ultimate power, gather everyone under its influence, and then permanently control and enslave them, trapping them in a state of darkness and subjugation.

quote: And she answered: ‘All your words are but to say: you are a woman, and your part is in the house. quote:
Hear all ye Elves!’ she cried to those about her. ‘Let none say again that Dwarves are grasping and ungracious! Yet surely, Gimli son of Glóin, you desire something that I could give? Name it, I bid you! You shall not be the only guest without a gift.’
‘There is nothing, Lady Galadriel,’ said Gimli, bowing low and stammering. ‘Nothing, unless it might be – unless it is permitted to ask, nay, to name a single strand of your hair, which surpasses the gold of the earth as the stars surpass the gems of the mine. I do not ask for such a gift. But you commanded me to name my desire.

I do not ask for such a gift. But you commanded me to name my desire.
summary: Lady Galadriel, addressing the Elves, declared that Dwarves are not greedy or ungracious, challenging a common prejudice. She then insisted that Gimli, a Dwarf, name a gift he desired, since all other guests had received one. Though hesitant and deeply respectful, Gimli eventually revealed his wish: a single strand of her hair, which he valued more highly than gold or precious gems. He clarified that he didn't expect such an extraordinary gift, but only named it because she had commanded him to state his desire.

quote: Then Eomer was silent, and looked on his sister, as if pondering anew all the days of their past life together. But Aragorn said: "I saw also what you saw, Eomer. Few other griefs amid the ill chances of this world have more bitterness and shame for a man's heart than to behold the love of a lady so fair and brave that cannot be returned. Sorrow and pity have followed me ever since I left her desperate in Dunharrow and rode to the Paths of the Dead; and no fear upon that way was so present as the fear for what might befall her. And yet, Eomer, I say to you that she loves you more truly than me; for you she loves and knows; but in me she loves only a shadow and a thought: a hope of glory and great deeds, and lands far from the fields of Rohan.

summary: Eomer was silently reflecting on his sister, Eowyn, and their shared past. Aragorn understood his thoughts, explaining that few things cause as much pain and shame as witnessing a brave woman's love go unreturned. He admitted he felt deep sorrow and pity for Eowyn after leaving her, and worried greatly about her safety. However, Aragorn clarified that Eowyn's love for Eomer is more true and genuine because she loves and knows him for who he really is. Her feelings for Aragorn, he explained, are not for him as a person, but rather for an idea – a symbol of glory, great deeds, and a different life far from Rohan.

quote: Not long ago-incredible though it may seem-I heard a clerk of Oxford declare that he 'welcomed' the proximity of mass-production robot factories, and the roar of self-obstructive traffic, because it brought his university into 'contact with real life.' He may have meant that the way men were living and working in the twentieth century was increasing in barbarity at an alarming rate, and that the loud demonstration of this in the streets of Oxford might serve as a warning that it is not possible to preserve for long an oasis of sanity in a desert of unreason by mere fences, without actual offensive action (practical and intellectual). I fear he did not. In any case the expression 'real life' in this context seems to fall short of academic standards. The notion that motor-cars are more 'alive' than, say, centaurs or dragons is curious; that they are more 'real' than, say, horses is pathetically absurd. How real, how startlingly alive is a factory chimney compared with an elm tree: poor obsolete thing, insubstantial dream of an escapist!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Not long ago-incredible though it may seem-I heard a clerk of Oxford declare that he 'welcomed' the proximity of mass-production robot factories, and the roar of self-obstructive traffic, because it brought his university into 'contact with real life.' He may have meant that the way men were living and working in the twentieth century was increasing in barbarity at an alarming rate, and that the loud demonstration of this in the streets of Oxford might serve as a warning that it is not possible to preserve for long an oasis of sanity in a desert of unreason by mere fences, without actual offensive action (practical and intellectual). I fear he did not. In any case the expression 'real life' in this context seems to fall short of academic standards. The notion that motor-cars are more 'alive' than, say, centaurs or dragons is curious; that they are more 'real' than, say, horses is pathetically absurd. How real, how startlingly alive is a factory chimney compared with an elm tree: poor obsolete thing, insubstantial dream of an escapist!
summary: The author describes an Oxford clerk who surprisingly welcomed noisy factories and heavy traffic, believing it brought his university into "contact with real life." However, the author profoundly disagrees with this view. While he considers the possibility that the clerk might have intended it as a warning about society's increasing barbarity, he fears this wasn't the case. The author criticizes the clerk's definition of "real life," finding it absurd to suggest that modern industrial elements like cars and factory chimneys are more "real" or "alive" than natural things like horses or elm trees, or even mythical creatures. He implies that the clerk's embrace of such things as "real life" is a misunderstanding, bordering on intellectual absurdity.

quote:
They also keep a horned cow
as proud as any queen;
But music turns her head like ale,
And makes her wave her tufted tail
and dance upon the green.
...
So the cat on his fiddle played hey-diddle-diddle,
a jig that would wake the dead:
He squeaked and sawed and quickened the tune,
While the landlord shook the Man of the Moon:
'It's after three' he said.

They rolled the Man slowly up the hill
and bundled him into the Moon,
While his horses galloped up in rear,
And the cow came capering like a deer,
and a dish ran up with the spoon.

Now quicker the fiddle went deedle-dum-diddle;
the dog began to roar,
The cow and the horses stood on their heads;
The guests all bounded from their beds
and danced upon the floor.

With a ping and a pong the fiddle-strings broke!
the cow jumped over the Moon,
And the little dog laughed to see such fun,
And the Saturday dish went off at a run
with the silver Sunday spoon.

The round Moon rolled behind the hill,
as the Sun raised up her head.
She hardly believed her fiery eyes;
For though it was day, to her surprise
they all went back to bed!

as proud as any queen;

...

a jig that would wake the dead:

'It's after three' he said.

They rolled the Man slowly up the hill
and bundled him into the Moon,

and a dish ran up with the spoon.

the dog began to roar,

and danced upon the floor.

With a ping and a pong the fiddle-strings broke!
the cow jumped over the Moon,

with the silver Sunday spoon.

The round Moon rolled behind the hill,
as the Sun raised up her head.
She hardly believed her fiery eyes;
For though it was day, to her surprise
they all went back to bed!
summary: This whimsical poem describes the chaotic and magical effects of a cat playing a fiddle. A proud cow, enchanted by the music, begins to dance, and as the cat's tune gets wilder, even the Man of the Moon is ushered off to bed. The music causes more bizarre events, with the cow, horses, and even a dish and spoon joining in the strange antics. The fiddle's fast tempo makes the cow and horses stand on their heads, and guests jump out of bed to dance. Finally, the fiddle strings snap, leading to the cow jumping over the Moon, the dog laughing, and the dish running off with the spoon. In a final twist, as the sun rises, everyone surprisingly goes back to bed.

quote:
But the Elves were not so lightly to be caught. As soon as Sauron set the One Ring upon his finger they were aware of him; and they knew him, and perceived that he would be master of them, and of an that they wrought. Then in anger and fear they took off their rings. But he, finding that he was betrayed and that the Elves were not deceived, was filled with wrath; and he came against them with open war, demanding that all the rings should be delivered to him, since the Elven-smiths could not have attained to their making without his lore and counsel. But the Elves fled from him; and three of their rings they saved, and bore them away, and hid them.

Now these were the Three that had last been made, and they possessed the greatest powers. Narya, Nenya, and Vilya, they were named, the Rings of Fire, and of Water, and of Air, set with ruby and adamant and sapphire; and of all the Elven-rings Sauron most desired to possess them, for those who had them in their keeping could ward off the decays of time and postpone the weariness of the world. But Sauron could not discover them, for they were given into the hands of the Wise, who concealed them and never again used them openly while Sauron kept the Ruling Ring.

Therefore the Three remained unsullied, for they were forged by Celebrimbor alone, and the hand of Sauron had never touched them; yet they also were subject to the One.

But he, finding that he was betrayed and that the Elves were not deceived, was filled with wrath; and he came against them with open war, demanding that all the rings should be delivered to him, since the Elven-smiths could not have attained to their making without his lore and counsel. But the Elves fled from him; and three of their rings they saved, and bore them away, and hid them.

Now these were the Three that had last been made, and they possessed the greatest powers. Narya, Nenya, and Vilya, they were named, the Rings of Fire, and of Water, and of Air, set with ruby and adamant and sapphire; and of all the Elven-rings Sauron most desired to possess them, for those who had them in their keeping could ward off the decays of time and postpone the weariness of the world. But Sauron could not discover them, for they were given into the hands of the Wise, who concealed them and never again used them openly while Sauron kept the Ruling Ring.

Therefore the Three remained unsullied, for they were forged by Celebrimbor alone, and the hand of Sauron had never touched them; yet they also were subject to the One.
summary: When Sauron put on his One Ring, the Elves immediately understood he intended to control them and all their creations. In response, they quickly removed their own Rings of Power. Furious that his plan was discovered, Sauron attacked them, demanding all the rings back, claiming they couldn't have been made without his help. The Elves fled, managing to save and hide three very powerful rings: Narya, Nenya, and Vilya. These rings had the power to prevent decay and slow the world's weariness, making them highly desired by Sauron, but he could never find them as they were hidden by wise individuals and never used openly. Although these three rings remained pure because Sauron never touched them, they were still ultimately under the influence of his One Ring.

quote: Dead men are not friends to living men, and give them no gifts.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Dead men are not friends to living men, and give them no gifts.
summary: This quote means that once someone has died, they can no longer offer any form of friendship, help, or benefit to those who are still alive. Death brings an end to their ability to interact, support, or provide anything, whether it's comfort, advice, or material aid. Essentially, the living must rely on other living people for companionship and assistance, as the deceased are utterly unable to contribute to the world they've left behind.

quote: Every man has something too dear to trust to another.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Every man has something too dear to trust to another.
summary: This quote means that every person, no matter how open they are, keeps at least one thing incredibly private and important to themselves. It's something so deeply personal or vulnerable that they wouldn't feel comfortable sharing it or entrusting it to anyone else, even someone they truly trust. They guard this part of their life because they consider it too precious to risk, highlighting a universal human need for a certain level of personal privacy and protection.

quote: For it is said in old lore, 'The hands of the king are the hands of a healer.' And so the rightful king could ever be known.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For it is said in old lore, 'The hands of the king are the hands of a healer.' And so the rightful king could ever be known.
summary: According to ancient beliefs, a true and rightful king was thought to possess the qualities of a healer. This meant that his leadership wouldn't just be about power, but about bringing well-being, order, and solutions to the problems of his people. His actions would essentially "heal" the kingdom, making things better and restoring harmony. Therefore, a king's ability to positively impact his subjects' lives and mend societal ills was considered the ultimate proof of his legitimate claim to the throne.

quote: But it may be the hard part of a friend to rebuke a friend's folly.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But it may be the hard part of a friend to rebuke a friend's folly.

While it might feel uncomfortable or even risky to point out a friend's errors, sometimes a good friend must do this challenging thing out of genuine care, even though it's the "hard part" of friendship.

quote:

quote: The Lord of the Rings' is of course a fundamentally religious and Catholic work; unconsciously so at first, but consciously in the revision. For the religious element is absorbed into the story and symbolism.

For the religious element is absorbed into the story and symbolism.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien explained that *The Lord of the Rings* is fundamentally a religious and Catholic work, even if he didn't realize it fully at first and only made it consciously so during revisions. Because the religious essence was so deeply ingrained in the story's core and symbolism, he deliberately removed or avoided any explicit mentions of religion, cults, or specific practices within the world of Middle-earth itself. He felt the spiritual element was already absorbed into the very fabric of the narrative and its deeper meanings.

quote: We were born in a dark age out of due time (for use). But there is this comfort: otherwise we should not know, or so much live, what we do love. I imagine the fish out of water is the only fish to have an inkling of water. (Letter #52)
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We were born in a dark age out of due time (for use). But there is this comfort: otherwise we should not know, or so much live, what we do love. I imagine the fish out of water is the only fish to have an inkling of water. (Letter #52)
summary: The author suggests they were born into a difficult and challenging era, a time not ideal for them. Yet, there's a surprising comfort in this hardship: if life were easy, we wouldn't truly know or deeply value the things we cherish. He illustrates this with the image of a fish out of water, explaining that only when we are deprived of something or face difficulty do we truly understand its worth, much like a fish gasping on land truly comprehends the value of water.

quote: If I stayed beside you, love would lead me, not wisdom

quote:
Hullo! said Merry. So that’s what is bothering you? Now, Pippin my lad, don’t forget Gildor’s saying—the one Sam used to quote: Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards, for they are subtle and quick to anger.
But our whole life for months has been one long meddling in the affairs of Wizards, said Pippin. I should like a bit of information as well as danger. I should like a look at that ball.
Go to sleep! said Merry. You’ll get information enough, sooner or later. My dear Pippin, no Took ever beat a Brandybuck for inquisitiveness; but is it this time, I ask you?
All right! What’s the harm in my telling you what I should like: a look at that stone? I know I can’t have it, with old Gandalf sitting on it, like a hen on an egg. But it doesn’t help much to get no more from you than a you-can’t-have-it-so-go-to-sleep!
Well, what else could I say? said Merry. I’m sorry, Pippin, but you really must wait till the morning. I’ll be as curious as you like after breakfast, and I’ll help you in any way I can at wizard-wheedling. But I can’t keep awake any longer. If I yawn any more, I shall split at the ears. Good night!

quote: I am Gandalf, and Gandalf means me!

quote: If fairy-story as a kind is worth reading at all it is worthy to be written for and read by adults. They will, of course, put more in and get more out than children can. Then, as a branch of a genuine art, children may hope to get fairy-stories fit for them to read and yet within their measure; as they may hope to get suitable introductions to poetry, history, and the sciences. Though it may be better for them to read some things, especially fairy-stories, that are beyond their measure rather than short of it. Their books like their clothes should allow for growth, and their books at any rate should encourage it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If fairy-story as a kind is worth reading at all it is worthy to be written for and read by adults. They will, of course, put more in and get more out than children can. Then, as a branch of a genuine art, children may hope to get fairy-stories fit for them to read and yet within their measure; as they may hope to get suitable introductions to poetry, history, and the sciences. Though it may be better for them to read some things, especially fairy-stories, that are beyond their measure rather than short of it. Their books like their clothes should allow for growth, and their books at any rate should encourage it.
summary: This quote argues that fairy stories are a serious and valuable art form, primarily intended for adults who can understand and appreciate them more deeply than children. While children can certainly enjoy these stories, perhaps in simpler forms, it's often better for them to read tales that are slightly beyond their current level. The author suggests that children's books, especially fairy stories, should challenge them and encourage their minds to grow, much like clothes that allow for a child's physical development.

quote: Going on from there was the bravest thing he ever did. The tremendous things that happened afterwards were as nothing compared to it. He fought the real battle in the tunnel alone, before he ever saw the vast danger that lay in wait.

quote:
In western lands beneath the Sun
the flowers may rise in Spring,
the trees may bud, the waters run,
the merry finches sing.
Or there maybe 'tis cloudless night
and swaying beeches bear
the Elven-stars as jewels white
amid their branching hair.

Though here at journey's end I lie
in darkness buried deep,
beyond all towers strong and high,
beyond all mountains steep,
above all shadows rides the Sun
and Stars for ever dwell:
I will not say the Day is done,
nor bid the Stars farewell.

summary: The poem begins by painting a picture of the beautiful, vibrant natural world in the West, where spring brings flowers, budding trees, and singing birds, and even the night is lit by bright stars. However, the speaker then shifts to their own situation, acknowledging that they are at the very end of their life, buried deep in darkness, beyond all earthly limits. Despite this physical end, the speaker declares with conviction that the sun still shines above all shadows and the stars remain forever. Therefore, they refuse to say that their "Day" is truly done or to bid farewell to the eternal light, expressing a powerful hope that their spirit or essence will endure beyond death.

quote: Frodo drew the Ring out of his pocket again and looked at it. It now appeared plain and smooth, without mark or device that he could see. quote: It was an irresistible development of modern illustration (so largely photographic) that borders should be abandoned and the "picture" end only with the paper. This method may be suitable for for photographs; but it is altogether inappropriate for the pictures that illustrate or are inspired by fairy-stories. An enchanted forest requires a margin, even an elaborate border. To print it coterminous with the page, like a "shot" of the Rockies in Picture Post, as if it were indeed a "snap" of fairyland or a "sketch by our artist on the spot", is a folly and an abuse.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It was an irresistible development of modern illustration (so largely photographic) that borders should be abandoned and the "picture" end only with the paper. This method may be suitable for for photographs; but it is altogether inappropriate for the pictures that illustrate or are inspired by fairy-stories. An enchanted forest requires a margin, even an elaborate border. To print it coterminous with the page, like a "shot" of the Rockies in Picture Post, as if it were indeed a "snap" of fairyland or a "sketch by our artist on the spot", is a folly and an abuse.
summary: The author observes a trend in modern illustration, especially those influenced by photography, to abandon borders and have images fill the entire page. While this full-page approach might work for photographs, they argue it's entirely wrong for illustrations of fairy tales. Fairy tale images, like an enchanted forest, need a margin or even a decorative border to frame them. Treating a magical scene as if it were a casual 'snapshot' of reality, like a news photo, is seen as a mistake and an improper way to present such art.

quote:
As a lord was held
for the strength of his body and stoutness of heart.
Much lore he learned, and loved wisdom
but fortune followed him in few desires;
oft wrong and awry what he wrought turned;
what he loved he lost, what he longed for he won not;
and full friendship he found not easily,
nor was lightly loved for his looks were sad.
He was gloom-hearted, and glad seldom
for the sundering sorrow that filled his youth...
(On Turin Turambar - The Children of Hurin)

summary: Tom could understand the trees' deep and often unsettling thoughts, which were filled with a strong hatred for anything that harms or takes over their land, like creatures that chew, break, or burn. The forest was truly ancient, earning its name "Old Forest" because it was a remnant of much larger, forgotten woods. Within it lived incredibly old trees, the ancestors of all others, who aged as slowly as the hills themselves and remembered a time long ago when they, the trees, were the rulers of the land.

quote: The main mark of modern governments is that we do not know who governs, de facto any more than de jure. We see the politician and not his backer; still less the backer of the backer; or, what is most important of all, the banker of the backer.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The main mark of modern governments is that we do not know who governs, de facto any more than de jure. We see the politician and not his backer; still less the backer of the backer; or, what is most important of all, the banker of the backer.
summary: This quote suggests that a key characteristic of modern governments is that we don't truly know who holds power. It's not just that we're unsure who officially governs, but more importantly, we don't know who actually pulls the strings behind the scenes. We only see the visible politicians, but not the people who support or fund them. Even less visible are the people who back those supporters, and most crucially, the financial powers – the "bankers of the backer" – who ultimately control the entire system through their money and influence. In essence, the true rulers are hidden, far removed from public view.

quote:
Do not laugh! But once upon a time (my crest has long since fallen) I had a mind to make a body of more or less connected legend, ranging from the large and cosmogonic, to the level of romantic fairy-story – the larger founded on the lesser in contact with the earth, the lesser drawing splendour from the vast backcloths – which I could dedicate simply to: to England; to my country. It should possess the tone and quality that I desired, somewhat cool and clear, be redolent of our ‘air’ (the clime and soil of the North West, meaning Britain and the hither parts of Europe: not Italy or the Aegean, still less the East), and, while possessing (if I could achieve it) the fair elusive beauty that some call Celtic (though it is rarely found in genuine ancient Celtic things), it should be ‘high’, purged of the gross, and fit for the more adult mind of a land long now steeped in poetry. I would draw some of the great tales in fullness, and leave many only placed in the scheme, and sketched. The cycles should be linked to a majestic whole, and yet leave scope for other minds and hands, wielding paint and music and drama. Absurd.

Of course, such an overweening purpose did not develop all at once. The mere stories were the thing. They arose in my mind as ‘given’ things, and as they came, separately, so too the links grew. An absorbing, though continually interrupted labour (especially since, even apart from the necessities of life, the mind would wing to the other pole and spend itself on the linguistics): yet always I had the sense of recording what was already ‘there’, somewhere: not of ‘inventing’. Of course, I made up and even wrote lots of other things (especially for my children). Some escaped from the grasp of this branching acquisitive theme, being ultimately and radically unrelated: Leaf by Niggle and Farmer Giles, for instance, the only two that have been printed. The Hobbit, which has much more essential life in it, was quite independently conceived: I did not know as I began it that it belonged. But it proved to be the discovery of the completion of the whole, its mode of descent to earth, and merging into ‘history’. As the high Legends of the beginning are supposed to look at things through Elvish minds, so the middle tale of the Hobbit takes a virtually human point of view – and the last tale blends them.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Do not laugh! But once upon a time (my crest has long since fallen) I had a mind to make a body of more or less connected legend, ranging from the large and cosmogonic, to the level of romantic fairy-story – the larger founded on the lesser in contact with the earth, the lesser drawing splendour from the vast backcloths – which I could dedicate simply to: to England; to my country. It should possess the tone and quality that I desired, somewhat cool and clear, be redolent of our ‘air’ (the clime and soil of the North West, meaning Britain and the hither parts of Europe: not Italy or the Aegean, still less the East), and, while possessing (if I could achieve it) the fair elusive beauty that some call Celtic (though it is rarely found in genuine ancient Celtic things), it should be ‘high’, purged of the gross, and fit for the more adult mind of a land long now steeped in poetry. I would draw some of the great tales in fullness, and leave many only placed in the scheme, and sketched. The cycles should be linked to a majestic whole, and yet leave scope for other minds and hands, wielding paint and music and drama. Absurd.

Of course, such an overweening purpose did not develop all at once. The mere stories were the thing. They arose in my mind as ‘given’ things, and as they came, separately, so too the links grew. An absorbing, though continually interrupted labour (especially since, even apart from the necessities of life, the mind would wing to the other pole and spend itself on the linguistics): yet always I had the sense of recording what was already ‘there’, somewhere: not of ‘inventing’. Of course, I made up and even wrote lots of other things (especially for my children). Some escaped from the grasp of this branching acquisitive theme, being ultimately and radically unrelated: Leaf by Niggle and Farmer Giles, for instance, the only two that have been printed. The Hobbit, which has much more essential life in it, was quite independently conceived: I did not know as I began it that it belonged. But it proved to be the discovery of the completion of the whole, its mode of descent to earth, and merging into ‘history’. As the high Legends of the beginning are supposed to look at things through Elvish minds, so the middle tale of the Hobbit takes a virtually human point of view – and the last tale blends them.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien once had an ambitious vision to create a grand body of legends for England, ranging from vast cosmic myths to romantic fairy tales. He wanted these stories to have a cool, clear, and distinctly Northern European feel, refined and suitable for an adult audience, and dedicated to his country. Although he initially thought this grand plan was "absurd," he later felt that the stories emerged naturally, as if he were recording something already existing rather than inventing it. Interestingly, his popular book, *The Hobbit*, though conceived independently, turned out to be the crucial piece that connected his high legends with the more grounded, human world, ultimately bringing his grand mythological vision to completion.

quote: Saruman rose to his feet, and stared at Frodo. There was a strange look in his eyes of mingled wonder and respect and hatred. 'You have grown, Halfling,' he said. 'Yes, you have grown very much. You are wise, and cruel. you have robbed my revenge of sweetness, and now I must go hence in bitterness, in debt to your mercy. I hate it and you! Well, I go and I will trouble you no more. But do not expect me to wish you health and long life. You will have neither. But that is not my doing. I merely foretell.

He declares he will no longer trouble Frodo, but ominously predicts that Frodo will have neither good health nor a long life, claiming he is merely foretelling the future, not causing it.

quote: Struck by lightning! Struck by lightning!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Struck by lightning! Struck by lightning!
summary: The repeated phrase "Struck by lightning!" strongly conveys a feeling of intense shock and disbelief. It could literally mean someone was hit by lightning, expressing their overwhelming surprise and the sudden, powerful nature of such an event. More broadly, it's often used metaphorically to describe any incredibly sudden, powerful, and unexpected experience that leaves a person stunned or profoundly changed, whether it's a sudden realization, an overwhelming emotional moment, or a completely unforeseen stroke of luck or misfortune.

quote: The news today about "Atomic bombs" is so horrifying one is stunned. The utter folly of these lunatic physicists to consent to do such work for war-purposes: calmly plotting the destruction of the world! Such explosives in men's hands, while their moral and intellectual status is declining, is about as useful as giving out firearms to all inmates of a gaol and then saying that you hope "this will ensure peace" . . . Well we're in God's hands. And He does not look kindly on Babel-builders. (letter 102)

quote: In the Wide World the Wood-elves lingered in the twilight of our Sun and Moon, but loved best the stars; and they wandered in the great forests that grew tall in lands that are now lost. However, after humans appeared, they became more reclusive, keeping to the shadows of dawn and dusk. Despite these changes, they remained true elves, known as the "Good People."

quote: Beowulf survives: for a time, for as long as learning keeps any honor in its land. And how long will that be? God ána wát. (Tolkien on the life and relevance of the Beowulf poem)
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Beowulf survives: for a time, for as long as learning keeps any honor in its land. And how long will that be? God ána wát. (Tolkien on the life and relevance of the Beowulf poem)
summary: Tolkien suggests that the ancient poem *Beowulf* will continue to exist and be considered important only for as long as society values and respects learning and knowledge. He then raises a troubling question about how long this appreciation for learning will truly last. His concluding thought, "God alone knows," conveys his deep uncertainty and even pessimism about the future, implying that if learning loses its place of honor, *Beowulf* might eventually fade from relevance.

quote: Therefore he willed that the hearts of Men should seek beyond the world and should find no rest therein; but they should have a virtue to shape their life, amid the powers and chances of the world, beyond the Music of the Ainur, which is as fate to all things else; and of their operation everything should be, in form and deed, completed, and the world fulfilled unto the last and smallest.

quote: Warning? Warning against what?’ said Boromir sharply. ‘Against delay. Against the way that seems easier. Against refusal of the burden that is laid on me. Against – well, if it must be said, against trust in the strength and truth of Men.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Warning? Warning against what?’ said Boromir sharply. ‘Against delay. Against the way that seems easier. Against refusal of the burden that is laid on me. Against – well, if it must be said, against trust in the strength and truth of Men.
summary: Boromir asks for clarification on what he should be warned against. The answer explains that the warning is not about an external threat, but rather a caution against internal failings and misguided trust. It advises against procrastinating or delaying important actions, and against choosing the path that seems easiest instead of the right one. Furthermore, it warns against refusing the difficult responsibilities laid upon oneself. Finally, and significantly, it cautions against placing too much faith in the inherent strength, honesty, or reliability of other people.

quote: In the spring when the wind is in the new leaves the echo of her voice may still be heard by the fall that bear her name.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In the spring when the wind is in the new leaves the echo of her voice may still be heard by the fall that bear her name.
summary: This quote suggests that even after someone is gone, their memory and presence can still be felt, especially in places connected to them. It paints a picture of spring, when new leaves emerge and the wind rustles through them, symbolizing renewal and a subtle reminder. During this time, it's as if a faint echo of her voice, or her spirit, can still be perceived. This feeling is particularly strong near the waterfall that bears her name, implying that her essence is intertwined with that enduring natural landmark, keeping her memory alive.

quote: His house was perfect, whether you liked food, or sleep, or work, or story-telling, or singing, or just sitting and thinking best, or a pleasant mixture of them all.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: His house was perfect, whether you liked food, or sleep, or work, or story-telling, or singing, or just sitting and thinking best, or a pleasant mixture of them all.

Whether someone preferred quiet activities like sleeping or thinking, more social ones like storytelling or singing, productive work, or simply good food, the house was ideal. It was also excellent for those who liked to enjoy a combination of these different pursuits, making it a universally comfortable and accommodating place.

quote: I wrote The Lord of the Rings because I wished ‘to try my hand at a really long story that would hold the attention of readers, amuse them, delight them, and at times maybe excite them or deeply move them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I wrote The Lord of the Rings because I wished ‘to try my hand at a really long story that would hold the attention of readers, amuse them, delight them, and at times maybe excite them or deeply move them.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien explained that he wrote *The Lord of the Rings* primarily because he wanted to challenge himself to create a very long story. His aim was for the book to captivate readers and keep them engaged. Beyond just holding attention, he hoped it would also bring them joy and amusement, and occasionally stir stronger feelings like excitement or deep emotional resonance.

quote: Not all those who wander are lost; The old that is strong does not wither, Deep roots are not reached by the frost. From the ashes a fire shall be woken, A light from the shadows shall spring; Renewed shall be blade that was broken, The crownless again shall be king.

quote: Do not then stumble at the end of the road.

It means that after putting in a lot of hard work and coming a long way, it's crucial not to make a mistake or give up right when success is within reach. Essentially, it's a warning not to ruin all your progress by failing at the final moment.

quote: I shall claim full amends for every fall and stubbed toe, if you do not lead us well.

quote:
to Sam’s final and complete satisfaction and pure joy, a minstrel of Gondor stood forth, and knelt, and begged leave to sing. And behold! he said:

For I will sing to you of Frodo of the Nine Fingers and the Ring of Doom.’

And all the host laughed and wept, and in the midst of their merriment and tears the clear voice of the minstrel rose like silver and gold, and all men were hushed. And he sang to them, now in the elven-tongue, now in the speech of the West, until their hearts, wounded with sweet words, overflowed, and their joy was like swords, and they passed in thought out to regions where pain and delight flow together and tears are the very wine of blessedness.

quote: Gandalf as Ring-Lord would have been far worse than Sauron. He would have remained 'righteous', but self-righteous. Thus while Sauron multiplied evil, he left 'good' clearly distinguishable from it. Gandalf would have made good detestable and seem evil.

summary: This quote argues that if Gandalf had taken the One Ring, he would have been worse than Sauron. Sauron, despite being evil, was openly so, making it clear what was good and what was bad. quote: It is usually assumed that children are the natural or the specially appropriate audience for fairy-stories. In describing a fairy-story which they think adults might possibly read for their own entertainment, reviewers frequently indulge in such waggeries as: "this book is for children from the ages of six to sixty." But I have never yet seen the puff of a new motor-model that began thus: "this toy will amuse infants from seventeen to seventy"; though that to my mind would be much more appropriate. Is there any essential connexion between children and fairy-stories? Is there any call for comment, if an adult reads them for himself? Reads them as tales, that is, not studies them as curios. Adults are allowed to collect and study anything, even old theatre programmes or paper bags.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is usually assumed that children are the natural or the specially appropriate audience for fairy-stories. But I have never yet seen the puff of a new motor-model that began thus: "this toy will amuse infants from seventeen to seventy"; though that to my mind would be much more appropriate.
