quote:
Yes, I see,’ said Frodo. ‘For one thing, I see that you’re behind the times and the news here. Much has happened since you left the South. Your day is over, and all other ruffians’. The Dark Tower has fallen, and there is a King in Gondor. And Isengard has been destroyed, and your precious master is a beggar in the wilderness. I passed him on the road. The King’s messengers will ride up the Greenway now not bullies from Isengard.’

The man stared at him and smiled. ‘A beggar in the wilderness!’ he mocked. ‘Oh, is he indeed? Swagger it, swagger it, my little cock-a-whoop. But that won’t stop us living in this fat little country where you have lazed long enough. And’ - he snapped his fingers in Frodo’s face - ‘King’s messengers! That for them! When I see one, I’ll take notice, perhaps.’

This was too much for Pippin. His thoughts went back to the Field of Cormallen, and here was a squint-eyed rascal calling the Ring-bearer ‘little cock-a-whoop’. He cast back his cloak, flashed out his sword, and the silver and sable of Gondor gleamed on him as he rode forward.

‘I am a messenger of the King,’ he said. ‘You are speaking to the King’s friend, and one of the most renowned in all the lands of the West. You are a ruffian and a fool. Down on your knees in the road and ask pardon, or I will set this troll’s bane in you!
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Yes, I see,’ said Frodo. ‘For one thing, I see that you’re behind the times and the news here. Much has happened since you left the South. Your day is over, and all other ruffians’. The Dark Tower has fallen, and there is a King in Gondor. And Isengard has been destroyed, and your precious master is a beggar in the wilderness. I passed him on the road. The King’s messengers will ride up the Greenway now not bullies from Isengard.’

The man stared at him and smiled. ‘A beggar in the wilderness!’ he mocked. ‘Oh, is he indeed? Swagger it, swagger it, my little cock-a-whoop. But that won’t stop us living in this fat little country where you have lazed long enough. And’ - he snapped his fingers in Frodo’s face - ‘King’s messengers! That for them! When I see one, I’ll take notice, perhaps.’

This was too much for Pippin. His thoughts went back to the Field of Cormallen, and here was a squint-eyed rascal calling the Ring-bearer ‘little cock-a-whoop’. He cast back his cloak, flashed out his sword, and the silver and sable of Gondor gleamed on him as he rode forward.

‘I am a messenger of the King,’ he said. ‘You are speaking to the King’s friend, and one of the most renowned in all the lands of the West. You are a ruffian and a fool. Down on your knees in the road and ask pardon, or I will set this troll’s bane in you!
summary: Frodo confronts a man, informing him that the great evil (the Dark Tower) has fallen, a King now rules Gondor, and the man's powerful master from Isengard is defeated and powerless. Frodo asserts that the time for bullies is over and royal messengers will now be in charge. However, the man scoffs at this news, mockingly dismissing the idea of a King's authority and stating that he and his kind will continue to dominate. This disrespect, especially towards Frodo and the new King, enrages Pippin. He proudly reveals himself as a King's messenger, displaying his uniform and drawing his sword, sternly warning the man to show respect and beg for pardon, or face his wrath.

quote: In describing a fairy story which they think adults might possibly read for their own entertainment, reviewers frequently indulge in such waggeries as: 'this book is for children from the ages of six to sixty'. prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In describing a fairy story which they think adults might possibly read for their own entertainment, reviewers frequently indulge in such waggeries as: 'this book is for children from the ages of six to sixty'. But I have never yet seen the puff of a new motor-model that begun thus: 'this toy will amuse infants from seventeen to seventy'; though that to my mind would be much more appropriate.
summary: The author observes that reviewers often joke that fairy tales are for all ages, from children to adults, acknowledging that adults enjoy them too. However, they never use a similar playful description for new car advertisements, like calling a car a "toy" for adults. The author finds this inconsistent, believing it would be much more fitting to describe new cars as toys that amuse adults, given how adults often act like children when excited about them.

quote: The mind that thought of light, heavy, grey, yellow, still, swift, also conceived of magic that would make heavy things light and able to fly, turn grey lead into yellow gold, and the still rock into swift water. If it could do the one, it could do the other; it inevitably did both. When we can take green from grass, blue from heaven, and red from blood, we have already an enchanter's power-upon one plane; and the desire to wield that power in the world external to our minds awakes. It does not follow that we shall use that power well on any plane. We may put a deadly green upon a man's face and produce a horror; we may make the rare and terrible blue moon to shine; or we may make woods to spring with silver leaves and rams to wear fleeces of gold, and put hot fire into the belly of the cold worm.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The mind that thought of light, heavy, grey, yellow, still, swift, also conceived of magic that would make heavy things light and able to fly, turn grey lead into yellow gold, and the still rock into swift water. If it could do the one, it could do the other; it inevitably did both. When we can take green from grass, blue from heaven, and red from blood, we have already an enchanter's power-upon one plane; and the desire to wield that power in the world external to our minds awakes. It does not follow that we shall use that power well on any plane. We may put a deadly green upon a man's face and produce a horror; we may make the rare and terrible blue moon to shine; or we may make woods to spring with silver leaves and rams to wear fleeces of gold, and put hot fire into the belly of the cold worm.
summary: The quote suggests that the human mind is capable of two things: understanding the world as it is (like things being light or heavy, or having specific colors) and also imagining magical transformations (like making heavy things fly or turning lead into gold). It argues that just by perceiving and naming colors, we already possess a kind of mental, "enchanter's" power. This internal power then sparks a desire within us to apply it to the real world, to change things externally. However, the author cautions that simply having this power doesn't mean we will use it wisely or for good; we might use it to create beauty and wonder, but equally, we could use it to produce something unnatural, terrifying, or even harmful.

quote: At length they came in their journeying to the Pools of Ivrin, and looked with grief on the defilement wrought there by the passage of Glaurung the Dragon; but even as they gazed upon it they saw one going northward in haste, and he was a tall Man, clad in black, and bearing a black sword. quote: Ever Melkor found some ears that would heed him, and some tongues that would enlarge what they had heard; and his lies passed from friend to friend, as secrets of which the knowledge proves the teller wise.

quote:
Deep down here by the dark water lived old
Gollum, a small slimy creature. I don’t know
where he came from, nor who or what he was. He was Gollum — as dark as darkness, except for two big round pale eyes in his thin face. He had a little boat, and he rowed about quite quietly on the lake; for lake it was, wide and deep and deadly cold. He paddled it with large feet dangling over the side, but never a ripple did he make. Not he. He was looking out of his pale lamp-like eyes for blind fish, which he grabbed with his long fingers as quick as thinking. He liked meat too. Goblin he thought good, when he could get it; but he took care they never found him out. He just throttled them from behind, if they ever came down alone anywhere near the edge of the water, while he was prowling about. They very seldom did, for they had a feeling that something unpleasant was lurking down there, down at the very roots of the mountain. They had come on the lake,
when they were tunnelling down long ago, and they found they could go no further; so there their road ended in that direction, and there was no reason to go that way — unless the Great Goblin sent them. Sometimes he took a fancy for fish from the lake, and sometimes neither goblin nor fish came back.

quote: What a pity that Bilbo did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!’ ‘Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike without need. quote: Certainly it reminds me very much of Bilbo in the last years, before he went away. quote: Not even the very wise can see all ends.

No matter how wise someone is, they cannot foresee all the ways things might end up, as there will always be unexpected events or unforeseen circumstances. It highlights the inherent uncertainty of the future and the limits of human foresight.

quote: But handsome is as handsome does, as we say in the Shire; and I daresay we shall all look much the same after lying for days in hedges and ditches.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But handsome is as handsome does, as we say in the Shire; and I daresay we shall all look much the same after lying for days in hedges and ditches.
summary: This quote means that what truly matters is not how handsome or attractive someone looks, but rather their actions and character. The speaker explains this is a common belief where they come from, suggesting that good deeds are more important than appearances. They then add that outward looks will quickly become irrelevant anyway, as everyone will look equally dirty and unkempt after enduring difficult conditions like lying in hedges and ditches. So, in tough situations, a person's conduct and inner qualities are what truly count.

quote: The nights were comfortless and chill, and they did not dare to sing or talk too loud, for the echoes were uncanny, and the silence seemed to dislike being broken—except by the noise of water and the wail of wind and the crack of stone.

This was because any human noise produced strange, unsettling echoes, and the deep silence felt almost alive, as if it didn't want to be broken. The only sounds that seemed natural or acceptable were those made by nature itself: the flowing water, the howling wind, and the cracking of stones.

quote: We who have lived long under the Shadow may surely listen to echoes from a land untroubled by it?

It's essentially asking if those who have endured much pain can find solace or understanding by listening to stories or memories from a world that hasn't known such trouble.

quote: Then Mablung said to his company: ‘Truly, it is by lack of counsel not of courage that Húrin’s kin bring woe to others!

It is difficult to say anything without saying too much: the attempt to say a few words opens a floodgate of excitement, the egoist and the artist at once desires to say how the stuff has grown, what it is like, and what he thinks he means, or is trying to represent by it all."

-JRR Tolkien, 1951
summary: Tolkien explains that when asked for a short overview of his imaginary world, he finds it incredibly difficult to be brief. Trying to give a quick answer just makes him excited and opens a floodgate of things he wants to say. As both an artist and someone proud of his work, he feels a strong urge to explain in detail how his world developed, what it's truly like, and all the deeper meanings or ideas he tried to represent within it.

quote: The world was young, the mountains green, No stain yet on the Moon was seen, No words were laid on stream or stone When Durin woke and walked alone. He named the nameless hills and dells; He drank from yet untasted wells; He stooped and looked in Mirrormere, And saw a crown of stars appear, As gems upon a silver thread, Above the shadow of his head. The world was fair, the mountains tall, In Elder Days before the fall Of mighty kings in Nargothrond And Gondolin, who now beyond The Western Seas have passed away: The world was fair in Durin’s Day. A king he was on carven throne In many-pillared halls of stone With golden roof and silver floor, And runes of power upon the door. The light of sun and star and moon In shining lamps of crystal hewn Undimmed by cloud or shade of night There shone for ever fair and bright. There hammer on the anvil smote, There chisel clove, and graver wrote; There forged was blade, and bound was hilt; The delver mined, the mason built. There beryl, pearl, and opal pale, And metal wrought like fishes’ mail, Buckler and corslet, axe and sword, And shining spears were laid in hoard. Unwearied then were Durin’s folk; Beneath the mountains music woke: The harpers harped, the minstrels sang, And at the gates the trumpets rang. The world is grey, the mountains old, The forge’s fire is ashen-cold; No harp is wrung, no hammer falls: The darkness dwells in Durin’s halls; The shadow lies upon his tomb In Moria, in Khazad-dûm. But still the sunken stars appear In dark and windless Mirrormere; There lies his crown in water deep, Till Durin wakes again from sleep.

But still the sunken stars appear In dark and windless Mirrormere; There lies his crown in water deep, Till Durin wakes again from sleep.
summary: This quote tells the story of Durin, an ancient king who awoke in a young, untouched world. He explored and named the land, eventually founding a glorious underground kingdom called Khazad-dûm (later known as Moria). This was a golden age where his people were industrious, creating beautiful treasures and weapons, and filling their brightly lit halls with music and joy. However, the quote then shifts to the present, where Durin's once-magnificent kingdom is now old, dark, and ruined. Yet, a glimmer of hope remains: a symbolic crown of stars still appears in a deep lake, suggesting that Durin's spirit, or perhaps Durin himself, might one day awaken again.

quote: It had wakened him up wide in a splintered second, and when goblins came to grab him, there was a terrific flash like lightning in the cave, a smell like gunpowder, and several of them fell dead.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It had wakened him up wide in a splintered second, and when goblins came to grab him, there was a terrific flash like lightning in the cave, a smell like gunpowder, and several of them fell dead.
summary: Something woke a person up very suddenly. Just as goblins came to attack him, a huge flash of light, like lightning, filled the cave. Along with the flash, there was a smell like gunpowder, and several of the gobl goblins immediately died.

quote: Of course, it is likely enough, my friends,’ he said slowly, ‘likely enough that we are going to our doom: the last march of the Ents. But if we stayed at home and did nothing, doom would find us anyway, sooner or later. That thought has long been growing in our hearts; and that is why we are marching now. It was not a hasty resolve. Now at least the last march of the Ents may be worth a song. Aye,’ he sighed, ‘we may help the other peoples before we pass away. Still, I should have liked to see the songs come true about the Entwives. I should dearly have liked to see Fimbrethil again. But there, my friends, songs like trees bear fruit only in their own time and their own way: and sometimes they are withered untimely.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Of course, it is likely enough, my friends,’ he said slowly, ‘likely enough that we are going to our doom: the last march of the Ents. But if we stayed at home and did nothing, doom would find us anyway, sooner or later. That thought has long been growing in our hearts; and that is why we are marching now. But there, my friends, songs like trees bear fruit only in their own time and their own way: and sometimes they are withered untimely.
summary: The speaker, an Ent, acknowledges that their current journey, the "last march of the Ents," will likely lead to their destruction. However, he explains that doing nothing would also lead to their doom eventually, a realization that has long been growing in their hearts. Therefore, this decision to march was not made lightly but is a deliberate, long-considered resolve. He hopes that by taking action, their sacrifice will be remembered and "worth a song," and that they might help other peoples before they perish. Despite this grim resolve, he expresses a personal sadness about unfulfilled hopes, particularly his wish to see the Entwives again, understanding that some dreams, like songs or trees bearing fruit, may never come true or are cut short prematurely.

quote: If I understand aright all that I have heard,’ he said, ‘I think that this task is appointed for you, Frodo; and that if you do not find a way, no one will. This is the hour of the Shire-folk, when they arise from their quiet fields to shake the towers and counsels of the Great. Who of all the Wise could have foreseen it? Or, if they are wise, why should they expect to know it, until the hour has struck?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If I understand aright all that I have heard,’ he said, ‘I think that this task is appointed for you, Frodo; and that if you do not find a way, no one will. This is the hour of the Shire-folk, when they arise from their quiet fields to shake the towers and counsels of the Great. Who of all the Wise could have foreseen it? Or, if they are wise, why should they expect to know it, until the hour has struck?
summary: The speaker believes that Frodo has been uniquely chosen for a crucial task, and if he doesn't succeed, no one else will. This marks an unexpected moment in history where the quiet, unassuming people of the Shire are rising from their peaceful lives to challenge powerful figures and established order. The speaker concludes that no one, not even the wisest, could have foreseen such an event, and true wisdom isn't about knowing everything beforehand, but recognizing the significance of events as they unfold.

quote:
I don't keep water in my pockets."

-Frodo Baggins
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I don't keep water in my pockets."

-Frodo Baggins
summary: When Frodo Baggins says, "I don't keep water in my pockets," he's expressing a very practical and sensible approach to life. Just as it's utterly pointless and impossible to try to carry water in pockets because it would simply leak away, he means he doesn't waste his time, energy, or resources on futile, impractical, or impossible endeavors. He focuses on what is realistic, achievable, and makes sense, rather than attempting things that are clearly destined to fail or yield no useful outcome.

quote: I hope you will like the little things I have sent you. You seem to be most interested in Railways just now, so I am sending you mostly things of that sort. I send as much love as ever, in fact more. We have both, the old Polar Bear and I, enjoyed having so many nice letters from you and your pets. If you think we have not read them you are wrong; but if you find that not many of the things you asked for have come, and not perhaps quite as many as sometimes, remember that this Christmas all over the world there are a terrible number of poor and starving people. I (and also my Green Brother) have had to do some collecting of food and clothes, and toys too, for the children whose fathers and mothers and friends cannot give them anything, sometimes not even dinner. I know yours won’t forget you. So, my dears, I hope you will be happy this Christmas and not quarrel, and will have some good games with your Railway all together. Don’t forget old Father Christmas, when you light your tree.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I hope you will like the little things I have sent you. If you think we have not read them you are wrong; but if you find that not many of the things you asked for have come, and not perhaps quite as many as sometimes, remember that this Christmas all over the world there are a terrible number of poor and starving people. I (and also my Green Brother) have had to do some collecting of food and clothes, and toys too, for the children whose fathers and mothers and friends cannot give them anything, sometimes not even dinner. I know yours won’t forget you. So, my dears, I hope you will be happy this Christmas and not quarrel, and will have some good games with your Railway all together. Don’t forget old Father Christmas, when you light your tree.
summary: Father Christmas hopes the children will enjoy their gifts, especially the railway toys, as he knows they love trains. He sends them much love and says he and the Polar Bear enjoyed reading all their letters. He explains that if there are fewer gifts this year, it's because he (and his Green Brother) have been very busy collecting food, clothes, and toys for many poor and starving children around the world who have nothing. He reassures the children that their own families won't forget them. Finally, he wishes them a happy Christmas, hoping they won't quarrel and will have fun playing with their railway, and reminds them to remember Father Christmas when they light their tree.

quote: I suppose we haven’t lost more than two days by my short cut through the Forest! But perhaps the delay will prove useful – it may have put them off our trail.’ The others looked
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I suppose we haven’t lost more than two days by my short cut through the Forest! But perhaps the delay will prove useful – it may have put them off our trail.’ The others looked
summary: Someone realized that their "shortcut" through the forest actually cost them two days instead of saving time. However, they quickly tried to find a silver lining, suggesting that this unexpected delay might actually be useful. They hoped it would confuse anyone who was following them, making it harder for their pursuers to track them down. The others in the group observed their explanation.

quote: Too swiftly by in love do slip our gentle years.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Too swiftly by in love do slip our gentle years.
summary: This quote means that when we are deeply involved in love, our precious years seem to pass by incredibly quickly. These "gentle years"—our comfortable, perhaps youthful, or simply valuable times—slip away so fast that we barely notice them going. It suggests that while love is a wonderful experience, it can make us lose track of how rapidly life is truly moving.

quote: Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky, Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone, Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die, One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie. One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.

summary: This quote explains how different magical rings were distributed: three to the Elves, seven to the Dwarves, and nine to Men. However, there was one ultimate ring made for a powerful evil lord, the Dark Lord, who lives in the dark land of Mordor. This single Ring was designed to control all the other rings and their wearers, bringing them under the Dark Lord's complete power and binding them to his will in the darkness.

quote: No pidas consejo a los Elfos, pues te dirán al mismo tiempo que sí y que no.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: No pidas consejo a los Elfos, pues te dirán al mismo tiempo que sí y que no.
summary: The quote suggests you should avoid asking Elves for advice. This is because their counsel is so ambiguous and complex that it will simultaneously tell you "yes" and "no." Essentially, their wisdom is presented in such a contradictory or indecisive way that it ultimately offers no clear direction or practical help for making a decision.

quote: Good Morning! said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat. What do you mean? he said. Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on? All of them at once, said Bilbo. And a very fine morning for a pipe of tobacco out of doors, into the bargain. If you have a pipe about you, sit down and have a fill of mine! There’s no hurry, we have all the day before us! Then Bilbo sat down on a seat by his door, crossed his legs, and blew out a beautiful grey ring of smoke that sailed up into the air without breaking and floated away over The Hill. Very pretty! said Gandalf. But I have no time to blow smoke-rings this morning. I am looking for someone to share in an adventure that I am arranging, and it’s very difficult to find anyone. I should think so—in these parts! We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner! I can’t think what anybody sees in them, said our Mr. Baggins, and stuck one thumb behind his braces, and blew out another even bigger smoke-ring. Then he took out his morning letters, and began to read, pretending to take no more notice of the old man. He had decided that he was not quite his sort, and wanted him to go away. But the old man did not move. He stood leaning on his stick and gazing at the hobbit without saying anything, till Bilbo got quite uncomfortable and even a little cross. Good morning! he said at last. We don’t want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water. By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.

summary: Bilbo, enjoying a beautiful morning, cheerfully greeted Gandalf. Gandalf, however, questioned what Bilbo truly meant by "Good Morning." Bilbo clarified he meant it was a good morning in every possible way and invited Gandalf to relax and smoke a pipe. Gandalf declined, revealing he was looking for someone to join him on an adventure. Bilbo immediately declared his strong dislike for adventures, calling them bothersome and disruptive. He tried to politely get rid of Gandalf, but when Gandalf remained silent and persistent, Bilbo became uncomfortable and firmly told him they wanted no part in any adventures and wished him to leave.

quote: May you ever appear where you are most needed and least expected!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: May you ever appear where you are most needed and least expected!
summary: This quote is a wish for someone to always show up exactly where their help is most crucial. It emphasizes appearing at times or in places where your presence is truly needed, but perhaps not anticipated. Essentially, it's a blessing to be a helpful surprise, arriving precisely when and where you can make the biggest difference, often when no one saw you coming.

quote: I suppose you will be hanging up your stocking just once more: I hope so for I have still a few little things for you. After this I shall have to say goodbye, more or less: I mean, I shall not forget you. We always keep the old numbers of our old friends, and their letters; and later on we hope to come back when they are grown up and have houses of their own and children.

summary: This quote expresses a bittersweet farewell from someone who is preparing to leave, but not before offering one last special gift or experience. The speaker assures the recipient that even though they are saying goodbye for now, they will never truly forget them, just as one cherishes memories and contact information of old friends. There's also a hope for a future reunion, when the recipient has grown up and established their own life and family.

quote: Nay, though all things must come utterly to an end in time, Gondor shall not perish yet. Not though the walls be taken by a reckless foe that will build a hill of carrion before them. There are still other fastnesses, and secret ways of escape into the mountains. Hope and memory shall live still in some hidden valley where the grass is green.

Even if its walls are breached by a destructive enemy, there are still other strongholds and secret escape routes into the mountains. Most importantly, the spirit of hope and the memory of their legacy will endure, surviving in some hidden, peaceful place.

quote: I have thought of a nice ending for it: and he lived happily ever after to the end of his days.’ Gandalf laughed. ‘I hope he will. Then, shifting his concern, Bilbo asks Gandalf to keep a watchful eye on Frodo, a request Gandalf readily promises to fulfill.

quote: But perhaps you could call her perilous, because she’s so strong in herself. You, you could dash yourself to pieces on her, like a ship

quote:
گیملی گفت : و تردیدی ندارم که آثار سنگی بهتر،قدیمی تر هستند و در دوره نخست بنا ساخته شده اند . وقتی آدم ها کاری را شروع میکنند ، همیشه وضع این طور است : یادر بهار یخبندان میشود و یا در تابستان خشکسالی و آنها در انجام وعده های خود شکست میخورند .

summary: Gimli expresses a pessimistic view of human endeavors, believing that while their projects may begin impressively (like ancient stone works), they often falter due to unforeseen difficulties, resulting in broken promises and ultimately just "lost opportunities." Legolas, however, counters that even if humans fail in their immediate promises, their actions are like seeds. These "seeds" may lie dormant for a long time but will eventually sprout unexpectedly, meaning that human deeds endure and have a lasting impact that outlives the people themselves. Gimli dismisses this as mere missed chances, a concept Legolas suggests elves, with their different perspective, do not fully understand.

quote: ...fear both the heat and the cold of your heart, and strive for patience, if you can.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: ...fear both the heat and the cold of your heart, and strive for patience, if you can.
summary: This quote advises us to be cautious of the powerful, often conflicting emotions within ourselves. The "heat of your heart" represents intense feelings like anger, passion, or impulsiveness that can lead to rash decisions, while the "cold of your heart" signifies a lack of feeling, such as apathy, bitterness, or emotional detachment, which can make us unfeeling or cruel. The quote suggests that both these extremes are dangerous. Instead of letting these strong emotions control us, it encourages us to actively seek and cultivate patience, acknowledging that it's a challenging but valuable quality that helps us find balance and respond thoughtfully to life's situations.

quote: The air seemed heavy, and the making of words, wearisome.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The air seemed heavy, and the making of words, wearisome.
summary: This quote describes a feeling of deep exhaustion and mental fatigue. The person felt weighed down, as if the very air was heavy and oppressive, making everything feel difficult. On top of this general weariness, even simple acts like forming thoughts into words or speaking felt incredibly tiring and burdensome, indicating a profound lack of energy for communication.

quote: I would see the White Tree in flower again in the courts of the kings, and the Silver Crown return, and Minas Tirith in peace: Minas Anor again as of old, full of light, high and fair, beautiful as a queen among other queens: not a mistress of many slaves, nay, not even a kind mistress of willing slaves. War must be, while we defend our lives against a destroyer who would devour all; but I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend: the city of the Men of Númenor; and I would have her loved for her memory, her ancientry, her beauty, and her present wisdom. Not feared, save as men may fear the dignity of a man, old and wise.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I would see the White Tree in flower again in the courts of the kings, and the Silver Crown return, and Minas Tirith in peace: Minas Anor again as of old, full of light, high and fair, beautiful as a queen among other queens: not a mistress of many slaves, nay, not even a kind mistress of willing slaves. War must be, while we defend our lives against a destroyer who would devour all; but I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend: the city of the Men of Númenor; and I would have her loved for her memory, her ancientry, her beauty, and her present wisdom. Not feared, save as men may fear the dignity of a man, old and wise.
summary: The speaker deeply desires to see the great city, Minas Tirith, restored to its former glory, peace, and beauty, full of light and dignity, much like its ancient name Minas Anor. They envision it as a respected queen among cities, not one that rules over others or holds slaves. While acknowledging that war is sometimes necessary to defend against a destructive enemy, the speaker clarifies that they do not love fighting, weapons, or military glory. Their only true love and motivation is to defend the city itself, valuing it for its long history, beauty, and wisdom, and wishing for it to be admired and respected, rather than feared.

quote: Here the hands of the Valar themselves, in ancient wars of the world’s beginning, had wrested the great mountains asunder, and the sides of the rift were sheer as if axe-cloven, and they towered up to heights unguessable.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Here the hands of the Valar themselves, in ancient wars of the world’s beginning, had wrested the great mountains asunder, and the sides of the rift were sheer as if axe-cloven, and they towered up to heights unguessable.

The sides of this chasm were extremely steep, looking as if they had been cleanly split by a giant axe, and they reached unbelievably high into the sky.

quote: ..an equally basic passion of mine ab initio was for myth (not allegory!) and for fairy-story, and above all for heroic legend on the brink of fairy-tale and history, of which there is far too little in the world (accessible to me) for my appetite ...
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: ..an equally basic passion of mine ab initio was for myth (not allegory!) and for fairy-story, and above all for heroic legend on the brink of fairy-tale and history, of which there is far too little in the world (accessible to me) for my appetite ...
summary: The author explains that from a very young age, he has always had a deep love for certain kinds of stories. He especially enjoys myths (but not allegories, which are stories meant to teach a hidden lesson), and also fairy tales. His greatest passion, however, is for heroic legends that sit on the edge of real history and fantastical fairy tales. He feels there are far too few of these specific kinds of stories in the world for his immense appetite, and he wishes more were available to him.

quote: Rally to me! To me!

quote: This is a story of how a Baggins had an adventure, and found himself doing and saying things altogether unexpected. He may have lost the neighbours’ respect, but he gained—well, you will see whether he gained anything in the end.

quote: A thousand years this city has stood, now at the whim of a madman it will fall.

The tragedy is that this downfall isn't due to a mighty conquest or a natural disaster, but rather the arbitrary and irrational decision of a single, unstable leader – a "madman" – whose unpredictable will is enough to bring down centuries of history.

quote: they saw a new World made visible before them, and it was globed amid the Void, and it was sustained therein, but was not of it.

This world was floating in vast, empty space, seemingly held up or sustained without any visible support. Crucially, even though this world existed *within* the emptiness, it was fundamentally different from it, possessing its own unique nature and not being a part of the void itself.

quote: From that the talk turned to the great hoard itself and to the things that Thorin and Balin remembered. But fairest of all was the great white gem, which the dwarves had found beneath the roots of the Mountain, the Heart of the Mountain, the Arkenstone of Thrain.

But the most beautiful item of all was the great white gem, known as the Arkenstone or the Heart of the Mountain, which the dwarves had found deep inside the mountain.

quote: I have come,’ he said. ‘But I do not choose now to do what I came to do. I will not do this deed. The Ring is mine!

Instead, he dramatically announced that he was claiming the Ring for himself, showing he has succumbed to its powerful temptation and chosen personal desire over his original purpose.

quote: Middle-earth is ... not my own invention. It is a modernization or alteration ... of an old word for the inhabited world of Men, the oikoumene: middle because thought of vaguely as set amidst the encircling Seas and (in the northern-imagination) between ice of the North and the fire of the South. O. English middan-geard, mediaeval E. midden-erd, middle-erd. Many reviewers seem to assume that Middle-earth is another planet!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Middle-earth is ... not my own invention. It is a modernization or alteration ... of an old word for the inhabited world of Men, the oikoumene: middle because thought of vaguely as set amidst the encircling Seas and (in the northern-imagination) between ice of the North and the fire of the South. O. English middan-geard, mediaeval E. midden-erd, middle-erd. Many reviewers seem to assume that Middle-earth is another planet!
summary: The author clarifies that "Middle-earth" is not his own invented fantasy world or another planet. Instead, it's a modernized term for an ancient concept: the inhabited world of humans, similar to the Greek word *oikoumene*. It's called "middle" because it was traditionally imagined as being surrounded by seas and positioned between the icy North and the fiery South of our own world. He notes this explanation is necessary because many reviewers wrongly assume Middle-earth is a different planet entirely.

This intense feeling awakened his adventurous 'Took' side, making him suddenly want to leave his comfortable home. He longed to explore huge mountains, listen to the pines and waterfalls, discover hidden caves, and carry a sword instead of just a walking stick.

quote: When my father was a young man, during the years of the First World War and long before there was any inkling of the tales that were to form the narrative of The Hobbit or The Lord of the Rings, he began the writing of a collection of stories that he called The Book of Lost Tales. That was his first work of imaginative literature, and a substantial one, for though it was left unfinished there are fourteen completed tales. It was in The Book of Lost Tales that there first appeared in narrative the Gods, or Valar; Elves and Men as the Children of Ilúvatar (the Creator); Melkor-Morgoth the great Enemy; Balrogs and Orcs; and the lands in which the Tales are set, Valinor ‘land of the Gods’ beyond the western ocean, and the ‘Great Lands’ (afterwards called ‘Middle-earth’, between the seas of east and west).
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: When my father was a young man, during the years of the First World War and long before there was any inkling of the tales that were to form the narrative of The Hobbit or The Lord of the Rings, he began the writing of a collection of stories that he called The Book of Lost Tales. That was his first work of imaginative literature, and a substantial one, for though it was left unfinished there are fourteen completed tales. It was in The Book of Lost Tales that there first appeared in narrative the Gods, or Valar; Elves and Men as the Children of Ilúvatar (the Creator); Melkor-Morgoth the great Enemy; Balrogs and Orcs; and the lands in which the Tales are set, Valinor ‘land of the Gods’ beyond the western ocean, and the ‘Great Lands’ (afterwards called ‘Middle-earth’, between the seas of east and west).
summary: During World War I, long before he conceived of *The Hobbit* or *The Lord of the Rings*, the author's father began writing *The Book of Lost Tales*. This was his first major work of imaginative fiction, and although it was left unfinished, it contains fourteen complete stories. Crucially, this collection introduced many foundational elements of his later mythology, including the Gods (Valar), Elves, Men (as the Children of the Creator), the great enemy Melkor-Morgoth, Balrogs, and Orcs. It also established key locations like Valinor, the land of the Gods, and the 'Great Lands,' which would later be known as Middle-earth.

quote: I dare say you could,' snorted Gimli. ' You are a Wood-elf, anyway, though Elves of any kind are strange folk. Yet you comfort me. Where you go, I will go. This "Master-ring" was designed to control all the other rings, find their wearers, and bring them under the Dark Lord's power, binding them in darkness.

quote: Sorry! I don’t want any adventures, thank you. Not today. Good morning! But please come to tea—any time you like! Why not tomorrow? Come tomorrow! Good

quote: The Elder, you say, are unpunished, and even those who rebelled do not die. Yet that is to them neither reward nor punishment, but the fulfilment of their being. They cannot escape, and are bound to this world, never to leave it so long as it lasts, for its life is theirs. And you are punished for the rebellion of Men, you say, in which you had small part, and so it is that you die. But that was not at first appointed for a punishment. Thus you escape, and leave the world, and are not bound to it, in hope or in weariness. Which of us therefore should envy the others?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Elder, you say, are unpunished, and even those who rebelled do not die. Yet that is to them neither reward nor punishment, but the fulfilment of their being. They cannot escape, and are bound to this world, never to leave it so long as it lasts, for its life is theirs. And you are punished for the rebellion of Men, you say, in which you had small part, and so it is that you die. But that was not at first appointed for a punishment. Thus you escape, and leave the world, and are not bound to it, in hope or in weariness. Which of us therefore should envy the others?
summary: This quote contrasts two groups: the "Elder" who rebelled but don't die and seem unpunished, and "you" (humans) who die as a result of rebellion. The speaker explains that for the Elder, not dying isn't a reward, but their fundamental nature, which means they are forever tied to the world and can never leave it. On the other hand, while human death appears to be a punishment, it was not originally meant that way; instead, it acts as an escape, freeing humans from being bound to the world. The speaker then asks which group truly has the better situation.

quote: I have done some touches to my nonsense fairy language – to its improvement.1 I often long to work at it and don’t let myself ‘cause though I love it so it does seem such a mad hobby!

This is because, despite their affection, they perceive it as an unconventional or "mad" pastime.

quote: You asked for a brief sketch of my stuff that is connected with my imaginary world. It is difficult to say anything without saying too much: the attempt to say a few words opens a floodgate of excitement, the egoist and artist at once desires to say how the stuff has grown, what it is like, and what (he thinks) he means or is trying to represent by it all. I shall inflict some of this on you; but I will append a mere resume of its contents: which is (may be) all that you want or will have use or time for.

I shall inflict some of this on you; but I will append a mere resume of its contents: which is (may be) all that you want or will have use or time for.

While they plan to share some of these detailed thoughts, they will also include a simple, short summary, anticipating that this brief version is likely all the recipient truly needs or has time for.

quote: It’s a dangerous business, Frodo, going out of your door, he used to say. You step into the Road, and if you don't keep your feet, there is no knowing where you might be swept off to.

quote: Dwarves’ tongues run on when speaking of their handiwork, they say.

quote: It is difficult with these evil folk to know when they are in league, and when they are cheating one another.

You can't tell if they are secretly working together as a group on a plan, or if they are simply betraying and deceiving each other for their own individual gain. Their untrustworthy nature makes it impossible to know what they're really up to.

quote: We’ve got – you’ve got some of the light of it in that star-glass that the Lady gave you! Why, to think of it, we’re in the same tale still! It’s going on. Don’t the great tales never end?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We’ve got – you’ve got some of the light of it in that star-glass that the Lady gave you! Why, to think of it, we’re in the same tale still! It’s going on. Don’t the great tales never end?

quote: Keep It Secret. Keep It Safe." - Gandalf.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Keep It Secret. Keep It Safe." - Gandalf.
summary: Gandalf's quote, "Keep It Secret. Keep It Safe," is a powerful instruction about protecting something very important or dangerous. It means that if you possess something valuable or risky, you must first ensure that its existence remains unknown to others, preventing it from being discovered by the wrong people or drawing unwanted attention. At the same time, you must also actively guard and secure it, making sure it is physically protected from any harm, theft, or misuse, even if its presence is eventually discovered. Essentially, it's about both hiding something crucial and ensuring its complete security.

quote: Ti hoćeš da mi daš taj prsten od svoje volje! Na mesto Mračnog Gospodara hoćeš da postaviš jednu gospodaricu. Ali ja neću biti mračna, nego lepa i strašna kao Jutro i Noć. Užasna kao Oluja i Munja, Snažnija od temelja zemlje. Svi će me voleti i očajavati.

quote:
Frodo indeed 'failed' as a hero, as conceived by simple minds: he did not endure to the end; he
gave in, ratted. I do not say 'simple minds' with contempt: they often see with clarity the simple truth and the absolute ideal to which effort must be directed, even if it is unattainable. Their weakness, however, is twofold. They do not perceive the complexity of any given situation in Time, in which an absolute ideal is enmeshed. They tend to forget that strange element in the World that
we call Pity or Mercy, which is also an absolute requirement in moral judgement (since it is present in the Divine nature). In its highest exercise it belongs to God. For finite judges of imperfect knowledge it must lead to the use of two different scales of 'morality'. To ourselves we must present the absolute ideal without compromise, for we do not know our own limits of natural strength
(+grace), and if we do not aim at the highest we shall certainly fall short of the utmost that we could achieve. To others, in any case of which we know enough to make a judgement, we must apply a scale tempered by 'mercy': that is, since we can with good will do this without the bias inevitable in judgements of ourselves, we must estimate the limits of another's strength and weigh this against the force of particular circumstances.
I do not think that Frodo's was a moral failure. At the last moment the pressure of the Ring would reach its maximum – impossible, I should have said, for any one to resist, certainly after long possession, months of increasing torment, and when starved and exhausted. Frodo had done what he could and spent himself completely (as an instrument of Providence) and had produced a situation in which the object of his quest could be achieved. His humility (with which he began) and his sufferings were justly rewarded by the highest honour; and his exercise of patience and mercy towards Gollum gained him Mercy: his failure was redressed.
We are finite creatures with absolute limitations upon the powers of our soul-body structure in either action or endurance. Moral failure can only be asserted, I think, when a man's effort or endurance falls short of his limits, and the blame decreases as that limit is closer approached.
Nonetheless, I think it can be observed in history and experience that some individuals seem to be placed in 'sacrificial' positions: situations or tasks that for perfection of solution demand powers beyond their utmost limits, even beyond all possible limits for an incarnate creature in a physical
world – in which a body may be destroyed, or so maimed that it affects the mind and will.
Judgement upon any such case should then depend on the motives and disposition with which he started out, and should weigh his actions against the utmost possibility of his powers, all along the road to whatever proved the breaking-point.

To others, in any case of which we know enough to make a judgement, we must apply a scale tempered by 'mercy': that is, since we can with good will do this without the bias inevitable in judgements of ourselves, we must estimate the limits of another's strength and weigh this against the force of particular circumstances.
I do not think that Frodo's was a moral failure. At the last moment the pressure of the Ring would reach its maximum – impossible, I should have said, for any one to resist, certainly after long possession, months of increasing torment, and when starved and exhausted. Frodo had done what he could and spent himself completely (as an instrument of Providence) and had produced a situation in which the object of his quest could be achieved. His humility (with which he began) and his sufferings were justly rewarded by the highest honour; and his exercise of patience and mercy towards Gollum gained him Mercy: his failure was redressed.
We are finite creatures with absolute limitations upon the powers of our soul-body structure in either action or endurance. Moral failure can only be asserted, I think, when a man's effort or endurance falls short of his limits, and the blame decreases as that limit is closer approached.
Nonetheless, I think it can be observed in history and experience that some individuals seem to be placed in 'sacrificial' positions: situations or tasks that for perfection of solution demand powers beyond their utmost limits, even beyond all possible limits for an incarnate creature in a physical
world – in which a body may be destroyed, or so maimed that it affects the mind and will.
Judgement upon any such case should then depend on the motives and disposition with which he started out, and should weigh his actions against the utmost possibility of his powers, all along the road to whatever proved the breaking-point.
summary: Many people might see Frodo's inability to destroy the Ring at the very end as a moral failure, believing he simply "gave in." However, the author argues that this perspective is too simplistic, overlooking the complexities of real situations and the crucial role of mercy in our judgments of others. While we should strive for absolute ideals ourselves, we must judge others with compassion, acknowledging their limitations and the extreme pressures they face. Frodo's "failure" was not a moral one; the Ring's power at its peak was overwhelming, impossible for anyone to resist after such a long ordeal. He had pushed himself to his absolute limit, successfully creating the situation where the Ring could be destroyed, and his earlier mercy towards Gollum ultimately saved the quest and earned him grace. Therefore, true moral failure occurs only when someone falls short of their *own* limits; some are placed in tasks so monumental that perfect success is impossible, and they should be judged by their good intentions and how much they endured until their breaking point.

A heartbroken Bilbo kneels, lamenting the sad end to their adventure and stating that no gold could compensate for it, though he's grateful to have shared the dangers. Thorin then praises Bilbo's courage and wisdom, imparting a final piece of wisdom: the world would be happier if people valued simple joys like food, merriment, and songs more than gold treasures. After Thorin's final goodbye, Bilbo retreats alone and weeps bitterly.

quote: There is nothing like looking, if you want to find something (or so Thoron said to the young dwarves).
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is nothing like looking, if you want to find something (or so Thoron said to the young dwarves).
summary: This quote means that if you want to discover or locate something, the most effective and essential thing you can do is to actively search for it. It emphasizes that simply wishing or waiting won't work; you must put in the effort to observe and look around. Essentially, the best way to find what you're looking for is to actually go out and start searching.

quote: Hobbits give presents to other people on their own birthdays. Not very expensive ones, as a rule, and not so lavishly as on this occasion; but it was not a bad system.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Hobbits give presents to other people on their own birthdays. Not very expensive ones, as a rule, and not so lavishly as on this occasion; but it was not a bad system.
summary: The quote describes a unique Hobbit birthday tradition: instead of receiving gifts, Hobbits give presents to other people on their own special day. These gifts are typically simple and not very expensive, but the Hobbits find this system to be a good one.

quote: [But] I fear that in the individual lives of all but a few, the balance is in debit - we do so little that is positive good, even if we negatively avoid what is actively evil.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: [But] I fear that in the individual lives of all but a few, the balance is in debit - we do so little that is positive good, even if we negatively avoid what is actively evil.
summary: The author expresses a concern that, for most people, their lives fall short when it comes to doing good. While individuals might successfully avoid committing actively bad or evil acts, this avoidance alone isn't enough to create a truly positive impact. Instead, the lack of proactive good deeds means their overall contribution to the world, or their personal "score," remains in the negative.

quote: Until the coming of another day of fear, they walked in silence with bowed heads.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Until the coming of another day of fear, they walked in silence with bowed heads.
summary: This quote describes people who are experiencing a temporary lull in their troubles. They are moving quietly and with a sense of sadness or burden, knowing that their current respite is only brief. They anticipate that another day of fear and difficulty will soon arrive, and they are simply enduring the present moment before those struggles return.

quote: [They] liked to have booked filled with things that they already knew, set out fair and square with no contradictions’.

summary: These individuals strongly preferred a world where everything was predictable and aligned with what they already understood. They wanted information to be presented clearly, without any hidden complexities or conflicting ideas. Essentially, they disliked surprises or challenges to their existing beliefs, preferring a consistent and familiar reality.

quote: Mr. Baggins was still officially their expert burglar and investigator. If he liked to risk a light, that was his affair. They would wait in the tunnel for his report.

Because he was the expert, he had the freedom to make his own decisions about how to do his job, even if it meant taking risks like using a light. quote: He remained a learner and explorer, not a warrior;

quote: I serve no man,’ said Aragorn; ‘but the servants of Sauron I pursue into whatever land they may go. There are few among mortal Men who know more of Orcs; and I do not hunt them in this fashion out of choice. The Orcs whom we pursued took captive two of my friends. In such need a man that has no horse will go on foot, and he will not ask for leave to follow the trail. Nor will he count the heads of the enemy save with a sword. I am not weaponless.’ Aragorn threw back his cloak. The elven-sheath glittered as he grasped it, and the bright blade of Andúril shone like a sudden flame as he swept it out. ‘Elendil!’ he cried. ‘I am Aragorn son of Arathorn, and am called Elessar, the Elfstone, Dúnadan, the heir of Isildur Elendil’s son of Gondor. Here is the Sword that was Broken and is forged again! Will you aid me or thwart me? Choose swiftly!’ Gimli and Legolas looked at their companion in amazement, for they had not seen him in this mood before. He seemed to have grown in stature while Éomer had shrunk; and in his living face they caught a brief vision of the power and majesty of the kings of stone. For a moment it seemed to the eyes of Legolas that a white flame flickered on the brows of Aragorn like a shining crown.

quote: These charges were for the most part false; yet those were bitter days, and hate brings forth hate.

However, despite this constant, repeating nature of time, the quote reminds us that everything in the world, without exception, will eventually wear out, decay, and reach its final end.

quote: Ride now, ride now! Ride to Gondor! Suddenly

quote: But as for sermons! They are bad, aren’t they! Most of them from any point of view. The answer to the mystery is prob. not simple; but part of it is that ‘rhetoric’ (of which preaching is a dept.) is an art, which requires (a) some native talent and (b) learning and practice. The instrument used is v. much more complex than a piano, yet most performers are in the position of a man who sits down to a piano and expects to move his audience without any knowledge of the notes at all. The art can be learned (granted some modicum of aptitude) and can then be effective, in a way, when wholly unconnected with sincerity, sanctity etc. But preaching is complicated by the fact that we expect in it not only a performance, but truth and sincerity, and also at least no word, tone, or note that suggests the possession of vices (such as hypocrisy, vanity) or defects (such as folly, ignorance) in the preacher. Good sermons require some art, some virtue, some knowledge. Real sermons require some special grace which does not transcend art but arrives at it by instinct or ‘inspiration’; indeed the Holy Spirit seems sometimes to speak through a human mouth providing art, virtue and insight he does not himself possess: but the occasions are rare. In other times I don’t think an educated person is required to suppress the critical faculty, but it should be kept in order by a constant endeavour to apply the truth (if any), even in cliche form, to oneself exclusively! A difficult exercise. . . . .

The answer to the mystery is prob. not simple; but part of it is that ‘rhetoric’ (of which preaching is a dept.) is an art, which requires (a) some native talent and (b) learning and practice. The instrument used is v. much more complex than a piano, yet most performers are in the position of a man who sits down to a piano and expects to move his audience without any knowledge of the notes at all. The art can be learned (granted some modicum of aptitude) and can then be effective, in a way, when wholly unconnected with sincerity, sanctity etc. But preaching is complicated by the fact that we expect in it not only a performance, but truth and sincerity, and also at least no word, tone, or note that suggests the possession of vices (such as hypocrisy, vanity) or defects (such as folly, ignorance) in the preacher. Good sermons require some art, some virtue, some knowledge. Real sermons require some special grace which does not transcend art but arrives at it by instinct or ‘inspiration’; indeed the Holy Spirit seems sometimes to speak through a human mouth providing art, virtue and insight he does not himself possess: but the occasions are rare. In other times I don’t think an educated person is required to suppress the critical faculty, but it should be kept in order by a constant endeavour to apply the truth (if any), even in cliche form, to oneself exclusively! A difficult exercise. . . . .
summary: The author finds most sermons to be poor because preaching is a difficult art, similar to playing a complex musical instrument, that requires natural talent, study, and practice—skills many preachers lack. Unlike other performances, sermons also come with the expectation of truth and sincerity, and the preacher themselves must appear virtuous, free from flaws like hypocrisy or ignorance. Therefore, truly good sermons need a combination of artistic skill, moral virtue, and knowledge. The author suggests that genuinely inspired sermons, where divine grace seems to speak through the preacher, are extremely rare. Finally, listeners are encouraged to use their critical judgment but also to diligently apply any truths heard to their own lives.

quote:
When evening in the Shire was grey
his footsteps on the hill were heard;
before the dawn he went away
on journey long without a word.

From Wilderland to Western shore,
from northern waste to southern hill,
through dragon-lair and hidden door
and darkling woods he walked at will.

With Dwarf and Hobbit, Elves and Men,
with mortal and immortal folk,
with bird on bough and beast in den,
in their own secret tongues he spoke.

A deadly sword, a healing hand,
a back that bent beneath its load;
a trumpet-voice, a burning brand,
a weary pilgrim on the road.

A lord of wisdom throned he sat,
swift in anger; quick to laugh;
an old man in a battered hat
who leaned upon a thorny staff.

He stood upon the bridge alone
and Fire and Shadow both defied;
his staff was broken on the stone,
in Khazad-dûm his wisdom died.

quote:
That is a fair lord and a great captain of men," said Legolas. "If Gondor has such men still in these days of fading, great must have been its glory in the days of its rising."

"And doubtless the good stone-work is the older and was wrought in the first building," said Gimli. "It is ever so with the things that Men begin: there is a frost in Spring, or a blight in Summer, and they fail of their promise."

"Yet seldom do they fail of their seed," said Legolas. "And that will lie in the dust and rot to spring up again in times and places unlooked-for. The deed of Men will outlast us, Gimli."

"And yet come to naught in the end but might-have-beens, I guess," said the Dwarf.

"To that the Elves know not the answer," said Legolas.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: That is a fair lord and a great captain of men," said Legolas. "If Gondor has such men still in these days of fading, great must have been its glory in the days of its rising."

"And doubtless the good stone-work is the older and was wrought in the first building," said Gimli. "It is ever so with the things that Men begin: there is a frost in Spring, or a blight in Summer, and they fail of their promise."

"Yet seldom do they fail of their seed," said Legolas. "And that will lie in the dust and rot to spring up again in times and places unlooked-for. The deed of Men will outlast us, Gimli."

"And yet come to naught in the end but might-have-beens, I guess," said the Dwarf.

"To that the Elves know not the answer," said Legolas.
summary: This quote features a debate between Legolas and Gimli about the nature and ultimate fate of human endeavors. Legolas is optimistic, suggesting that even if Men's glory fades, their deeds leave a "seed" that can sprout again, implying that human achievements have an enduring quality beyond individual lives. Gimli, however, is more pessimistic, believing that human efforts often fail to live up to their initial promise and eventually come to nothing but what-ifs. Legolas concludes by admitting that even the Elves do not know the final answer to whether human efforts truly endure or ultimately fail.

quote: And what about your companions? What about Legolas and me?’ cried Gimli, unable to contain himself longer. ‘You rascals, you woolly-footed and wool-pated truants! A fine hunt you have led us! Hammer and tongs! I am so torn between rage and joy, that if I do not burst, it will be a marvel!’ ‘You speak for me, Gimli,’ laughed Legolas. ‘Though I would sooner learn how they came by the wine.’ ‘One thing you have not found in your hunting, and that’s brighter wits,’ said Pippin, opening an eye. ‘Here you find us sitting on a field of victory, amid the plunder of armies, and you wonder how we came by a few well-earned comforts!’ ‘Well-earned?’ said Gimli. ‘I cannot believe that!’ The Riders laughed. ‘It cannot be doubted that we witness the meeting of dear friends,’ said Théoden.

Despite Gimli's disbelief, the scene clearly strikes Théoden as a heartwarming reunion of dear friends.

quote: I coined the word 'eucatastrophe': the sudden happy turn in a story which pierces you with a joy that brings tears (which I argued it is the highest function of fairy-stories to produce). And I was there led to the view that it produces its peculiar effect because it is a sudden glimpse of Truth, your whole nature chained in material cause and effect, the chain of death, feels a sudden relief as if a major limb out of joint had suddenly snapped back. It perceives – if the story has literary 'truth' on the second plane (....) – that this is indeed how things really do work in the Great World for which our nature is made. And I concluded by saying that the Resurrection was the greatest 'eucatastrophe' possible in the greatest Fairy Story – and produces that essential emotion: Christian joy which produces tears because it is qualitatively so like sorrow, because it comes from those places where Joy and Sorrow are at one, reconciled, as selfishness and altruism are lost in Love.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I coined the word 'eucatastrophe': the sudden happy turn in a story which pierces you with a joy that brings tears (which I argued it is the highest function of fairy-stories to produce). And I was there led to the view that it produces its peculiar effect because it is a sudden glimpse of Truth, your whole nature chained in material cause and effect, the chain of death, feels a sudden relief as if a major limb out of joint had suddenly snapped back. It perceives – if the story has literary 'truth' on the second plane (....) – that this is indeed how things really do work in the Great World for which our nature is made. And I concluded by saying that the Resurrection was the greatest 'eucatastrophe' possible in the greatest Fairy Story – and produces that essential emotion: Christian joy which produces tears because it is qualitatively so like sorrow, because it comes from those places where Joy and Sorrow are at one, reconciled, as selfishness and altruism are lost in Love.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien coined the term "eucatastrophe" to describe a sudden, happy turning point in a story that brings a profound, tear-inducing joy. He believed this was the highest purpose of fairy tales because it offers a brief glimpse of ultimate Truth. This moment provides a deep sense of relief to our human nature, which often feels bound by the limitations of the material world and death, showing us how things truly work in the greater reality for which we were made. For Tolkien, the greatest eucatastrophe is the Resurrection, which he saw as the ultimate "happy ending" in the greatest story, producing a unique "Christian joy" that brings tears because it reconciles and unites both joy and sorrow.

quote: I once saw a so-called "children's pantomime," the straight story of Puss-in-Boots, with even the metamorphosis of the ogre into a mouse.
