He emphasizes that even if she were completely happy, fearless, and powerful, like a blissful Queen, he would still love her just the same.

quote: فقال جاندالف: إنني معكم في الوقت الحاضر، ولكن قريبا لن أكون معكم. إنني لست ذاهبا إلى المقاطعة. ينبغي عليكم أن تسووا أموركم بأنفسكم، هذا ما تم تدريبكم من أجله. ألم تفهموا بعد؟ لقد انتهى وقتي وزماني. لم تعد بعد مهمتي أن أصحح الأشياء وأقومها، ولا أن أساعد الأشخاص في أن يفعلوا ذلك. وبالنسبة لكم أنتم يا أصدقائي الأعزاء، فلن تحتاجوا إلى أي مساعدة. لقد كبرتم الآن. كبرتم حقا وصرتم طوالا جدا. إنكم بين العظماء، ولم يعد يساورني أي خوف على الإطلاق على أي واحد منكم. ولكن إذا كنتم ستعرفون، فإنني سوف أحيد عن الطريق سريعا. سوف أتبادل حديثا طويلا مع بومباديل. حديث لم يحدث قط أن تبادت مثله طوال حياتي. إنه جامع طحالب، وقد كنت أنا صخرا كتب عليه أن يتدحرج ويدور. ولكن أيام تدحرجي ودوراني تصل إلى نهايتها، والآن سوف يكون لدينا الكثير ليقوله كل منا للآخر.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: فقال جاندالف: إنني معكم في الوقت الحاضر، ولكن قريبا لن أكون معكم. إنني لست ذاهبا إلى المقاطعة. ينبغي عليكم أن تسووا أموركم بأنفسكم، هذا ما تم تدريبكم من أجله. ألم تفهموا بعد؟ لقد انتهى وقتي وزماني. لم تعد بعد مهمتي أن أصحح الأشياء وأقومها، ولا أن أساعد الأشخاص في أن يفعلوا ذلك. وبالنسبة لكم أنتم يا أصدقائي الأعزاء، فلن تحتاجوا إلى أي مساعدة. لقد كبرتم الآن. كبرتم حقا وصرتم طوالا جدا. إنكم بين العظماء، ولم يعد يساورني أي خوف على الإطلاق على أي واحد منكم. ولكن إذا كنتم ستعرفون، فإنني سوف أحيد عن الطريق سريعا. سوف أتبادل حديثا طويلا مع بومباديل. حديث لم يحدث قط أن تبادت مثله طوال حياتي. إنه جامع طحالب، وقد كنت أنا صخرا كتب عليه أن يتدحرج ويدور. ولكن أيام تدحرجي ودوراني تصل إلى نهايتها، والآن سوف يكون لدينا الكثير ليقوله كل منا للآخر.
summary: Gandalf tells his companions that he is leaving them soon and will not be returning to the Shire. He explains that his time for directly fixing things and helping others is over, and they must now handle their own affairs, as they are trained and ready. He assures them that they have matured into great individuals who no longer need his assistance, and he has no fear for their future. He then reveals he will have a long, unprecedented conversation with Bombadil, signaling a deep personal change for him, moving from a life of constant action (a "rolling stone") to a more reflective existence.

quote:
Alive without breath;
as cold as death;
never thirsting, ever drinking;
clad in mail, never clinking.
Drowns on dry land,
thinks an island
is a mountain;
thinks a fountain
is a puff of air.
So sleek, so fair!
What a joy to meet!
We only wish
to catch a fish,
so juicy-sweet!
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Alive without breath;
as cold as death;
never thirsting, ever drinking;
clad in mail, never clinking.
Drowns on dry land,
thinks an island
is a mountain;
thinks a fountain
is a puff of air.
So sleek, so fair!
What a joy to meet!
We only wish
to catch a fish,
so juicy-sweet!
summary: This riddle describes a fish. It lives underwater, so it doesn't need to breathe air and is always surrounded by water. It has a smooth, scaly body and moves silently. A fish cannot survive on dry land. The poem also suggests that a fish has a unique way of seeing the world, perceiving land as large obstacles and water sprays as mere puffs of air. Ultimately, the speaker expresses a desire to catch this sleek, sweet creature for food.

quote: The world is grey, the mountains old, The forge’s fire is ashen-cold; No harp is wrung, no hammer falls: The darkness dwells in Durin’s halls; The shadow lies upon his tomb In Moria, in Khazad-dûm.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world is grey, the mountains old, The forge’s fire is ashen-cold; No harp is wrung, no hammer falls: The darkness dwells in Durin’s halls; The shadow lies upon his tomb In Moria, in Khazad-dûm.
summary: This quote paints a bleak picture of a world that has lost its vibrancy and warmth. It specifically laments the desolate state of the once-mighty Dwarven kingdom of Durin, known as Moria or Khazad-dûm. What was once a bustling place of fire, music, and industrious work is now cold, silent, and utterly abandoned. Only darkness and the shadow of death remain, marking it as a ruin where a great legacy has fallen.

quote: he found himself wondering, since Entish was such an ‘unhasty’ language, whether they had yet got further than Good Morning;
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: he found himself wondering, since Entish was such an ‘unhasty’ language, whether they had yet got further than Good Morning;
summary: The speaker wondered about the incredibly slow nature of Entish, the language spoken by the Ents. Given its 'unhasty' and deliberate pace, he humorously questioned whether they could have possibly progressed beyond just saying 'Good Morning' to one another, implying that any conversation among them would take an extraordinarily long time.

quote:
-Desleal es aquel que se despide cuando el camino se oscurece.
-Quizá, pero no jure que caminará en las tinieblas quien no ha visto la caída de la noche.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: -Desleal es aquel que se despide cuando el camino se oscurece.
-Quizá, pero no jure que caminará en las tinieblas quien no ha visto la caída de la noche.
summary: This quote explores the nature of loyalty during difficult times. The first statement suggests that someone who leaves when circumstances become challenging is disloyal. However, the second part offers a more cautious perspective, implying that while this might be true, one shouldn't promise to endure hardship if they haven't truly experienced real adversity yet. It's easy to talk about staying strong, but the true test only comes when facing actual darkness.

quote: In place of the Dark Lord you will set up a Queen. And I shall not be dark, but beautiful and terrible as the Morning and the Night! Fair as the Sea and the Sun and the Snow upon the Mountain! Dreadful as the Storm and the Lightning! Stronger than the foundations of the earth. All shall love me and despair!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In place of the Dark Lord you will set up a Queen. And I shall not be dark, but beautiful and terrible as the Morning and the Night! Fair as the Sea and the Sun and the Snow upon the Mountain! Dreadful as the Storm and the Lightning! Stronger than the foundations of the earth. All shall love me and despair!
summary: This quote describes a powerful new Queen who will replace an existing "Dark Lord." She claims she won't be evil in the same way, but will be both beautiful and terrifying, embodying the majesty of nature like the sun and sea, yet also the destructive force of a storm. She sees herself as incredibly strong, more powerful than anything on Earth. Her reign will be so absolute and overwhelming that everyone will be forced to admire and adore her, while simultaneously feeling a sense of hopelessness and despair at her unstoppable might.

quote: We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner!
summary: This quote describes a group of ordinary, peaceful people who strongly dislike adventures. They see exciting experiences as unpleasant, disruptive, and uncomfortable. Their biggest concern is that such events might even make them late for dinner, highlighting their preference for a simple, routine-filled life over any kind of excitement or disturbance.

quote: It was in fairy-stories that I first divined the potency of the words, and the wonder of the things, such as stone, and wood, and iron; tree and grass; house and fire; bread and wine.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It was in fairy-stories that I first divined the potency of the words, and the wonder of the things, such as stone, and wood, and iron; tree and grass; house and fire; bread and wine.
summary: This quote means that the author first truly understood the deep power of words and the profound wonder of everyday things, like stone, wood, trees, and even basic necessities such as a house, fire, bread, and wine, by reading fairy stories. In essence, fairy tales taught them to see the magic and significance in both language and the simple, fundamental elements of the world around us.

quote: Even in ancient days they were, as a rule, shy of 'the Big Folk', as they call us, and now they avoid us with dismay and are becoming hard to find.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Even in ancient days they were, as a rule, shy of 'the Big Folk', as they call us, and now they avoid us with dismay and are becoming hard to find.
summary: The quote explains that a certain group of people, who refer to us as 'the Big Folk,' have historically been timid and avoided our presence. This shyness has worsened over time; now, they actively stay away from us with a sense of distress or unhappiness. As a result, they are becoming increasingly rare and difficult to encounter.

quote: Far off there was a great hill of shadow, and out of that shadow, which was its root, he saw the King's Tree springing up, tower upon tower, into the sky, and its light was like the sun at noon; and it bore at once leaves and flowers and fruits uncounted, and not one was the same as any other that grew on The Tree.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Far off there was a great hill of shadow, and out of that shadow, which was its root, he saw the King's Tree springing up, tower upon tower, into the sky, and its light was like the sun at noon; and it bore at once leaves and flowers and fruits uncounted, and not one was the same as any other that grew on The Tree.
summary: The quote describes a magnificent and powerful tree, known as the King's Tree. It is seen growing out of a vast, dark hill, which acts as its base. This tree is incredibly tall, reaching high into the sky, and it shines with a light as bright as the midday sun. What makes it truly remarkable is that it produces countless leaves, flowers, and fruits all at once, and every single one of these items is unique and different from the others growing on the tree.

quote: But I should have said that the story had for the more intelligent reader a great number of philosophical and mythical implications that enormously enhanced without detracting from the surface 'adventure'. I found the blend of vera historia with mythos irresistible.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But I should have said that the story had for the more intelligent reader a great number of philosophical and mythical implications that enormously enhanced without detracting from the surface 'adventure'. I found the blend of vera historia with mythos irresistible.
summary: The speaker is saying that a good story isn't just about the obvious plot or "adventure." For a thoughtful reader, it also has many deeper philosophical and mythical meanings. These deeper layers don't spoil the surface story; instead, they greatly enrich and improve it. The speaker found this combination of a realistic storyline ("vera historia") with profound mythical elements ("mythos") incredibly compelling and enjoyable.

quote: I’ve more need of thoughts than of sleep.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I’ve more need of thoughts than of sleep.
summary: This quote means the speaker feels a much stronger urge or need to engage their mind in thinking, reflecting, or problem-solving than to get physical rest or sleep. They are prioritizing mental activity and the pursuit of ideas over the basic human need for sleep, indicating that their thoughts are currently more vital or compelling to them than a break.

quote: In pigri giardini, molti fiori come te gli dèi innamorati sono soliti baciare d'un bacio che assomiglia al miele; e poi li buttano via, sciupati, e li calpestano, mentre emanano il profumo loro. [...] E chi non vorrebbe gustare la dolcezza del miele sfiorando labbra, o calpestar coi piedi il morbido, fresco tessuto dei pallidi fiori, alleggerendo, come gli dèi, le ore che si trascinano?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In pigri giardini, molti fiori come te gli dèi innamorati sono soliti baciare d'un bacio che assomiglia al miele; e poi li buttano via, sciupati, e li calpestano, mentre emanano il profumo loro. [...] E chi non vorrebbe gustare la dolcezza del miele sfiorando labbra, o calpestar coi piedi il morbido, fresco tessuto dei pallidi fiori, alleggerendo, come gli dèi, le ore che si trascinano?
summary: This quote suggests that beautiful people, like flowers in a relaxed garden, are passionately admired and enjoyed by those who indulge, much like gods sharing a sweet, honey-like kiss. However, once the pleasure is gone, these individuals are carelessly discarded and trampled, even though they still possess their charm. The passage then asks who wouldn't be tempted to experience such fleeting delights—tasting sweetness or crushing delicate beauty—if it helps pass the time, just as the gods do.

quote:
Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.

"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.

"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
summary: In this exchange, a character uses "Good morning!" as a polite but firm way to end a conversation and express that he wants no adventures or trouble, essentially telling the other person to leave and try somewhere else. Gandalf, however, sees through this polite dismissal. He points out the irony of using a cheerful greeting to mean the exact opposite – that the speaker actually wants him to leave, and things won't be good until he does.

quote: There is a lot more in him than you guess, and a deal more than he has any idea of himself.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is a lot more in him than you guess, and a deal more than he has any idea of himself.
summary: This quote suggests that a person has far more hidden potential, talent, and inner qualities than others might realize at first glance. More importantly, the individual themselves is often completely unaware of the true extent of their own capabilities and strengths.

quote: But the story has gone crooked, and I am left, and I cannot plead before the inexorable Mandos.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But the story has gone crooked, and I am left, and I cannot plead before the inexorable Mandos.
summary: This quote expresses a deep sense of injustice and powerlessness. The speaker feels that the true account of events, or their personal history, has been twisted or misrepresented, leading to a negative outcome. They are left alone to face the consequences of this distorted truth, and crucially, they have no way to defend themselves or plead their case before a powerful, unyielding authority figure or ultimate fate (Mandos), who will not listen to any arguments.

quote: His sword, Sting, Bilbo hung over his fireplace, and his coat of marvellous mail, the gift of the Dwarves from the Dragon-hoard, he lent to a museum, to the Michel Delving Mathom-house in fact.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: His sword, Sting, Bilbo hung over his fireplace, and his coat of marvellous mail, the gift of the Dwarves from the Dragon-hoard, he lent to a museum, to the Michel Delving Mathom-house in fact.
summary: Bilbo kept his sword, Sting, hanging above his fireplace at home. He also had a special coat of armor, which was a valuable gift from the Dwarves, taken from a dragon's treasure. Instead of keeping this marvelous coat for himself, he decided to lend it to a museum, the Michel Delving Mathom-house.

quote: One has indeed personally to come under the shadow of war to feel fully its oppression; but as the years go by it seems now often forgotten that to be caught in youth by 1914 was no less hideous an experience than to be involved in 1939 and the following years. By 1918 all but one of my close friends were dead. Or
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: One has indeed personally to come under the shadow of war to feel fully its oppression; but as the years go by it seems now often forgotten that to be caught in youth by 1914 was no less hideous an experience than to be involved in 1939 and the following years. By 1918 all but one of my close friends were dead. Or
summary: The author explains that you can only truly understand the full suffering of war if you experience it yourself. However, he feels it's often forgotten that being young during World War I (starting in 1914) was just as terrible an experience as being involved in World War II (starting in 1939). To show how devastating it was, he shares that by 1918, almost all of his close friends had died.

quote: We must walk open-eyed into that trap, with courage, but small hope for ourselves. For, my lords, it may well prove that we ourselves shall perish utterly in a black battle far from the living lands; so that even if Barad-dûr be thrown down, we shall not live to see a new age. But this, I deem, is our duty. And better so than to perish nonetheless - as we surely shall, if we sit here - and know as we die that no new age shall begin.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We must walk open-eyed into that trap, with courage, but small hope for ourselves. For, my lords, it may well prove that we ourselves shall perish utterly in a black battle far from the living lands; so that even if Barad-dûr be thrown down, we shall not live to see a new age. But this, I deem, is our duty. And better so than to perish nonetheless - as we surely shall, if we sit here - and know as we die that no new age shall begin.
summary: The speaker believes they must bravely face a dangerous situation, fully aware they likely won't survive. They expect to die in a terrible battle, far from home, and even if they succeed in defeating the enemy, they won't live to see the peaceful future that follows. However, they believe this sacrifice is their duty. It's better to fight and die, giving a new age a chance to begin, than to do nothing, die anyway, and guarantee that no better future will ever come.

quote: Understand one another? I fear I am beyond your comprehension. But you, Saruman, I understand now too well. I keep a clearer memory of your arguments, and deeds, than you suppose. When last I visited you, you were the jailor of Mordor, and there I was to be sent. Nay, the guest who has escaped from the roof, will think twice before he comes back in by the door.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Understand one another? I fear I am beyond your comprehension. But you, Saruman, I understand now too well. I keep a clearer memory of your arguments, and deeds, than you suppose. When last I visited you, you were the jailor of Mordor, and there I was to be sent. Nay, the guest who has escaped from the roof, will think twice before he comes back in by the door.
summary: The speaker tells Saruman that while Saruman may not understand them, the speaker now understands Saruman's true nature very well. They remember Saruman's past arguments and actions much more clearly than Saruman might think. The speaker recalls a previous visit where Saruman acted as an agent of Mordor, attempting to send them to be imprisoned there. Therefore, having narrowly escaped such peril before, the speaker makes it clear they will not willingly return to a dangerous situation or trust Saruman again.

quote: Non tocca a noi dominare tutte le maree del mondo; il nostro compito è di fare il possibile per la salvezza degli anni nei quali viviamo, sradicando il male dai campi che conosciamo, al fine di lasciare a coloro che verranno dopo terra sana e pulita da coltivare.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Non tocca a noi dominare tutte le maree del mondo; il nostro compito è di fare il possibile per la salvezza degli anni nei quali viviamo, sradicando il male dai campi che conosciamo, al fine di lasciare a coloro che verranno dopo terra sana e pulita da coltivare.
summary: This quote suggests that we shouldn't try to control every single thing in the world. Instead, our true responsibility is to focus on doing what we can in our own time and within our immediate surroundings. This means actively working to remove the 'evil' or problems from the areas we understand and have influence over. The ultimate goal is to leave a healthy, clean, and fertile world for future generations to inherit and make their own.

quote: It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered, full of darkness and danger they were, and sometimes you didn't want to know the end, because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was, before so much bad had happened? But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come, and when the sun shines, it will shine all the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you, that meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances to turn back, only they didn't. They kept going, because they were holding onto something...There's some good in this world. And it's worth fighting for.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered, full of darkness and danger they were, and sometimes you didn't want to know the end, because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was, before so much bad had happened? But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come, and when the sun shines, it will shine all the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you, that meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances to turn back, only they didn't. They kept going, because they were holding onto something...There's some good in this world. And it's worth fighting for.
summary: This quote explains that the most important stories are often those filled with immense darkness and danger, making it hard to imagine a happy outcome or a return to normal. However, it emphasizes that even the deepest despair is temporary, like a passing shadow, and a new, brighter day will always follow. The speaker realizes that the heroes in these enduring stories didn't give up, even when they had chances to turn back. They kept going because they believed in something good in the world, understanding that this good is worth fighting for, no matter how challenging the circumstances.

quote: There is some good in this world, and it's worth fighting for.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is some good in this world, and it's worth fighting for.
summary: This quote suggests that even when things seem difficult or negative, there are still positive elements, valuable principles, or good people in the world. These good things are so important and precious that they are worth defending, working hard for, and striving to protect or preserve. It encourages us to fight for what is right and positive, rather than giving up hope.

quote: In Tirion upon Túna the Vanyar and the Noldor dwelt long in fellowship.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In Tirion upon Túna the Vanyar and the Noldor dwelt long in fellowship.
summary: This quote describes how two groups, the Vanyar and the Noldor, lived together peacefully for a long time in a place called Tirion upon Túna.

quote: The banquet was very splendid, however, though I had a bad cold at the time, I remember, and could only say ‘thag you very buch’.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The banquet was very splendid, however, though I had a bad cold at the time, I remember, and could only say ‘thag you very buch’.
summary: The quote describes someone attending a magnificent and impressive banquet. However, despite the grand occasion, they were suffering from a bad cold. Because of their illness, when they tried to express their gratitude, they could only manage to mumble a slurred "thank you very much," a moment they clearly remember.

quote: For so it seemed to them: Lórien was slipping backward, like a bright ship masted with enchanted trees, sailing on to forgotten shores, while they sat helpless upon the margin of the grey and leafless world.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For so it seemed to them: Lórien was slipping backward, like a bright ship masted with enchanted trees, sailing on to forgotten shores, while they sat helpless upon the margin of the grey and leafless world.
summary: The people in the quote felt that a beautiful, magical place called Lórien was slowly slipping away from them. They perceived it as a radiant ship, adorned with enchanted trees, sailing off towards distant, forgotten lands. Meanwhile, they themselves were left stranded and powerless at the edge of a bleak, dull, and lifeless world, unable to do anything but watch as the vibrant Lórien vanished into memory.

quote: «Prenderò io l'Anello», disse, «ma non conosco la strada».
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: «Prenderò io l'Anello», disse, «ma non conosco la strada».
summary: This quote means that someone has bravely volunteered to take on a significant and perhaps difficult task, symbolized by "the Ring." However, immediately after offering to undertake this responsibility, they honestly admit that they do not know the way or how to achieve this goal.

quote: The chance never arrived, until Bilbo Baggins was grown up, being about fifty years old or so, and living in the beautiful hobbit-hole built by his father, which I have just described for you, until he had in fact apparently settled down immovably.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The chance never arrived, until Bilbo Baggins was grown up, being about fifty years old or so, and living in the beautiful hobbit-hole built by his father, which I have just described for you, until he had in fact apparently settled down immovably.
summary: The quote explains that a significant opportunity or adventure didn't come to Bilbo Baggins until he was quite old, around fifty years of age. By this time, he was living comfortably in his father's beautiful hobbit-hole and seemed to be completely settled in his life, appearing unmoving and unlikely to change his routine.

quote:
One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them,
One Ring to bring them all, and in the darkness bind them,
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them,
One Ring to bring them all, and in the darkness bind them,
In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.
summary: This quote describes the immense and terrifying power of the One Ring. quote: Un hombre perseguido se cansa a veces de desconfiar y desea tener amigos.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Un hombre perseguido se cansa a veces de desconfiar y desea tener amigos.
summary: This quote means that someone who feels constantly targeted or pursued eventually grows weary of always being suspicious and distrustful of others. The constant need to be on guard becomes exhausting. Because of this deep fatigue, they reach a point where they no longer want to live in isolation and instead begin to long for genuine connection and friendship.

quote:
Pippin: I didn't think it would end this way.

Gandalf: End? No, the journey doesn't end here. Death is just another path, one that we all must take. The grey rain-curtain of this world rolls back, and all turns to silver glass, and then you see it.

Pippin: What? Gandalf? See what?

Gandalf: White shores, and beyond, a far green country under a swift sunrise.

Pippin:: Well, that isn't so bad.

Gandalf: No. No, it isn't.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Pippin: I didn't think it would end this way.

Gandalf: End? No, the journey doesn't end here. Death is just another path, one that we all must take. The grey rain-curtain of this world rolls back, and all turns to silver glass, and then you see it.

Pippin: What? Gandalf? See what?

Gandalf: White shores, and beyond, a far green country under a swift sunrise.

Pippin:: Well, that isn't so bad.

Gandalf: No. No, it isn't.
summary: Pippin is worried about an impending end, but Gandalf reassures him that death isn't the final stop, but merely another step on a journey. Gandalf describes death not as a true ending, but a transition where the world's "grey rain-curtain" rolls back to reveal something beautiful and bright. He paints a picture of "white shores" and a "far green country" under a "swift sunrise," suggesting a peaceful and hopeful afterlife. Pippin, initially fearful, finds comfort in this description, realizing that such an end isn't bad at all.

quote: May the wind under your wings bear you where the sun sails and the moon walks," answered Gandalf, who knew the correct reply.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: May the wind under your wings bear you where the sun sails and the moon walks," answered Gandalf, who knew the correct reply.
summary: This quote is Gandalf's way of giving a powerful blessing or farewell. He wishes for the recipient to receive strong support and good fortune ("the wind under your wings") to guide them on their journey. The phrase "where the sun sails and the moon walks" refers to the highest, most glorious, and perhaps even magical places imaginable. Essentially, Gandalf is wishing someone a magnificent journey, filled with help, that takes them to their ultimate and most wonderful destination.

quote: So most men teach, and few men learn. Let the unseen days be. Today is more than enough.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: So most men teach, and few men learn. Let the unseen days be. Today is more than enough.
summary: This quote observes that many people offer advice or try to teach, but only a few truly absorb and apply what they hear. It then advises us to let go of worries about the future and what is yet to come. Instead, we should fully embrace the present moment, recognizing that today holds everything we need and is more than sufficient for our focus and contentment.

quote: We renounce no friendship. But it may be the part of a friend to rebuke a friend’s folly. And

quote:
Another bed was set beside him for his servant. Sam hesitated fora moment, then bowing very low: Good night, Captain, my lord, he said. You took the chance, sir.
Did I so? said Faramir.
Yes, sir, and showed your quality: the very highest.
Faramir smiled. A pert servant, Master Samwise. But nay: the praise of the praiseworthy is above all rewards. Yet there was naught in this to praise. I had no lure or desire to do other than I have done.
Ah well, sir, said Sam, you said my master had an Elvish air; and the twas good and true. But I can say this: you have an air too, sir, that reminds of, of – well, Gandalf, of wizards.
Maybe, said Faramir. Maybe you discern from far away the air of Numenor. Good night!

Faramir humbly dismisses the praise, explaining that he simply did what felt right and had no temptation to do otherwise, so he doesn't feel it merits special commendation. Faramir acknowledges the possibility, suggesting Sam might be sensing the ancient nobility of his Numenorean heritage before wishing him goodnight.

quote: Recovery (which includes return and renewal of health) is a re-gaining - regaining of a clear view. I do not say ‘seeing things as they are’ and involve myself with the philosophers, though I might venture to say ‘seeing things as we are (or were) meant to see them’ - as things apart from ourselves. We need, in any case, to clean our windows; so that the things seen clearly may be freed from the drab blur of triteness or familiarity - from possessiveness. Of all faces those of our familiares are the ones both most difficult to play fantastic tricks with, and most difficult really to see with fresh attention, perceiving their likeness and unlikeness: that they are faces, and yet unique faces. This triteness is really the penalty of ‘appropriation’: the things that are trite, or (in a bad sense) familiar, are the things that we have appropriated, legally or mentally. We say we know them. They have become like the things which once attracted us by their glitter, or their colour, or their shape, and we laid hands on them, and then locked them in our hoard, acquired them, and acquiring ceased to look at them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Recovery (which includes return and renewal of health) is a re-gaining - regaining of a clear view. I do not say ‘seeing things as they are’ and involve myself with the philosophers, though I might venture to say ‘seeing things as we are (or were) meant to see them’ - as things apart from ourselves. We need, in any case, to clean our windows; so that the things seen clearly may be freed from the drab blur of triteness or familiarity - from possessiveness. Of all faces those of our familiares are the ones both most difficult to play fantastic tricks with, and most difficult really to see with fresh attention, perceiving their likeness and unlikeness: that they are faces, and yet unique faces. This triteness is really the penalty of ‘appropriation’: the things that are trite, or (in a bad sense) familiar, are the things that we have appropriated, legally or mentally. We say we know them. They have become like the things which once attracted us by their glitter, or their colour, or their shape, and we laid hands on them, and then locked them in our hoard, acquired them, and acquiring ceased to look at them.
summary: Recovery isn't just about getting healthy; it's about regaining a clear perspective on things. This isn't about seeing objective truth, but rather about seeing things freshly, as if for the first time, without our usual assumptions or sense of ownership. We need to "clean our mental windows" to remove the dullness that comes from familiarity and possessiveness. When we feel we "know" or have "appropriated" something—whether it's a person, an idea, or an object—it often becomes trite. Like a shiny treasure we once coveted, we acquire it, lock it away, and then stop truly looking at or appreciating it.

quote:
Then the prophecies of the old songs have turned out to be true, after a fashion! said Bilbo.

You don't really suppose, do you, that all your adventures and escapes were managed by mere luck, just for your sole benefit? quote: Hope comes from the most unlikely places. The sun shines brightest in the morning, however dark the night was. At spring the first flower is brightest and the fruits are freshest. quote: Not fitting is it that the Elder Children of Ilúvatar should wed the Younger; nor is it wise, for they are brief, and soon pass, to leave us in widowhood while the world lasts. Neither will fate suffer it, unless it be once or twice only, for some high cause of doom that we do not perceive.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Not fitting is it that the Elder Children of Ilúvatar should wed the Younger; nor is it wise, for they are brief, and soon pass, to leave us in widowhood while the world lasts. Neither will fate suffer it, unless it be once or twice only, for some high cause of doom that we do not perceive.
summary: This quote explains that it is generally unsuitable and unwise for immortal Elves to marry mortal Men. The main reason is practical: Men are short-lived and die quickly, leaving their Elven spouses widowed and alone for an immensely long time, essentially forever. Beyond this personal sorrow, the speaker suggests that destiny itself usually prevents such unions. They only occur very rarely, and then only for a profound and important reason that is part of a larger, unseen fate.

quote: I say neither yea nor nay. I must consider this message and what it means under its fair cloak. ‘Consider well, but not too long, said he. ‘The time of my thought is my own to spend, answered Dáin. ‘For the present, said he, and rode into the darkness.

quote: if he had used all his power to guard Mordor, so that none could enter, and bent all his guile to the hunting of the Ring, then indeed hope would have faded: neither Ring nor bearer could long have eluded him. But
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: if he had used all his power to guard Mordor, so that none could enter, and bent all his guile to the hunting of the Ring, then indeed hope would have faded: neither Ring nor bearer could long have eluded him. But

In such a scenario, the Ring and its bearer would quickly have been caught, making escape impossible. quote: On the contrary! No, the burned hand teaches best. After that advice about fire goes to the heart.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: On the contrary! No, the burned hand teaches best. After that advice about fire goes to the heart.

It means that once someone has personally suffered the consequences of a mistake, like getting burned, then the warnings or advice they were given previously will finally make sense and be truly understood. In essence, some lessons are best learned the hard way.

quote: El trabajo que nunca se empieza es el que más tarda en terminarse.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: El trabajo que nunca se empieza es el que más tarda en terminarse.
summary: This Spanish proverb means that a task you never begin will, in a way, take the longest to complete—because it will never actually get finished. It highlights that if you keep putting something off, it will never get done. The quote emphasizes that the most important step to completing any job is simply to start it, as inaction guarantees no progress whatsoever.

quote: And there I got my hurt; for a man that flies from his fear may find that he has only taken a short cut to meet it.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: And there I got my hurt; for a man that flies from his fear may find that he has only taken a short cut to meet it.
summary: This quote suggests that trying to avoid what you fear is often counterproductive and can lead to more pain. The speaker implies they were hurt because they tried to escape something they were afraid of. It means that if you run away from your problems or fears, you might not actually escape them. Instead, you could find that by trying to avoid them, you've only found a quicker way to confront them, making the encounter inevitable or even worse. Essentially, facing your fears directly is often better than trying to run from them, as running away often leads you right back to what you dreaded.

quote:
Frodo peering forward saw in the distance two great rocks approaching: like great pinnacles or pillars of stone they seemed. Tall and sheer and ominous they stood upon either side of the stream. A narrow gap appeared between them, and the River swept the boats towards it.
‘Behold the Argonath, the Pillars of the Kings!’ cried Aragorn. ‘We shall pass them soon. Keep the boats in line, and as far apart as you can! Hold the middle of the stream!’
As Frodo was borne towards them the great pillars rose like towers to meet him. Giants they seemed to him, vast grey figures silent but threatening. Then he saw that they were indeed shaped and fashioned: the craft and power of old had wrought upon them, and still they preserved through the suns and rains of forgotten years the mighty likenesses in which they had been hewn. Upon great pedestals founded in the deep waters stood two great kings of stone: still with blurred eyes and crannied brows they frowned upon the North. The left hand of each was raised palm outwards in gesture of warning; in each right hand there was an axe; upon each head there was a crumbling helm and crown. Great power and majesty they still wore, the silent wardens of a long-vanished kingdom. Awe and fear fell upon Frodo, and he cowered down, shutting his eyes and not daring to look up as the boat drew near. Even Boromir bowed his head as the boats whirled by, frail and fleeting as little leaves, under the enduring shadow of the sentinels of Númenor. So they passed into the dark chasm of the Gates.

As Frodo was borne towards them the great pillars rose like towers to meet him. Giants they seemed to him, vast grey figures silent but threatening. Then he saw that they were indeed shaped and fashioned: the craft and power of old had wrought upon them, and still they preserved through the suns and rains of forgotten years the mighty likenesses in which they had been hewn. The left hand of each was raised palm outwards in gesture of warning; in each right hand there was an axe; upon each head there was a crumbling helm and crown. Great power and majesty they still wore, the silent wardens of a long-vanished kingdom. Awe and fear fell upon Frodo, and he cowered down, shutting his eyes and not daring to look up as the boat drew near. Even Boromir bowed his head as the boats whirled by, frail and fleeting as little leaves, under the enduring shadow of the sentinels of Númenor. So they passed into the dark chasm of the Gates.
summary: As Frodo's boat approached, he saw two enormous, ominous stone pillars that Aragorn identified as the Argonath, the Pillars of the Kings. These were not just rocks, but colossal, ancient statues of two kings carved directly from the stone, standing on either side of the river. They appeared like silent, powerful giants, with axes in their right hands and their left hands raised in a warning gesture, still wearing crowns and helms despite the passage of countless years. The sheer size and majesty of these figures filled Frodo with such awe and fear that he cowered down, closing his eyes, and even the brave Boromir bowed his head in reverence as their boats swiftly passed through the narrow gap between these imposing guardians.

quote:
It is easy for the student to feel that with all his labour he is collecting only a few leaves, many of them now torn or decayed, from the countless foliage of the Tree of Tales, with which the Forest of Days is carpeted. It seems vain to add to the litter. Who can design a new leaf? The patterns from bud to unfolding, and the colours from spring to autumn were all discovered by men long ago. But that is not true. The seed of the tree can be replanted in almost any soil, even in one so smoke-ridden (as Lang said) as that of England. Spring is, of course, not really less beautiful because we have seen or heard of other like events: like events, never from world's beginning to world's end the same event. Each leaf, of oak and ash and thorn, is a unique embodiment of the pattern, and for some this very year may be the embodiment, the first ever seen and recognized, though oaks have put forth leaves for countless generations of men.

We do not, or need not, despair of drawing because all lines must be either curved or straight, nor of painting because there are only three 'primary' colours. We may indeed be older now, in so far as we are heirs in enjoyment or in practice of many generations of ancestors in the arts. In this inheritance of wealth there may be a danger of boredom or of anxiety to be original, and that may lead to a distaste for fine drawing, delicate pattern, and 'pretty' colours, or else to mere manipulation and over-elaboration of old material, clever and heartless. But the true road of escape from such weariness is not to be found in the willfully awkward, clumsy, or misshapen, not in making all things dark or unremittingly violent; nor in the mixing of colours on through subtlety to drabness, and the fantastical complication of shapes to the point of silliness and on towards delirium. Before we reach such states we need recovery. We should look at green again, and be startled anew (but not blinded) by blue and yellow and red. We should meet the centaur and the dragon, and then perhaps suddenly behold, like the ancient shepherds, sheep, and dogs, and horses – and wolves. This recovery fairy-stories help us to make. In that sense only a taste for them may make us, or keep us, childish.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is easy for the student to feel that with all his labour he is collecting only a few leaves, many of them now torn or decayed, from the countless foliage of the Tree of Tales, with which the Forest of Days is carpeted. It seems vain to add to the litter. Who can design a new leaf? The patterns from bud to unfolding, and the colours from spring to autumn were all discovered by men long ago. But that is not true. The seed of the tree can be replanted in almost any soil, even in one so smoke-ridden (as Lang said) as that of England. Spring is, of course, not really less beautiful because we have seen or heard of other like events: like events, never from world's beginning to world's end the same event. Each leaf, of oak and ash and thorn, is a unique embodiment of the pattern, and for some this very year may be the embodiment, the first ever seen and recognized, though oaks have put forth leaves for countless generations of men.

We do not, or need not, despair of drawing because all lines must be either curved or straight, nor of painting because there are only three 'primary' colours. We may indeed be older now, in so far as we are heirs in enjoyment or in practice of many generations of ancestors in the arts. In this inheritance of wealth there may be a danger of boredom or of anxiety to be original, and that may lead to a distaste for fine drawing, delicate pattern, and 'pretty' colours, or else to mere manipulation and over-elaboration of old material, clever and heartless. But the true road of escape from such weariness is not to be found in the willfully awkward, clumsy, or misshapen, not in making all things dark or unremittingly violent; nor in the mixing of colours on through subtlety to drabness, and the fantastical complication of shapes to the point of silliness and on towards delirium. Before we reach such states we need recovery. We should look at green again, and be startled anew (but not blinded) by blue and yellow and red. We should meet the centaur and the dragon, and then perhaps suddenly behold, like the ancient shepherds, sheep, and dogs, and horses – and wolves. This recovery fairy-stories help us to make. In that sense only a taste for them may make us, or keep us, childish.
summary: The author explains that artists and students often feel overwhelmed by the vast amount of existing stories and art, believing there's nothing new left to create, like trying to add a few more torn leaves to an already massive forest. However, he argues this isn't true; just as every new leaf is unique despite following an old pattern, new creations can always emerge and find new meaning, even from old ideas. He warns against forcing originality by being deliberately strange, dark, or overly complicated, which leads to creative weariness. Instead, the real way to overcome this feeling is through "recovery": rediscovering fundamental beauty, simplicity, and wonder in the world, like seeing colors anew or encountering mythical creatures. Fairy stories, he concludes, are vital for this process, helping us refresh our perspective and appreciate both the extraordinary and the ordinary with fresh eyes.

quote:
Do you remember that bit of rabbit, Mr. Frodo?’ he said. ‘And our place under the warm bank in Captain Faramir’s country, the day I saw an oliphaunt?’

‘No, I am afraid not, Sam,’ said Frodo. ‘At least, I know that such things happened, but I cannot see them. No taste of food, no feel of water, no sound of wind, no memory of tree or grass or flower, no image of the moon or star are left to me. I am naked in the dark, Sam, and there is no veil between me and the wheel of fire. I begin to see it even with my waking eyes, and all else fades.

Instead, he feels exposed and consumed by a terrifying vision, a "wheel of fire," which is all he can see, even when awake, causing everything else to fade away.

quote: Then Beleg went out, and led in by the hand the maiden Nellas, who dwelt in the woods, and came never into Menegroth; and she was afraid, both for the great pillared hall and the roof of stone, and for the company of many eyes that watched her. The King, finding her simple honesty amusing, smiled and jokingly remarked that others also sit in trees but don't feel the need to tell him about it.

quote: The Machine is our more obvious modern form though more closely related to Magic than is usually recognised.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Machine is our more obvious modern form though more closely related to Magic than is usually recognised.
summary: This quote suggests that while technology, or "The Machine," is a clear and dominant part of our modern world, we often fail to see its surprising connection to "magic." It implies that just like magic, machines can perform incredible feats that seem almost inexplicable to those who don't understand how they work, producing powerful results that feel mysterious and awe-inspiring, much like a magical spell. So, even though we see machines as logical and scientific, they share a deeper, often unacknowledged link to the mysterious power we associate with magic.

quote: the pity of Bilbo may rule the fate of many

summary: This quote suggests that the most significant changes and events in world history – what it calls 'the wheels of the world' – are often not orchestrated or driven by the traditionally powerful. This means it's not the famous leaders, governors, or even divine forces that primarily shape the course of history. Instead, the quote argues that these profound shifts are frequently brought about by individuals who are seemingly insignificant, unknown, or lack conventional power.

quote: It was just as the 1914 War burst on me that I made the discovery that "legends" depend on the language to which they belong; but a living language depends equally on the "legends" which it conveys by tradition. (For example, that the Greek mythology depends far more on the marvellous aesthetic of its language and so of its nomenclature of persons and places and less on its content than people realize, though of course it depends on both. And vice versa. Volapuk, Esperanto, Ido, Novial, &C. are dead, for deader than ancient unused languages, because their authors never invented any Esperanto legends.). (letter 180)
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It was just as the 1914 War burst on me that I made the discovery that "legends" depend on the language to which they belong; but a living language depends equally on the "legends" which it conveys by tradition. (For example, that the Greek mythology depends far more on the marvellous aesthetic of its language and so of its nomenclature of persons and places and less on its content than people realize, though of course it depends on both. And vice versa. Volapuk, Esperanto, Ido, Novial, &C. are dead, for deader than ancient unused languages, because their authors never invented any Esperanto legends.). (letter 180)
summary: Tolkien observed a profound two-way relationship between legends and language. He realized that myths and stories are deeply tied to the language they belong to, gaining much of their power and beauty from the language itself, as seen with Greek mythology. Conversely, for a language to truly be alive and vibrant, it needs a body of traditional stories and legends to convey. He argued that this is why artificial languages like Esperanto fail to thrive; they lack their own unique, shared legends, making them "deader" than even ancient, unused tongues.

quote: My friend, you had horses, and deed of arms, and the free fields; but she, being born in the body of a maid, had a spirit and courage at least the match of yours.

quote: The Eldar, you say, are unpunished, and even those who rebelled do not die. Yet that is to them neither reward nor punishment, but the fulfilment of their being. They cannot escape, and are bound to this world, never to leave it so long as it lasts, for its life is theirs. Thus you escape, and leave the world, and are not bound to it, in hope or in weariness. Which of us therefore should envy the others?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Eldar, you say, are unpunished, and even those who rebelled do not die. Yet that is to them neither reward nor punishment, but the fulfilment of their being. They cannot escape, and are bound to this world, never to leave it so long as it lasts, for its life is theirs. And you are punished for the rebellion of Men, you say, in which you had small part, and so it is that you die. But that was not at first appointed for a punishment. Thus you escape, and leave the world, and are not bound to it, in hope or in weariness. Which of us therefore should envy the others?
summary: This quote contrasts the fates of Elves and Humans. It explains that Elves are immortal; they don't die, even if they rebelled. This unending life isn't a reward or punishment for them, but simply their inherent nature, which also means they are forever tied to this world and cannot escape it. Humans, however, die. While this is often seen as a punishment for a rebellion they barely participated in, the speaker clarifies that death wasn't originally meant as a penalty. Instead, death offers humans a way to leave the world, whether they do so with hope or weariness. The quote concludes by questioning which group truly has the better lot in life: the immortal Elves who are eternally bound to this world, or the mortal Humans who eventually get to leave it.

quote: Probably every writer making a secondary world, a fantasy, every sub-creator, wishes in some measure to be a real maker, or hopes that he is drawing on reality: hopes that the peculiar quality of this secondary world (if not all the details) are derived from Reality, or are flowing into it. If he indeed achieves a quality that can fairly be described by the dictionary definition: "inner consistency of reality," it is difficult to conceive how this can be, if the work does not in some way partake of reality. The peculiar quality of the "joy" in successful Fantasy can thus be explained as a sudden glimpse of the underlying reality or truth. It is not only a "consolation" for the sorrow of this world, but a satisfaction, and an answer to that question, "Is it true?" The answer that I gave to that question at first was (quite rightly): "If you have built your little world well, yes: it is true in that world." That is enough for the artist (or the artist part of the artist). But in the "eucatastrophe" we see in a brief vision that the answer may be greater—it may be a far-off gleam or echo of evangelium in the real world.

- Theoden, The Two Towers
summary: King Theoden is consumed by deep sorrow. He speaks of the Simbelmÿne flower, which has always grown on the graves of his ancestors, but now sadly must cover the tomb of his own son. He laments the harshness of these times, feeling cursed that the young are dying while the old like him are left to live. He fears he is witnessing the end of his family line, expressing the profound and universal grief that no parent should ever have to bury their own child.

summary: In this quote, Tolkien strongly rejects a certain kind of "progress" championed by those he sees as overly focused on data and lacking true creativity. He declares he will not follow their mundane, unchanging way of life or their uninspired art. Instead, he asserts his independence, refusing to submit to oppressive authority or abandon his own unique, creative spirit.

quote: Not even to see fair Lothlórien?’ said Haldir. ‘The world is indeed full of peril, and in it there are many dark places; but still there is much that is fair, and though in all lands love is now mingled with grief, it grows perhaps the greater.

quote: In Eregion long ago many Elven-rings were made, magic rings as you call them, and they were, of course, of various kinds: some more potent and some less. The lesser rings were only essays in the craft before it was full-grown, and to the Elven-smiths they were but trifles – yet still to my mind dangerous for mortals. But the Great Rings, the Rings of Power, they were perilous. ‘A mortal, Frodo, who keeps one of the Great Rings, does not die, but he does not grow or obtain more life, he merely continues, until at last every minute is a weariness. And if he often uses the Ring to make himself invisible, he fades: he becomes in the end invisible permanently, and walks in the twilight under the eye of the Dark Power that rules the Rings. Yes, sooner or later – later, if he is strong or well-meaning to begin with, but neither strength nor good purpose will last – sooner or later the Dark Power will devour him.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In Eregion long ago many Elven-rings were made, magic rings as you call them, and they were, of course, of various kinds: some more potent and some less. But the Great Rings, the Rings of Power, they were perilous. ‘A mortal, Frodo, who keeps one of the Great Rings, does not die, but he does not grow or obtain more life, he merely continues, until at last every minute is a weariness. And if he often uses the Ring to make himself invisible, he fades: he becomes in the end invisible permanently, and walks in the twilight under the eye of the Dark Power that rules the Rings. summary: Long ago in Eregion, Elves made many magic rings, some more powerful than others. Even the less potent rings, though considered minor by their makers, were dangerous for mortals. The most powerful ones, known as the Great Rings or Rings of Power, were incredibly perilous. A mortal who kept one of these Great Rings would not die, but would stop growing and simply continue to exist, with every moment becoming a burden. If they frequently used the Ring to become invisible, they would slowly fade away, eventually becoming permanently unseen and trapped in a shadowy world, under the control of a sinister Dark Power. Sooner or later, this Dark Power would completely consume them, no matter how strong or well-intentioned they were at first.

quote:
Niggle's Picture!" said Parish in astonishment. "Did you think of all this, Niggle? I never knew you were so clever. Why didn't you tell me?"

"He tried to tell you long ago," said the man; "but you would not look. He had only got canvas and paint in those days, and you wanted to mend your roof with them. This is what you and your wife used to call Niggle's Nonsense, or That Daubing."

"But it did not look like this then, not real," said Parish.

"No, it was only a glimpse then," said the man; "but you might have caught the glimpse, if you had ever thought it worth while to try."

"I did not give you much chance," said Niggle. "I never tried to explain. I used to call you Old Earthgrubber. But what does it matter? We have lived and worked together now. Things might have been different, but they could not have been better.
prompt_template:

"He tried to tell you long ago," said the man; "but you would not look. He had only got canvas and paint in those days, and you wanted to mend your roof with them. This is what you and your wife used to call Niggle's Nonsense, or That Daubing."

summary: Parish is utterly astonished by a finished artwork by Niggle, praising his cleverness. However, a third person explains that Parish had previously dismissed this very work as "Niggle's Nonsense" or "That Daubing," preferring to use the materials for practical things like mending a roof, and failing to see its potential. Parish argues it wasn't "real" then, but the man clarifies it was a "glimpse" that Parish could have appreciated if he'd tried. Niggle admits he didn't explain himself well, even calling Parish "Old Earthgrubber" because he was so focused on practical matters. Despite their past differences and misunderstandings, Niggle feels that their journey together has ultimately led to the best possible outcome.

quote: The valley of Minas Morgul passed into evil very long ago, and it was a menace and a dread while the banished Enemy dwelt yet far away, and Ithilien was still for the most part in our keeping. Nine Lords there were, and after the return of their Master, which they aided and prepared in secret, they grew strong again. Then the Nine Riders issued forth from the gates of horror, and we could not withstand them. Do not approach their citadel. You will be espied. quote:
The Silmarillion is the history of the War of the Exiled Elves against the Enemy, which all takes place in the North-west of the world (Middle-earth). Several tales of victory and tragedy are caught up in it; but it ends with catastrophe, and the passing of the Ancient World, the world of the long First Age. The jewels are recovered (by the final intervention of the gods) only to be lost for ever to the Elves, one in the sea, one in the deeps of earth, and one as a star of heaven. This legendarium ends with a vision of the end of the world, its breaking and remaking, and the recovery of the Silmarilli and the ‘light before the Sun’ – after a final battle which owes, I suppose, more to the Norse vision of Ragnarok than to anything else, though it is not much like it.

[From letter 131]
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Silmarillion is the history of the War of the Exiled Elves against the Enemy, which all takes place in the North-west of the world (Middle-earth). Several tales of victory and tragedy are caught up in it; but it ends with catastrophe, and the passing of the Ancient World, the world of the long First Age. The jewels are recovered (by the final intervention of the gods) only to be lost for ever to the Elves, one in the sea, one in the deeps of earth, and one as a star of heaven. This legendarium ends with a vision of the end of the world, its breaking and remaking, and the recovery of the Silmarilli and the ‘light before the Sun’ – after a final battle which owes, I suppose, more to the Norse vision of Ragnarok than to anything else, though it is not much like it.

[From letter 131]
summary: *The Silmarillion* tells the history of a long war fought by the Exiled Elves against their Enemy in the North-west of Middle-earth. It contains many tales of both victory and tragedy, but ultimately ends in a major disaster that marks the close of the ancient First Age. While the precious jewels, the Silmarilli, are recovered with divine help, they are permanently lost to the Elves, scattered across the sea, deep earth, and sky. The book concludes with a grand vision of the world's ultimate destruction and remaking, where the Silmarilli and the original light are finally recovered after a last great battle, which shares some resemblance to the Norse legend of Ragnarok.

quote: Tom Bombadil is not an important person – to the narrative. I suppose he has some importance as a ‘comment’. I mean, I do not really write like that: he is just an invention (who first appeared in the Oxford Magazine about 1933), and he represents something that I feel important, though I would not be prepared to analyze the feeling precisely. I would not, however, have left him in, if he did not have some kind of function. I might put it this way. The story is cast in terms of a good side, and a bad side, beauty against ruthless ugliness, tyranny against kingship, moderated freedom with consent against compulsion that has long lost any object save mere power, and so on; but both sides in some degree, conservative or destructive, want a measure of control, but if you have, as it were taken ‘a vow of poverty’, renounced control, and take your delight in things for themselves without reference to yourself, watching, observing, and to some extent knowing, then the question of the rights and wrongs of power and control might become utterly meaningless to you, and the means of power quite valueless. It is a natural pacifist view, which always arises in the mind when there is a war.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Tom Bombadil is not an important person – to the narrative. I suppose he has some importance as a ‘comment’. I mean, I do not really write like that: he is just an invention (who first appeared in the Oxford Magazine about 1933), and he represents something that I feel important, though I would not be prepared to analyze the feeling precisely. I would not, however, have left him in, if he did not have some kind of function. I might put it this way. The story is cast in terms of a good side, and a bad side, beauty against ruthless ugliness, tyranny against kingship, moderated freedom with consent against compulsion that has long lost any object save mere power, and so on; but both sides in some degree, conservative or destructive, want a measure of control, but if you have, as it were taken ‘a vow of poverty’, renounced control, and take your delight in things for themselves without reference to yourself, watching, observing, and to some extent knowing, then the question of the rights and wrongs of power and control might become utterly meaningless to you, and the means of power quite valueless. It is a natural pacifist view, which always arises in the mind when there is a war.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien explains that Tom Bombadil isn't central to *The Lord of the Rings*' main story or plot. Instead, Bombadil is an invention who represents something deeply important to Tolkien personally, even if he can't fully explain it. Tolkien clarifies that while the story's main conflict is between good and evil, both sides, in their own way, desire control. Bombadil, however, embodies a unique viewpoint: someone who has given up the need for control and power, finding joy and meaning in things simply for what they are, without relating them to himself. For such a person, the entire concept of power and who wields it becomes meaningless. Tolkien describes this as a natural pacifist perspective that often arises during times of conflict.

summary: This story recounts a sad tale from a long time ago when the Ents and Entwives lived together. However, their fundamental desires and ways of loving the world began to differ significantly. The Ents cherished the vast, untamed forests, the wild trees, and the high hills, preferring to live in harmony with nature, speaking with trees and Elves, and taking only what was freely given. The Entwives, on the other hand, focused on smaller trees and sunny meadows, cultivating specific plants like apples and cherries. They didn't wish to speak *with* these plants, but rather to command them, making them grow exactly as desired to achieve order, plenty, and a fixed sense of peace. This core difference in their approach to nature ultimately led them to drift apart.

quote: But when Glaurung felt his death-pang, he screamed, and in his dreadful throe he heaved up his bulk and hurled himself across the chasm, and there lay lashing and coiling in his agony. And he set all in a blaze about him, and beat all to ruin, until at last his fires died, and he lay still. Now Gurthang had been wrested from Turambar’s hand in the throe of Glaurung, and it clave to the belly of the dragon. Turambar therefore crossed the water once more, desiring to recover his sword and to look upon his foe; and he found him stretched at his length, and rolled upon one side, and the hilts of Gurthang stood in his belly. Then Turambar seized the hilts and set his foot upon the belly, and cried in mockery of the dragon and his words at Nargothrond: ‘Hail, Worm of Morgoth! Well met again! Die now and the darkness have thee! Thus is Túrin son of Húrin avenged.’ Then he wrenched out the sword, but a spout of black blood followed it, and fell on his hand, and the venom burned it. And thereupon Glaurung opened his eyes and looked upon Turambar with such malice that it smote him as a blow; and by that stroke and the anguish of the venom he fell into a dark swoon, and lay as one dead, and his sword was beneath him.

summary: As the dragon Glaurung died, he thrashed violently in agony, causing destruction and fire around him, before finally becoming still. Turambar, who had wounded him, returned to retrieve his sword, which was stuck in the dragon's body. He stood over the dead beast and taunted it, declaring his revenge. When he pulled out the sword, black, poisonous blood spurted onto his hand, burning it. Glaurung then briefly opened his eyes and looked at Turambar with intense hatred. This look, combined with the burning venom, caused Turambar to fall into a deep faint, collapsing as if dead with his sword beneath him.

quote: All that he saw was shapely, but the shapes seemed at once clear cut, as if they had been first conceived and drawn at the uncovering of his eyes, and ancient as if they had endured for ever. It's the feeling you get when you encounter something incredibly beautiful, vast, mysterious, or unexpected that captures your full attention. This state can make you feel small yet connected to something immense, sparking a desire to understand or simply appreciate the grandeur and mystery of what you're experiencing.

"All of them at once.

The other person responds that it encompasses all of these interpretations at once, highlighting how a common phrase can carry multiple layers of meaning simultaneously.

quote:
I don’t like anything here at all, said Frodo, Step or stone, breath or bone.  Earth, air and water all seem accursed.  But so our path is laid.
            Yes, that’s so, said Sam.  And we shouldn’t be here at all, if we’d known more about it before we started.  But I suppose it’s often that way.  The brave things in the old tales and songs, Mr. Frodo: adventure, as I used to call them.
            I used to think that they were things the wonderful folk of the stories went out and looked for because they wanted them, because they were exciting and life was a bit dull, a kind of sport as you might say.  But that’s not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind.
            Folk just seem to have landed in them, usually – their paths were laid that way, as you put it.  But I expect they had lots of chances like us, of turning back, only they didn’t.  And if they had, we shouldn’t know, because they’d have been forgotten. 
            We hear about those as just went on – and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end.  You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same – like Mr. Bilbo.  But those aren’t always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in.  I wonder what sort of tale we fallen into?"
I wonder, said Frodo, But I don’t know. And that’s the way of a real tale. Take any one that you’re fond of. You may know, or guess, what kind of a tale it is, happy-ending or sad-ending, but the people in it don’t know. And you don’t want them to." 'No, sir, of course not. Beren now, he never thought he was going to get that Silmaril from the Iron Crown in Thangorodrim, and yet he did, and that was a worse place and a blacker danger than ours. But that's a long tale, of course, and goes on past the happiness and into grief and beyond it – and the Silmaril went on and came to Earendil. And why, sir, I never thought of that before! We've got – you've got some of the light of it in that star-glass that the Lady gave you! Why, to think of it, we're in the same tale still! It's going on. Don't the great tales never end?' 'No, they never end as tales,' said Frodo. 'But the people in them come, and go when their part's ended. Our part will end later – or sooner.

He believes that the heroes of old tales were simply those who, despite opportunities to turn back, chose to press on, and that their own story is much the same. They both realize their journey isn't just a personal quest but part of a much larger, ancient, and ongoing "great tale" that connects to past legends. While the characters in these grand stories eventually complete their roles and depart, the overarching tale itself never truly ends.

quote: Éowyn of Rohan, I say to you that you are beautiful. In the valleys of our hills there are flowers fair and bright, and maidens fairer still; but neither flower nor lady have I seen till now in Gondor so lovely, and so sorrowful. It may be that only a few days are left ere darkness falls upon our world, and when it comes I hope to face it steadily; but it would ease my heart, if while the Sun yet shines, I could see you still. For you and I have both passed under the wings of the Shadow, and the same hand drew us back.

quote: September 1937, and for its fiftieth anniversary edition Rayner Unwin suggested to me that it would be of interest to include in it some unpublished or little known illustrations by my father, and also one of three manuscript sheets (each written on both sides, making six pages in all) that alone survive today of the original draft of the first chapter, An Unexpected Party. This preface is mostly concerned with this text and with pictures and designs; an account of the writing of The Hobbit (or what can be known of it) and the story of its publication are given by Humphrey Carpenter in J.R.R.Tolkien: A Biography, pp. 177-82.

This preface is mostly concerned with this text and with pictures and designs; an account of the writing of The Hobbit (or what can be known of it) and the story of its publication are given by Humphrey Carpenter in J.R.R.Tolkien: A Biography, pp. 177-82.
summary: In September 1937, for a special anniversary edition of *The Hobbit*, publisher Rayner Unwin suggested including some rare or previously unseen illustrations by the author's father, J.R.R. Tolkien. He also proposed adding one of the few surviving original draft pages from the first chapter, "An Unexpected Party." This particular page was preserved because it contained the very first sketch of Thror's Map. This introduction is mainly about these texts, pictures, and designs, while the complete story of how *The Hobbit* was written and published is detailed in Humphrey Carpenter's biography of J.R.R. Tolkien.

quote:
Where are you going, Master?' cried Sam, though at last he understood what was happening.
'To the Havens, Sam,' said Frodo.
'And I can't come.'
'No, Sam. Not yet anyway, not further than the Havens. Though you too were a Ring-bearer, if only for a little while. Your time may come. Do not be too sad, Sam. You cannot always be torn in two. You will have to be one and whole, for many years. You have so much to enjoy and to be, and to do.'
'But,' said Sam, and tears started in his eyes, 'I thought you were going to enjoy the Shire, too, for years and years, after all you have done.'
'So I thought too, once. But I have been deeply hurt, Sam. I tried to save the Shire, and it has been saved, but not for me. It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them.

He concludes by saying that sometimes, to save something precious, one must sacrifice it for oneself so that others may keep and enjoy it.

Into his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it, that having the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this, we shall put him out of reckoning.
summary: The speaker suggests that they should pretend to be foolish to deceive their Enemy. While the Enemy is very clever and carefully plans everything with malicious intent, his major flaw is that he only understands the desire for power and assumes everyone else shares this ambition. He cannot imagine anyone refusing power, especially not having the powerful Ring and then choosing to destroy it. By aiming to destroy the Ring, rather than use it, they will act in a way the Enemy cannot predict or understand, which will disrupt his plans and put him at a disadvantage.

prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Through him has pain and misery been made in the clash of overwhelming musics; and with confusion of sound have cruelty, and ravening, and darkness, loathly mire and all putrescence of thought or thing, foul mists and violent flame, cold without mercy, been born, and death without hope. Yet is this through him and not by him; and he shall see, and ye all likewise, and even shall those beings, who must now dwell among his evil and endure through Melko misery and sorrow, terror and wickedness, declare in the end that it redoundeth only to my great glory, and doth but make the theme more worth the hearing, Life more worth the liv- ing, and the World so much the more wonderful and marvellous, that of all the deeds of Ilúvatar it shall be called his mightiest and his loveliest.
summary: This passage explains that a being named Melko introduced all forms of pain, misery, cruelty, darkness, and death into the world through his discordant actions. However, the speaker clarifies that while these evils came *through* Melko, they were not truly *created* by him. Instead, the speaker (Ilúvatar) declares that even the suffering caused by Melko will ultimately serve Ilúvatar's own great glory. Ilúvatar believes this adversity makes the overall "theme" or story of existence more profound, life more valuable, and the world itself more wonderful and marvelous, to the point that this entire process is considered Ilúvatar's mightiest and most beautiful creation.
